More than most, this is an artist that requires some explanation so if you come to the museum that he designed himself, you'll get a lot more out of the visit if you go on a guided tour.

reviewnospace: Dali Theatre-Museum (Teatro-Museo Dali) is unique since it is surprising the visitor with all great works from Dali. The works are above and beyond all imagination and while you go between the works you get surprise from the ideas and creation skills Dali has. Don't miss this place!
titleopinion: Above and beyond any immagination. Dali Theatre-Museum (Teatro-Museo Dali) is unique since it is surprising the visitor with all great works from Dali. The works are above and beyond all imagination and while you go between the works you get surprise from the ideas and creation skills Dali has. Don't miss this place!

reviewnospace: In Dali's career there is a tension between Dali the skilled (sometimes genius) artist and Dali the cynical showman and commercial provocateur. Fans of the second will like his museum in Figueres. Fans of the first may be a little disappointed. it should also be noted that the frequently tight spaces in the museum do not handle well the enormous crowds that cram in there these days. Also of note: the museum is only partly accessible to wheelchair users, though in all fairness the administration admits this straight up and passes on the entrance fee.

quote: a wonderful museum for Dali admirers
reviewnospace:
Dali had a very creative imagination that he applied to various arts: paintings, sculptors, jewels, furnitures. You can see all that in the museum.

The museum is about 15 minutes away by taxi rom the TGV train station. Be careful, because there is another station, if you want to take a train to leave Figures.

We arrived around 1 pm and didn't have to wait in line for the tickets, which we got right away without any reservation.
We had to leave our suitcases after the entrance, on the left.
We took about 2 hours to visit the entire museum and all its collections, without a guide.

It was a very interesting visit.

reviewnospace: Dali designed, funded and filled this museum with art. His most famous works hang in National Galleries elsewhere, while the Theatre-Museum contains a more personal collection. There is a portrait of his father, painted by Dali aged 16, and numerous works of Gala. The collection is a enormous retrospective. The Jewellery museum is stunning-if you want to see a gold space elephant or melting clock studded with precious gems, this is the place to go.

The Jewellery museum is stunning-if you want to see a gold space elephant or melting clock studded with precious gems, this is the place to go.

reviewnospace: Dali was far more ahead of his time than I had realized; this was one of my favorite sites in Spain. His jewelry, in the small museum next door, was beautifully detailed and a highlight. Do not miss this on your visit to Spain.
titleopinion: Eye Popping!. Dali was far more ahead of his time than I had realized; this was one of my favorite sites in Spain. His jewelry, in the small museum next door, was beautifully detailed and a highlight. Do not miss this on your visit to Spain.

quote: Amazing artist with so much versatility & fantastic sense of humor.
reviewnospace: Dali is by far my favorite artist after visiting Teatro-Museo Dali. From dancing circles around some of Picassos drawings to jewelry, to coin operated funny art in the courtyard to enless sketches that remind me of Gary Larson's Far Side to interpretive furniture art mimicking Warhol's Marilyn images. Its overwhelming and breathtaking. Give yourself several hours to absorb and enjoy this cute little town, Figueres, Spain.

quote: Take a day out for the Dali experience
reviewnospace:
We were debating this one as it was a long day tour but in the end sense won out and we headed off to Girona and Figueres to see the countryside and the Dali Museum. It was a fresh wack to the brain - quite the antidote to days of churches and relics.

Quite out there in many ways, possible not that child friendly in some of the areas but definitely thought provoking and revealing about the motivations and aspriations of Dali across his career.
Gala is everywhere as you might expect if you know the backstory.

Lots of time, unlike a few other 'rushed tours' i will be commenting on soon:)
It was very memorable in a good way. Make the investment of time and you wont regret it.

reviewnospace:
The Teatre-Museu Dalí (1904-1989) is located in the former Municipal Theatre of Figueres a 19th century building destroyed during the Spanish Civil War. On its ruins Dalí decided to create his museum.
It was inaugurated in 1974 and is considered to be the last great work of Salvador Dalí.
Everything was designed by the artist so you can immerse yourself in his surrealistic world.The collection is a retrospective of Dali's works presented around the rooms allowing you to capture his first artistic experiences, surrealism, nuclear mysticism and his passion for science.They guide you to the works of the last part of his life.
The tower is a must see. The jewelry collection is exhibited there and it is fabulous!!!
He died at the private quarters in the tower, but that area is of limits.
titleopinion: PALACE OF SURREALISM. The Teatre-Museu Dalí (1904-1989) is located in the former Municipal Theatre of Figueres a 19th century building destroyed during the Spanish Civil War. On its ruins Dalí decided to create his museum. It was inaugurated in 1974 and is considered to be the last great work of Salvador Dalí.  Everything was designed by the artist so you can immerse yourself in his surrealistic world.The collection is a retrospective of Dali's works presented around the rooms allowing you to capture his first artistic experiences, surrealism, nuclear mysticism and his passion for science.They guide you to the works of the last part of his life. The tower is a must see. The jewelry collection is exhibited there and it is fabulous!!! He died at the private quarters in the tower, but that area is of limits.

quote: The place was in a shambles on a Sunday. Very poor organization.
reviewnospace: Whilst the Museum in itself is worth a visit - very rich in Dali` paintings - the organization was very bad. Perhaps Sunday is not a day to visit this Museum since it was teeming with school children and tours. One could hardly have a look at the paintings.

quote: Cool and interesting museum designed by Dali
reviewnospace: Long lines, but the outside of the building and grounds were so interesting that it took a while to absorb it all. It was extremely crowded and its not even "the season". Tour groups. The crowds kept me from seeing the artwork in a thoughtful way but the museum is filled with every imaginable...as well as those that are unimaginable...form of art. Dali chose and placed everything in and out and it was quite fascinating.

reviewnospace:
We had been warned to arrive early at the museum, and so we did and were pleasantly surprised to encounter no queues at all. For the first hour or so (from 10 am) it was almost as though we had the place to ourselves. Then the tours began to arrive and we understood the wisdom of the advice we had been given.

Brilliant exhibits - so many early works of Dali as well as later ones. Obviously, if you're visiting this town, you're a Dali fan. The museum is well laid out and does not disappoint.

reviewnospace:
Cool and interesting museum, designed by Dalí himself so you can feel that the museum is very authentic.
I think anyone who enjoys Dali love this place, the museum has a wide range of his work.
You should come early to avoid a long line.

quote: Museum is Great, but Some Stuff I Wish I Could Forget
reviewnospace: This museum was very well done (probably because Dali did most of it himself). I'm not an art buff and I mostly wanted to go because I remember seeing the crazy dreamscape type paintings in history classes - the pg-13 stuff. What I wasn't expecting was the hallway of drawings with fantastical creatures and random phalluses ejaculating into their own or somebody else's mouth. It will take me awhile to get those out of my head. So...probably not a great pick for kids old enough to notice that type of thing.

Icing on cake being the jewellery collection which I found breathtaking.Went on May Day so queue long, advisable to book in advance or go early. Bonus of Labour day was fantastic street market, live musicians & circus

quote: Exciting museum but little crowd control
reviewnospace: We were here on October 2nd in the morning, and initially the place wasn't too crowded. Then 2 tour buses pulled up and disgorged loads of Russian or Ukrainian tourists, and it became hard to move on the upper floors. The works span Dali's life and the collection is really interesting, but it became hard to see the works or even to pass by in the hallways, with the numbers of people that were in the building. It spoiled the viewing of the pictures. We would return but at a less popular time of day (if there is such a thing).
titleopinion: Exciting museum but little crowd control. We were here on October 2nd in the morning, and initially the place wasn't too crowded. Then 2 tour buses pulled up and disgorged loads of Russian or Ukrainian tourists, and it became hard to move on the upper floors. The works span Dali's life and the collection is really interesting, but it became hard to see the works or even to pass by in the hallways, with the numbers of people that were in the building. It spoiled the viewing of the pictures. We would return but at a less popular time of day (if there is such a thing).

reviewnospace: The sheer scale is what sticks in the memory. Most of the really famous stuff is actually in Madrid but this collection is valuable because of the sheer volume of material it covers. Get there really to avoid some of the numbers. Can't completely avoid them as there are a lot of group tours. Queues are quite short for individual visitors.
titleopinion: Got to be done. The sheer scale is what sticks in the memory. Most of the really famous stuff is actually in Madrid but this collection is valuable because of the sheer volume of material it covers. Get there really to avoid some of the numbers. .. by which I mean unusual but fun. I go to a lot of museums so I really like finding ones that are unique, and this one is.
I was there in the morning and it was quite crowded, and my guide said it is even more crowded later in the day!
I went as part of a day trip, booked though Viator, from Barcelona to Figures and Cadaques. I found the trip very worthwhile, but I liked Cadaques (and the Dali house there) more than this place - I don't think it's worth taking a day away from Barcelona just to see this museum.

reviewnospace: We went ton a rainy day and the queues were still enormous! Amazing building. Good value, we were expecting to pay more.

reviewnospace: This museum is as eclectic as his works.Designed by Dali himself and is as unconventional as his works. I personally prefer the Dali museum in St Petersburg, Florida which has a better design, and houses many of his grandest works. However, if you are a Dali fan, you cannot fail to visit this one.

quote: It's a must do if Figueras is in your way
reviewnospace: I liked everything outside and inside of the museum, from the entrance to exit. It is a true experience, a real contact with a work of a genius.
titleopinion: It's a must do if Figueras is in your way. I liked everything outside and inside of the museum, from the entrance to exit. It is a true experience, a real contact with a work of a genius.

reviewnospace:
Visited in April 2015, took a daytrip på Figueres from Barcelona just to visit this museum. Had my children with me, age 4 and 6. You are prompted to leave the buggy and any big bags at the entrence, then you can collect it when you leave which I thought was a nice service.

The museum is wonderful! Take your time and look at the art, find out all the clever details about the pictures. There is no café or nothing in the museum, so plan your visit. A lot of stairs and toilets only in one place at the groundfloor of the museum (very neat and tidy and many toilets available though) so with children there was a whole lot of running up and down the stairs.

quote: The Absolute Highlight of any Trip to Spain.
reviewnospace:
I've been to Spain multiple times and the country is great. I traveled it end to end. On my most recent visit, I flew to Barcelona and on the last day, decided to see the Dali museum in Figueres. Museum isn't the right word here. Playground? Art Amusement Park? Optical Illusion gallery? Jewelry exhibit, perhaps?

Well, all are correct. I have previously passed on the visit because Figueres is a bit off the beaten path. It is near the Costa Brava, and, there are many gorgeous little hamlets here, but Figueres was Dali's home, and now it is his homage, his museum, and actually his crypt - he's buried in the gallery.

You see all his periods, and how he has changed, but throughout you see that the man had sort of an intense "playfulness". Half of his items are optical illusions. His jewelry moves - a beating heart of jewels or a jeweled eye broach with a clock built into the iris. The building itself is fun.

I posted some pictures - although I can write, well, the pictures say it all.

You see all his periods, and how he has changed, but throughout you see that the man had sort of an intense  playfulness . Half of his items are optical illusions. His jewelry moves - a beating heart of jewels or a jeweled eye broach with a clock built into the iris. The building itself is fun.   I posted some pictures - although I can write, well, the pictures say it all.

reviewnospace: What an incredible place! not to be missed. Give yourself lots of time to explore this incredible place. Dali's imagination and his artwork is inspiring. The museum is not that big but it is packed with many artworks all full of little details that require time, patience and a sense of humour.

The museum is not that big but it is packed with many artworks all full of little details that require time, patience and a sense of humour.

quote: A glimpse into the odd world of Dali!
reviewnospace: This is an amazing museum - a must-see. Dali was strange but brilliant, some of his pieces truly show a unique intelligence! Every room is so different, it is good to either go with a guide or read up a bit about the museum as there are some truly amazing pieces to be viewed. It is also worth paying more and seeing the Jewellery exhibit, the pieces he designed are amazing.
titleopinion: A glimpse into the odd world of Dali!. This is an amazing museum - a must-see. Dali was strange but brilliant, some of his pieces truly show a unique intelligence! Every room is so different, it is good to either go with a guide or read up a bit about the museum as there are some truly amazing pieces to be viewed. It is also worth paying more and seeing the Jewellery exhibit, the pieces he designed are amazing.

quote: Hoax, does not worth the money nor time
reviewnospace: The museum has only few of Dali's famous paintings. I am a Dali's fan. Besides a couple of his well known paintings and the famous lip sofa - the museum has only mediocre works. Part of it is a celeb shrine. If that's the only reason you are in Figueres - don't bother.
titleopinion: Hoax, does not worth the money nor time. The museum has only few of Dali's famous paintings. I am a Dali's fan. quote: Lots of crowds but worth a look inside Dali's mind
reviewnospace:
Despite the vast size and limit on tourists, the museum was packed with students on tours.
The exhibits were cleverly presented and unbelievable in scale. It captured the Dali style of glitz and exhibitionism. Perhaps a night tour or off season might be better.
titleopinion: Lots of crowds but worth a look inside Dali's mind. Despite the vast size and limit on tourists, the museum was packed with students on tours. The exhibits were cleverly presented and unbelievable in scale. It captured the Dali style of glitz and exhibitionism. Perhaps a night tour or off season might be better.

quote: Nice but not easy to get around
reviewnospace:
Visited with a group over the Easter holidays. No where does it tell you that it is not suitable for anyone with mobility issues.
Once you enter the building there are 4 or 5 floors all with a lot of stairs and narrow corridors. My mother was not able to do stairs so left her on ground floor while I had quick look around, only to discover when I went back to ground floor that she then had to struggle up 2 flights of stairs to the exit.

quote: Well worth the train trip from Barcelona
reviewnospace: This guy was genius and his museum reflects it. Many animate and inanimate works from tiny peep holes into amazing displays and huge installations. You wander around and every turn finds something new and spectacular. Mae West was my favorite. Don't miss the "Jewels" in a separate building after you exit the museum (keep your stubs). They are absolutely unreal and spectacular--each more exquisite and creative than the next.
titleopinion: Well worth the train trip from Barcelona. This guy was genius and his museum reflects it. Many animate and inanimate works from tiny peep holes into amazing displays and huge installations. You wander around and every turn finds something new and spectacular. Mae West was my favorite. Don't miss the  Jewels  in a separate building after you exit the museum (keep your stubs). They are absolutely unreal and spectacular--each more exquisite and creative than the next.

reviewnospace: Dali was a strange, gifted, bizarre artist. Read up on him before you go so you'll appreciate his art even more. This is a museum he built, so it shows his choices. Other museums have very different pieces. Interesting life and art.
titleopinion: Keep an open mind. Dali was a strange, gifted, bizarre artist. Read up on him before you go so you'll appreciate his art even more. This is a museum he built, so it shows his choices. Other museums have very different pieces. Interesting life and art.

reviewnospace:
Its just wonderful that someone with crazy imagination can be successful where in our life most things are regimented. Here its
all fun , even if a serious art historian would be dismayed. Most importantly it is full of young visitors who can make a start in art
appreciation.
titleopinion: A lovely surprise. Its just wonderful that someone with crazy imagination can be successful where in our life most things are regimented. reviewnospace: I missed an audio guide in the Museum and a final evaluation system as other museums like Palau Robert in BCN !!
titleopinion: Poor information !!. I missed an audio guide in the Museum and a final evaluation system as other museums like Palau Robert in BCN !!

quote: Worth seeing if you enjoy art
reviewnospace:
I am a big art fan and I only spent 2.5 hours in the museum. We arrived at noon and caught a 2:52 train back to Barcelona. It was a Saturday in March but there was no line. In that time, we saw every floor and artwork, plus the jewelry museum. It was still worthwhile. The hour train ride is lovely.

I am very familiar with Dali. I knew going in that a lot of his most famous pieces were in New York's MoMa (my home!), Madrid's Reina Sofia (visited days prior), Brussels, and other world-class museums. What this means for you is that you will see almost no melting clocks. His most familiar works will be missing.

What you get instead is a loveletter to his wife, Gala, who appears in many works. You see how he progressed as an artist; the fine lines of some of his surreal works and the chunkier smears of some of his more pedestrian landscapes. You will see a single telephone on a field of black. You will see a few paintings that are clearly mockeries of Picasso and other contemporaries. You will see a strange obsession with Velasquez. All this will give you insight into the artist himself.

I came away inspired and motivated and more informed than before. Occasionally, I laughed. If you're not really into Dali, you may not find a lot to justify the trip.
titleopinion: Worth seeing if you enjoy art. I am a big art fan and I only spent 2.5 hours in the museum. We arrived at noon and caught a 2:52 train back to Barcelona. It was a Saturday in March but there was no line. In that time, we saw every floor and artwork, plus the jewelry museum. It was still worthwhile. The hour train ride is lovely.   I am very familiar with Dali. I knew going in that a lot of his most famous pieces were in New York's MoMa (my home!), Madrid's Reina Sofia (visited days prior), Brussels, and other world-class museums. What this means for you is that you will see almost no melting clocks. His most familiar works will be missing.  What you get instead is a loveletter to his wife, Gala, who appears in many works. You see how he progressed as an artist; the fine lines of some of his surreal works and the chunkier smears of some of his more pedestrian landscapes. You will see a single telephone on a field of black. You will see a few paintings that are clearly mockeries of Picasso and other contemporaries. You will see a strange obsession with Velasquez. All this will give you insight into the artist himself.  I came away inspired and motivated and more informed than before. Occasionally, I laughed. If you're not really into Dali, you may not find a lot to justify the trip.

reviewnospace: We took a day trip to Figueres from our base in Narbonne. It was a lovely town and the museum was mind blowing. Entrance isn't cheap and there is so much to see a coffee shop would have been good but it is well worth going. Dali was a genius and you get to see why and how in this visit.

The museum of Dali is a must see if you are in Figueres. The is amazing.

A bit long so you can spend 2-3 hours easily, but very interesting and funny sometimes :)
I recommend to visit!

reviewnospace: Not being the first time I enjoyed browsing around this museum in the absence of millions of tourists. Useful to have a student card for reduced price of entrance ticket.

quote: a window into a complex mind
reviewnospace:
Dali made full use of his wealth to remodel and refurbish a burned out theatre with his quirky art, along with some of his personal art collection. To most of the world familiar only with his melting clocks and stick -like drawings , this exhibition will be eye-opening.
Expect crowds- even in the off season there are busloads of students there on field trips. An early start is recommended.
titleopinion: a window into a complex mind. Dali made full use of his wealth to remodel and refurbish a burned out theatre with his quirky art, along with some of his personal art collection. To most of the world familiar only with his melting clocks and stick -like drawings , this exhibition will be eye-opening. Expect crowds- even in the off season there are busloads of students there on field trips. An early start is recommended.

reviewnospace: I've been to a lot of museums and looked at a lot of art but this place is special. Maybe it's Dali's style but this entire place is a spectacle. You get the full surrealist effect but also see his more serious pieces, or stages in his life where he tried to mimic the classics. All in all this is the most fun I've ever had at an art museum. I highly recommend it to anybody who's even the slightest bit familiar and/or interested in his work.
titleopinion: A Truly Unique Experience. I've been to a lot of museums and looked at a lot of art but this place is special. Maybe it's Dali's style but this entire place is a spectacle. You get the full surrealist effect but also see his more serious pieces, or stages in his life where he tried to mimic the classics. All in all this is the most fun I've ever had at an art museum. I highly recommend it to anybody who's even the slightest bit familiar and/or interested in his work.

reviewnospace: If Dali designed the layout and instructed where the contents and artworks should be placed ... I would accept I am wrong and out of line. It seems all the best art has been sold to museums and collectors around the world and there is not much left of the Dali talent or experience in the theatre and the crowds just make the experience worse. I admire a lot of his work but very few originals worth seeing but then again I did not know him

reviewnospace:
Immerse yourself in the crazy world of Dali. It's over-the-top, confusing and crowded, but let yourself go with the flow and revel at this man's amazing imagination.
We did a day trip by train from Barcelona, a long day, with a longish walk from the Figueres Station, but well worth the effort. Probably one of the most memorable and fun art galleries/ museos I have ever seen.
Arrive early to avoid the queues and stay calm. Worth the trip.

quote: Creepily beautiful and interesting for everyone
reviewnospace:
I visited this group as part of our field trip to Spain (related to tourism). Not everyone was as excited to go, but afterwards really everyone just loved it. The guides over there know extremely much about Dali's life and the meaning of his paintings. You might not even like his style but the stories are interesting, therefore I definitely would recommend you to visit this museum with a guide. The museum has been created by Dali himself when he was still alive (which explains the look of the building) which makes it even more interesting. Finally, we also learned that Dali did not just painted but for example, he also created jewelry.

In short: please just visit this amazingly interesting place. But do not expect to see his most famous works such as the clocks and elephants because those are in New York and somewhere else.

Finally, we also learned that Dali did not just painted but for example, he also created jewelry.  In short: please just visit this amazingly interesting place. But do not expect to see his most famous works such as the clocks and elephants because those are in New York and somewhere else.

reviewnospace:
Had been in Spain various times without coming but always wanting to.
Took a train to figueres fom bcn (like 40 euros both ways)
Loveeeeed the museum...dali was such a talented artist.
You dont take that long to see the whole exhibit. ..about 3 hours. So plan having lunch in the city before going back.

reviewnospace: Youll need the whole day to visit from barcelona. The train ride cost 32e . It was a hike from the train station but it was worth it. In addition to Dali there was a littke gallery on pichot. The most well known paintings - melting watches etc are not at this gallery, but still fab!
titleopinion: so awesome. Youll need the whole day to visit from barcelona. The train ride cost 32e . It was a hike from the train station but it was worth it. In addition to Dali there was a littke gallery on pichot. The most well known paintings - melting watches etc are not at this gallery, but still fab!

reviewnospace:
We queued for about 30 minutes but it is worth every second. The museum is interesting, stunning and thought provoking. It is busy but I didn't find this detracted from the experience.
Plan where you are going to park before you get there. The parking building close by was busy and very tight for our people mover hire car.
titleopinion: Well Worth It. We queued for about 30 minutes but it is worth every second. The museum is interesting, stunning and thought provoking. It is busy but I didn't find this detracted from the experience. Plan where you are going to park before you get there. The parking building close by was busy and very tight for our people mover hire car.

reviewnospace:
Dali designed this theatre to display his works as he would like them to be seen, and therein lies the difference between this museum and most other museums devoted to a single artist, including the Dali museum in St. Petersburg, Florida.
We made a hard choice on our last day this time in Barcelona between visiting Montserrat and this Dali museum. The two attractions are completely different, so it really came down to mood. I was concerned that the town Figueres would be unimpressive outside of the museum. Thanks to restaurant reviews on Tripadvisor I found that the town had a lot going on, and in fact was more of a city with a Rambla (cafe-lined outside square with lots of action) and Tons of gourmet restaurants.
If you've seen Barcelona before, as we have, it's nice to get a feel for other parts of Catalonia.
There are two trains to bring you from Barcelona to Figueres, one fast (50 min) and the slower one which is around 2 hours. We mistakenly bought tickets for the slower one and it turned out to be a lovely and scenic ride through the country side and many small towns as well as Girona which is sort of a small Barcelona in that the architecture is outstanding and much of it is ancient.
We arrived around 3 and didn't have to wait in line to buy tickets. It was 24 euros for 2 adults.
If you love Dali, or if you love Art, let the master lead you into his vision in his "theatre of art."
Dali is buried here, in the crypt, below the stage.
Wonderful museum.
Prepare to be amazed.

If you love Dali, or if you love Art, let the master lead you into his vision in his  theatre of art.   Dali is buried here, in the crypt, below the stage. Wonderful museum. Prepare to be amazed.

reviewnospace: You cannot help but view this collection and marvel at the eclectic genius of Dali. The climax of the visit was the Dali jewels exhibit next door -- do not miss this opportunity to view a little-known facet of Dali's unique and intensely personal vision. The jewels exhibit ticket is included in the admission to the main exhibit, so visit, marvel and enjoy.

reviewnospace: You have to see it to appreciate how amazing this museum is. I cannot believed how good and interesting the whole museum is, the building itself is a work of art. The down side is that it was very busy with school kids and tours. Even though it was busy, there was no rush for you to move on to the next room (22 in total). The tickets cost 12 euros which included entrance to the jewel centre. The small collection of jewellery was beautiful. You can purchase tickets on line or at the entrance which we did, no queue for us. Well worth the money.
titleopinion: Amazing!. You have to see it to appreciate how amazing this museum is. I cannot believed how good and interesting the whole museum is, the building itself is a work of art. The down side is that it was very busy with school kids and tours. Even though it was busy, there was no rush for you to move on to the next room (22 in total). The tickets cost 12 euros which included entrance to the jewel centre. The small collection of jewellery was beautiful. You can purchase tickets on line or at the entrance which we did, no queue for us. Well worth the money.

reviewnospace:
You're guided through the Dalí Museum by numbers, but there are hardly explanations for the works of art you see. Apparently that's how Dalí himself wanted it. You have to guess what everything is about (or Google it afterwards or buy a book).
That doesn't change that the works on display are interesting and the world of Dalí is still something special. We drove here from Leucate in France before driving on to Girona and did not regret our stop.

Tip: if you do not have skip-the-line tickets, make sure to go at least half an hour before the museum opens, or you might have to wait in line for quite a while.
titleopinion: Into the world of Dalí. You're guided through the Dalí Museum by numbers, but there are hardly explanations for the works of art you see. Apparently that's how Dalí himself wanted it. You have to guess what everything is about (or Google it afterwards or buy a book).  That doesn't change that the works on display are interesting and the world of Dalí is still something special. Tip: if you do not have skip-the-line tickets, make sure to go at least half an hour before the museum opens, or you might have to wait in line for quite a while.

It's not overly clear what route you are meant to take through the theatre-museum but, hey, that's part of the experience. I'm sure we missed a room or two. The art is definitely not to everybody's taste and, perhaps, it's worth looking online to get some idea of what you might see. For me, Dali's work is more challenging than that of Magritte although I am pressed to know why exactly; it's more fantastic still, I think.

Whilst I had seen a number of his images over the last forty or so years, I had no idea that he had created such amazing jewellery. It really is superb.

titleopinion: Oh so Dali. A must see for Dali fans. In about an hour you can see some interesting works that have not been on exhibit elsewhere. Just next door you can walk through two floor of exquisite designs in the Dali Joies.

reviewnospace:
The museum is as unique as Dali himself was! The architecture is surprising, featuring huge eggs on the roof! The artwork is nicely displayed, the exhibition rooms are large, making for a pleasant experience even on a busy day. Loved the painting of Gala/Lincoln. Very creative. Not to mention the furniture that, seen through a large magnifying glass, turns into a woman's face. My favorite piece was a gorgeous oil painting Dali did during the Spanish Civil War, of a dark beach with a lonely telephone no one seems to call or answer.
The museum shop offers a wonderful mix of gifts inspired by the collection, and a great selection of books. Whether you are a Dali aficionado or not, make sure to visit the museum. You won't be disappointed!

reviewnospace:
Even if you are not a big fun of Dali, you still should visit this museum.
That's definetely one of the coolest museums in the world.
Everything is done so nicely ( of course, since Dali designed it himself), and both interiour and exterior of the museum are so different from anything else, that it makes you admire the place and remember it for all your life.
The paintings, figures, jewellery are all so different and you can understand what a genious was this man.
Bravo Dali!

quote: Really interesting and some tips to appreciate it even more
reviewnospace: As most of the reviews describe it , the museum is a must in Figueres and probably one of the most original artistic museum in the world ! We spent 3 hours altogether visiting it and we enjoyed every minute of it ! Here are some tips to fully enjoy the visit : first , if you are coming by car , there is free parking available on the street ( a dead end one ) beside the entrance to the Castell de Sant Ferran and it is only a 10 minutes walk to the museum . Second , there are many guides leading different groups and they seem to be competing for attention and they speak very loudly , so following one is quite natural and you get a lot of free explanations this way ! If you do not want to do this , pick the plan from the front office ,and follow it : it is quite clear but one has to follow the crowd as going against the flow could be quite bumpy ! For the smokers , there is a beautiful terrasse on the 3rd floor ! After the visit , if you are hungry or thirsty there are some interesting caffés and restaurants on the pedestrian alley at the left of the exit ! After the break , do not forget to visit the Jewel museum of Dali , it is included in the price and it is very interesting : there was only 4 other people with us while we were there !

reviewnospace: Once found in the centre of Figueres, the signs are small and a bit misleading , the artistic range of Dali sculpture and paintings is everything anyone could want, whether you love his work or are just interested in it. The building itself is also a bit of a masterpiece. One tip, parking is a problem, the car park signed for the museum has a barrier which is too low for campervans. We went in the lunch break and were able to get a space on the street as all the shops were closed.

quote: An absolute 'must see' before you pop your clugs
reviewnospace:
Nothing prepares you for what's in store. Allow LOTS of time. Be prepared for excitement, challenge, amazement, wonder, humour, colour, and some of the most wonderfully provoking exhibits - there were smiles on our faces for virtually the entire afternoon. Alas, not enough time.
Aspects and insights of Dali I never imagined.
We WILL go again, and again......our next visut is already in the planning.
Enjoy!

reviewnospace: I was staying in Girona and travelled to Figueres on the train for a day trip. As the Dali Museum was one of the major attractions in the town I along with friends decided to pay it a visit. None of us had any in-depth knowledge of Dali's work, but found the objects on display s generally fascinating. However I wished I had done some initial reading/research about Dali as it would helped me understand his work better and may have increased my enjoyment.

reviewnospace:
Visited this, the largest surrealist object in the world during a really windy (no jump) day while skydiving at Empuriabrava.

Located in "Placa Gala-Salvador Dali" in the small town of Figueres (approx 1 hr 30 mins East of Barcelona. Parking is a little difficult and there is no dedicated parking area for the exhibition, but there is "some" pay and display bays dotted around if you can manage to find one.

The gallery/ museum is fantastic and is well worth a visit even if your not a great fan ofDali's work. It is spread over an outside courtyard, a ground floor and three further floors and in true Dali style is not laid out in any particular order or preconceived route, and has no system or chronological sense to the layout.

The unique architecture of the museum makes it difficult for people with reduced mobility, there is a map located at the entrance showing which areas are accessible by wheel chair.

Closed on Xmas day and New Year's Day along with every Monday between 1st Oct - 31st May... Open 7 days a week between 1st June - 30th Sep.

No bags are allowed to be carried within the museum and there is a place to deposit them at the entrance. At the time of writing (Jan 2015) entry prices are €12 for adults and €9 for concession with children under age 9 going free...

Closed on Xmas day and New Year's Day along with every Monday between 1st Oct - 31st May... Open 7 days a week between 1st June - 30th Sep.   No bags are allowed to be carried within the museum and there is a place to deposit them at the entrance. At the time of writing (Jan 2015) entry prices are €12 for adults and €9 for concession with children under age 9 going free...

reviewnospace:
Reflecting Dali's genius, this museum is a piece of art! Dali himself played a prominent role in the creation of this museum, which is far beyond any usual art museum. By the fast train Figueres is just an hour from Barcelona, but by the regional train is about two hours - be careful the two trains depart from Barcelona about the same time and arrive at different stations at Figueres.
The Cathedral next to the museum deserves also a visit.

reviewnospace:
I took my family to the Dali Museum on a day trip from Barcelona. The only way to sum up the experience of going to this museum is chaos reigns everywhere. The museum was mobbed and people were everywhere. The layout of the museum is strange as you need to keep walking in circles - much like the Guggenheim in New York - only the corridors are much smaller and you are cramped in many locations.
So why the five stars? Because Dali is a genius and his work is amazing. Even without his famous painting The Persistence of Time - which is in the Museum of Modern Art in New York - his other works are brilliant. You don't even have to like art to love this place. There are plenty of visuals everywhere. Just one word of warning. If you don't want your young children see endless amounts of naked women in both paintings and models, bring a blindfold. They're everywhere!

reviewnospace: Even if you'd never heard of Salvador Dali you would been entranced by this place. Kinky, quirky, witty, awesome - it is without doubt the most entertaining and eccentric museum I have ever visited. There is never a dull moment, every twist and turn of the way. Whatever Dali did, he did it large. And what a painter - his talent slightly overlooked by his larger than life personality. You could feel his presence everywhere, probably laughing at all the open mouths. A must if you are anywhere near enough to visit.

reviewnospace:
The Dali Museum in St. Petersburg Florida inspired us to become admirers of Dali’s work, so we were excited to visit the Dali Theatre-Museum in Figueres and Dali House in Cadaques last month on a Viator tour from Barcelona with lovely guide Julia.

We spent a couple of fascinating hours at the indoor-outdoor museum which is designed to spotlight a wide range of Dali works and relics. A visit to the exhibit of the exquisite Dali jewels is included. It was a sleepy Sunday morning in November; the museum was not overly crowded and it was possible to take our time and linger where we wanted.

Dali’s craftsmanship is so superb and the range of materials he mastered was amazingly broad. This is the perfect place for showcasing the imagination, artistry and wit that made up his spectacular genius.
titleopinion: Special place for Dali aficionados. The cashier was rude and wouldn't have our UK student ID's because she couldn't see the expiration date on the card so beware, in case you were hoping for a discount.

quote: If I could give a higher rating I would!
reviewnospace: This is the most amazing, out there, fantastical place. I was already a Dali fan, but I have now been a repeat visitor to my all time favourite place in Spain!
titleopinion: If I could give a higher rating I would!. This is the most amazing, out there, fantastical place. I was already a Dali fan, but I have now been a repeat visitor to my all time favourite place in Spain!

reviewnospace: As museums go, this one is the best and I have come away thinking this man was a visionary yet crazy. The art is fascinating and I am totally enamoured. He really was a genius. They also had a jewellery exhibition which, while small is absolutely beautiful. I purchased books of his art as gifts for friends from the little shop at the exit and hauled them around Spain. They were worth it. We did a day trip from Barcelona as a group of 6 at a very cheap price through Barcelona City Tours. I am very glad we did not miss this and really you should not miss this either.

reviewnospace: In my many trips to Barcelona I always wanted to visit the museum. last week I finally made it. It was a nice 2 hour trip from Barcelona into the small town of figueras. Without a map or anything i got lost a bit in the town and it was fun. I then found the museum and was surprised to be charged just 8 euros for the museum entrance. this also including the entrance to the jewels of dali. just amazing if you know a bit of his work, if you don't, you'll enjoy it as well. totally worth it

quote: If you like Dali, do not miss this museum !
reviewnospace: An outstanding overview of Dali and his masterpieces ! the museum is 10 minutes walk from the railwaystation or bus station. Entrance was 12 euro, we bought ticket on internet, so there is no queque at arrival (different entrance for prebooked visits). With the same ticket you can visit the Dali Jewels also, which are amazing. Everywhere you can take pictures, no flash. If you arrive by train from Barcelona (about 2 hours, trains many the whole day), on the way back you should stop for some hours in the city of Girona, an amazing architecture of coloured houses on the river banks, a beautiful cathedral and church on the hill. In summer there is a little train which takes you through the old center. Take a stroll in the narrow streets of the old jewish quartier, one of the biggest in Europe, well preserved.

quote: A must if your a Dali fan
reviewnospace:
Amazing. Good to get there early, before the hordes arrive. They will let you store luggage which is nice. A small walk from the bus stop, if this is how you arrive. We arrived by train from Barcelona, bus stop right outside of station and bus driver was very helpful.
Amazing selection of Dali's work, dont miss out on his jewellery museum, which is round the back of the main entrance. Location is beautiful.

reviewnospace: Visiting The Dali Museum in Figueres, Catalonia is an adventure in itself. A feast for the eyes and imagination. We took the bullet train from Barcelona. the museum is a short walk from the train station. The museum in an ancient ruin of a theatre that has been retro fitted with stunning galleries. This museum is not very handicapped friendly, due to the origins of the building and the shoulder to shoulder crowds. However it is well worth the visit. I must say I was not much of a Dali fan before visiting, but the trip really did change my opinion of this famous artist. We had the benefit of having an excellent tour guide for this trip who gave us great narrative as we progressed though the museum. If you have the time while visiting Barcelona, this side trip is well worth your visit. I do regret that our tour did not allow us time to roam the town and shop. I could have easily spent the day.

reviewnospace:
What an interesting and quirky museum, we didn't expect to spend 3 hours here but thoroughly enjoyed it. It was very entertaining as well, which is not how one would normally describe a museum visit. See for yourself and you'll know what I mean.

Go there early if you want to avoid the crowd. The first hour was nice for us but as time passed, it got crowded. Sometimes we felt bad to hold back the line so we rushed past the art works. Don't miss the Dali jewellery museum next door.

How to describe it ? Like the artist may be , just amazing.

When you enter in this Museum you are just carried away in a universe apart.

You should do it , and you can spend the day inside because there is so much to see.

quote: Was he a genius or mad?
reviewnospace: Salvador was born and lived in Figueres, about a 1 hour drive north of Barcelona. He converted the town's theatre into a fantastic museum. Here you can see his development as an artist, the fantastic creativity he brought to his work and the multiple dimensions and techniques he explored. Make an appointment ahead of time and plan to spend at least a half day to explore this important art museum
titleopinion: Was he a genius or mad?. Salvador was born and lived in Figueres, about a 1 hour drive north of Barcelona. He converted the town's theatre into a fantastic museum. Here you can see his development as an artist, the fantastic creativity he brought to his work and the multiple dimensions and techniques he explored. Make an appointment ahead of time and plan to spend at least a half day to explore this important art museum

reviewnospace:
I had only a day to explore the world of Dali so chose the most accessible museum by train, in FIgueras, which is easily reached by regional or fast train from Barcelona. If you are a Dali fan or have a passing interest, I would recommend a visit. While I was visiting off season, I did so on a Saturday so there was an early tour bus group. Once the tour bus left, it was an easy museum to visit. There is a lot to absorb here. In addition to his more known works, e.g., the car with the boat hanging over it, there were some wonderful other works that truly exhibited how skilled an artist Dali indeed was. The guy was unique, that is for sure. Had I had the time, I would have gladly visited the other two museums in the area. I did not reserve ahead but one can do so and it is advisable during more popular times. The Dali jewels were also on display nearby when I visited and they were wonderful to see. There is not much to see in this town but I grabbed a quick and unimpressive lunch before I headed back to the city. There is a nice farmers' market in the center of town on the way to the regional train station on Saturdays, should that be your day of a visit.

I recommend this place highly.

quote: Easy and entertaining day trip from Barcelona
reviewnospace:
Such an easy train ride (on high speed train takes 55 minutes) from Barcelona-Sants to Figueres Vilafant. Once you arrive at the train station, signage is really easy to direct you into town and towards the museum. It appears that the train station is on the outskirts of town, so you'll be walking on a paved sidewalk through what feels like a neighborhood; just trust the signs; keep walking, and you'll be fine. You'll pass a pretty park, some interesting statues, into a more congested area of shops and restaurants, and reach the museum. We didn't have advance tickets, but after spending a short time in a queue we gained entrance. I had planned to spend a couple of hours in the museum, but I was completely unaware about the scope of Dali's works that are on display. If you're a Dali lover (or simply a museum lover), you need to plan on a larger amount of time here, in my opinion. I had read a review that said to plan for a half hour visit; that is totally inappropriate. I had other items on an itinerary that we abandoned when we saw the size of this museum. Caveat: we love museums; what an amazing opportunity to expand one's knowledge.

I knew very little about Dali before I arrived, and I have to caution that you won't really be exposed to much information explaining anything that you are going to see. I left the museum wanting to read more about Dali and his contemporaries; surrealism is quite entertaining! Pictures are allowed (without flash), but it's extremely difficult to take proper pictures because of the crowds (masses of people, huge congestion, quite popular) and the reflection from the protective glass on most framed paintings. There aren't a lot of places to sit and rest for a while; if you're lucky, you'll find some open seats in the courtyard so be prepared by coming in comfortable shoes and attire. No snacks on premises (that I saw) so come fortified; our hunger is what drove us away, finally, from spending more time! Even though we went, I would do some reading on Dali's life and return; it's that amusing and amazing.

He was way ahead of his time.
Worth seeing this venture of artistic expression, that covered every medium, including an extraordinary jewelry exhibit.
Go see it!

I was in Barcelona with my friend 7 days, we went there (in Barcelona) alone, but we took Catalunya bus turistic to visit Girona and Figueras. Nice agency.

reviewnospace: This museum shows you Dali's vast repertoire including his playfulness when pushing the boundaries. Book on-line as there are always crowds given Dali's popularity. Plenty of parking available in the nearby parking lot (for a fee) if you self-drive like we did. Allow plenty of time for a proper appreciation of this Teatro-Museo and don't miss the jewellery collection!

Allow plenty of time for a proper appreciation of this Teatro-Museo and don't miss the jewellery collection!

reviewnospace:
This is a must-see for Dali fans.

We decided not to take the train and opted in paying a little more for tour that included a stop in the city of Girona along the way. There is not much to see or do in Figueres--so we enjoyed the day trip and not having to deal with a train.

We got to the Dali Museum in the later part of the afternoon and it was quite empty and had it to ourselves. Because it was a tour, the guide had our tickets handed to us and he also gave us a quick overview of what to see and which direction to walk in. The museum map/guide provided at the entrance is sufficient- follow that plan/direction- it is well worth it. To all those complaining about getting lost- Dali wanted it to be a labyrinth- that was the experience he wanted.

Dali purchased this old theater that has been damaged in a fire and restored it - that is why Teatro is still in the name. This was the town that he was born and raised- you can still see his home- a rather ordinary building a few blocks away on Career Monturiol to contrast it to his rather extraordinary museum. Photography without flash is allowed in the museum.

The outside of the museum is covered with these plastered round items which is in the shape of the traditional bread from Figueres. The museum has eggs on the room adorned with gold figurines.

Must see inside.
the original theater is the scene of his Black Cadillac (one of 6 made, Al Capone rumored to have one) he had when living in the US. Above the car is an upside down ship with rain topped off by an umbrella. When a coin is put into the slot, the umbrella opens up and it rains inside the car- to him symbolizing how hard it is to get a cab in NYC in the rain.

"Abe Lincoln" - Look closely you see his wife Gala looking out the window. Look at the picture you took or stand across the way and you see the profile of Abe Lincoln

Dali's tomb in the basement

Custom furniture that when climb the stairs in room see the face of Mae West

Around the corner is Dali's Jewelry Museum- a worth see- allot about 20+minutes or so.

Definitely worth a visit if you have the time!

We decided not to take the train and opted in paying a little more for tour that included a stop in the city of Girona along the way. Abe Lincoln  - Look closely you see his wife Gala looking out the window. Definitely worth a visit if you have the time!

quote: Unexpected Great Trip outside of Barcelona
reviewnospace:
Traveling with a group of eight (8) from the US. Everyone decided since had a couple of days there to drive a little distance out of the city to the Dali Museum. I was not expecting to see what I saw. Never realized that he had done so much different types of art and with different medium. I know he was known for his surreal painting, but there was much more than that. Sculptures, jewelry, and a lot more that is to be enjoyed by all. Recommend this for anyone regardless of age, or how you feel about art in general.

Not to mention, the town is very charming, just do not recommend the little cafe in the courtyard south of the church for pizza. Everything was good except the pizza...

quote: Excellent stop on the way to Barcelona
reviewnospace: For me this was truly an amazing museum..very worth visiting! Having a guide to explain this unique and surreal collection of art definitely made it a more enjoyable experience!
titleopinion: Excellent stop on the way to Barcelona. For me this was truly an amazing museum..very worth visiting! Having a guide to explain this unique and surreal collection of art definitely made it a more enjoyable experience!

reviewnospace: This place is just a museum of Dali's pictures. The only three particular things there were the car, Dali's grave and the design of his house. A lot of tourists, we had to wait for five minutes, to see the grave.
titleopinion: Disappointing. This place is just a museum of Dali's pictures. The only three particular things there were the car, Dali's grave and the design of his house. A lot of tourists, we had to wait for five minutes, to see the grave.

reviewnospace:
This is like an entertainment park for adults. Dali is a very playful person. You can tell from the exterior of the building, it is composed of eggs and bread. Very very funny. Dali said using eggs and bread to decorate the building because everyone can relate and recognize them. ^^

Don't miss the little jewelry gallery. It housed one of the world's best Dali designed jewelry piece. (i think) Totally took my breath away when i saw it!!!

Dali has many games to play when the people inside the building. The thinker sculpture is being very seriously thinking.....and there is an octopus getting ready to attack him from the ceiling. And on the ceiling, you do not see the lovely angels' faces, instead you saw angels' feet and sole, getting ready to be fly to heaven. very very funny!!

You will be amazed of the amount of works Dali did in his lifetime. He also worked on furniture pieces, video and pixel arts, installations, jewelry.....etc. He also collaborated with one of my favourite photographer, Philippe Halsman, on a book just focus on Mustache. very very funny!!

Get ready to get entertain!! Highly recommended!!

quote: Get a guide...or else be art ardent art lover.
reviewnospace:
One thing about museums is that they are best understood along with a guide. Else, you just might struggle for get your bearing right. Especially so if the museum happens to be of the eccentric artist called Dali...

It was a good thing we had a guide. A very patient woman, who actually waited so many times for the group to assemble and reassemble. Dali was a genius, that I already knew. But watching the works of the master for the first time left me awe struck. I don't understand art much, but I do like to appreciate a good thing when I see one. And the museum was full of such good things.

Two works that struck me were Dali's concept of no thing having one single perspective and the the piece on May West, that also happens to be an apartment.
.
.
And just to spook you. Dali's grave is in the center of the exhibition hall. It was the wish of the great man that people walk all over his tomb. And walk all over they do..thousands in one single day.
.
Nothing much to do in the town except for this museum.

reviewnospace:
I had a Dali day.
From here to his birthplace in Port lligat it was a fulfilling day.

This welcoming environment starts the ride and what a ride it is….providing a timeline was absolutely fantastic and now assists one when pondering dali's vast array of work.
He was prolific.
He was fun.
He was mad.
But what a mind….

Upstairs is narrow and makes it difficult to stop and look sometimes…

Not to be missed is his jewellery housed in a separate building…whimsical, magical and with his etchings seeing his vision come to fruition is outstanding.

Most convenient way is take the full day tour...

reviewnospace: It is the #4 "must see" for me in Barcelona (after Sagrada Familia, Picasso and La Pederera). Take the fast train from Sants; it takes 1 hour from Barcelona to Figueres and costs 60 Euro for return ticket. Go as early as 9:45am (museum opens at 11am, exactly when train arrives), and return either at 2:45pm or 3:45pm. There is not much to do in Figueres.
titleopinion: #3 must see in Barcelona. It is the #4  must see  for me in Barcelona (after Sagrada Familia, Picasso and La Pederera). Take the fast train from Sants; it takes 1 hour from Barcelona to Figueres and costs 60 Euro for return ticket. Go as early as 9:45am (museum opens at 11am, exactly when train arrives), and return either at 2:45pm or 3:45pm. There is not much to do in Figueres.

reviewnospace:
The most amazing museum ....make sure that you take euro coins with you as many of the exhibits are motorised and you need to put in a coin to see them working. Your ticket will also entitle you to visit the jewellery exhibition which should not be missed. It is truly awesome.
Many of Dali's famous works of art and paintings are on permanent display, allow plenty of time to wander round and appreciate all the nooks and crannies. Remember Dali himself established this museum in the old theatre and he laid it out in his own quirky way. After your visit there are many gift shops, cafés and bars nearby. Get there as close to opening as possible in the height of the season to avoid queues. It is especially busy on rainy days. Visit their website and you can buy timed tickets in advance. In August they have special visits at night including Cava!

Hello, I did the first visit by night last August. This is just amazing.
I recon to arrive way before the opening as the museum gets really busy especially during holidays. Also best to park in the parking nearby. enjoy.

reviewnospace: As presented in the brochure, "the Dali Theatre-Museum must be appreciated in it's entirety, as Salvador Dali's masterpiece: everything in it was conceived and designed by the artist in order to offer visitors a real experience of delving into his captivating and unique world" His paintings and jewellery collection are exquisite. The exhibition of his car outside the building and the surprise associated with it (and the boat above) can't be missed.
titleopinion: Comprehensive Dali exhibit. As presented in the brochure,  the Dali Theatre-Museum must be appreciated in it's entirety, as Salvador Dali's masterpiece: everything in it was conceived and designed by the artist in order to offer visitors a real experience of delving into his captivating and unique world  His paintings and jewellery collection are exquisite. The exhibition of his car outside the building and the surprise associated with it (and the boat above) can't be missed.

reviewnospace:
The museum has an unforgettable look from the outside with the bread loaves on the walls to the giant eggs on the parapets. The entrance is not where you think it would be and you need to go around almost the back to get in. The museum covers almost all facets of Dali's art, but it is crammed into such small spaces it is hard to appreciate the works of art. The museum is packed and corridors are narrow and the constant flow of people makes it difficult to study the art as one would in a larger more spacious place. Photography is allowed without flash which is nice. Also note there are sections of the museum that some people will miss because the path is not well defined. The curving galleries are nothing more that narrow corridors and art is placed all along these corridors making it hard to view. The jewelry gallery is separate from the main museum and not so crowded. It is worth the extra price to visit this gallery.
The museum has a very nice gift shop with lots of fun items to buy. There is also reproductions of jewelry in the jewels section that are very nice.
If you like Dali, this is one of the certified authentic museums and should be a treat to see. If you are staying in Barcelona be aware the train ride up and back can take hours and make this an all day outing.

There is also reproductions of jewelry in the jewels section that are very nice. If you like Dali, this is one of the certified authentic museums and should be a treat to see. If you are staying in Barcelona be aware the train ride up and back can take hours and make this an all day outing.

reviewnospace: This museum blew away all of what I thought I knew about Dali. What an amazing place, highlighting many works of art from very impressionistic early years to finding surrealism. A must-see!
titleopinion: SO much more to Dali!. This museum blew away all of what I thought I knew about Dali. What an amazing place, highlighting many works of art from very impressionistic early years to finding surrealism. A must-see!

reviewnospace: My daughter is the Dali fan and the theatre was a non-negotiable part of our trip to Spain. I had no idea the role this artist had played in the development of popular culture. I associated him with bizarre sculpture and art, not with theatre, costume or jewelry. I could see the role he had played in influencing comedy such as Monty Python and Barron-Cohen. It was rather mind-boggling. If you go to Figures be sure to check out the Toy museum. In fact I would choose Figures as a place to stay over Barcelona another time. I regretted deeply not positioning myself in the area and hiring a vehicle to explore all the little hamlets and to access even more Dali sites. And in Figures you will not starve to death faced with the tourist slop that passes for food in Barcelona. As long as you stay away from the cafes nearest to the theatre. Ah well, live and learn. The only down side to the museum was the lack of access to toilet facilities. It was a bit bizarre.

quote: This is unreal and totally amazing

reviewnospace: Great for all ages. How about the car that is outside and it's raining inside the car! Lots of different art than I ever knew Dali had done. Of interest to me was an exhibit from his work in Israel called Aliyah. This is a fun museum to visit.
titleopinion: Well worth a visit. Great for all ages. How about the car that is outside and it's raining inside the car! Lots of different art than I ever knew Dali had done. Of interest to me was an exhibit from his work in Israel called Aliyah. This is a fun museum to visit.

reviewnospace:
Where to start... opening times and online ticket booking times didn't correspond on their website; once clarified we arrived at the museum to find staff rude and unhelpful.

After paying I had to check my small handbag in to their left-luggage room designed for heavy walkers rucksacks and push chairs only then to subsequently find that other visitors with a similar style bag had been allowed to enter the "museum" without issue and also found a push chair in one of the galleries (so a disparity of permission granted).

At the end of the tour, which to be honest contained only one or two recognisable Dali works, and an awful lot of other artists works, I enquired (of the left-luggage room attendant) where the famous, melting clocks and stilt-walking elephants were... to which I was informed the majority are exhibited in museums and galleries around the world... ergo this museum displays the "leftovers" which quite frankly were not that interesting for a family of five who had driven four hours to look at them. Their website is disingenuous.

Their website is disingenuous.

reviewnospace: Great place, breathtaking! Visit late afternoon in October, relatively quiet. Must see this once in your life.

reviewnospace: It is truly unique that an artist would build a museum for himself, but that is what Salvador Dali did. Thus the building and the works in it are representative of the artist in a way no other museum I have ever visited has been. Be warned that they don't limit the number of people allowed in so it is crowded and chaotic inside. You can take pictures of whatever you wish to though, which is great. Also you can go to the Jewel exhibit next door which is a lot less crowded...

A must if you are around in Catalonia.
Too bad it is extremely crowded and they do not manage the number of people getting in. Probably early morning or late afternoon is best time to visit, to avoid the coach busses and large number of visitors not really interested.

reviewnospace: This was a trip to Figueres that is a must do for any art lover! As a lover of art it was so interesting to see Dali's different stages of technique through his life, and the museum is set up really well to take it all in!! A must do if you are near by for sure. A strange fellow this Mr. Dali, but so cool to see his thoughts put down on canvas and any other medium you can imagine!!

quote: Must See Museum and Best Value
reviewnospace: We tried to buy tickets online for Tuesday and unsuccessful. I think you can buy tickets online for weekend only because the dates in red are the only one responses to mouse click when choosing the date. The museum was arranged in a very creative and playful ways. You can see how much thought did Dali put into it. It was good that we browsed through the museum once in the morning and got our ticket stamped. We returned to the museum after lunch and it was less crowded. We surprised to see how much we missed.

reviewnospace:
We were on an Azamara cruise and took a cab from our port in Palamos to Figueres to see this museum in Dali's home town. It is really fun . There is a very large collection of Dali paintings, sculptures, jewelry and holograms. It is fascinating to see both the evolution of Dali's art from very traditional painting to very unconventional works and the incredible scope of artworks that Dali created. The sculpture in the entry hallway of a female figure poised on top of a vintage Cadillac is very striking. There are many significant and entertaining works and it is the largest collection of Dali's art assembled anywhere in the world.
I highly recommend spending several hours enjoying this museum.
titleopinion: Very Worthwhile. We were on an Azamara cruise and took a cab from our port in Palamos to Figueres to see this museum in Dali's home town. It is really fun . There is a very large collection of Dali paintings, sculptures, jewelry and holograms. It is fascinating to see both the evolution of Dali's art from very traditional painting to very unconventional works and the incredible scope of artworks that Dali created. The sculpture in the entry hallway of a female figure poised on top of a vintage Cadillac is very striking. There are many significant and entertaining works and it is the largest collection of Dali's art assembled anywhere in the world. I highly recommend spending several hours enjoying this museum.

reviewnospace:
We were looking for a day trip from Barcelona and my husband really likes Dali....we even have one of his pieces at home. So, we took the AVE train from Barcelona and did the Dali Museum and then the Dali House.

If you are doing this from Barcelona and want to do it all in one day as we did, it takes a bit of coordination. We left BCN early in the morning and took the last AVE train (high speed) back. The trip was something like the following: L5 from our hotel to Sants Estacion-->AVE train-->Figueres-->walk to museum-->1 hour bus to the Dali House (40 minute walk from the bus station to the house)-->1 hour bus from the Dali House to the bus station--> #15 bus to Figueres-->AVE train to Sants Estacion-->L5 back to our hotel. I might have left out a step or two, but you get the idea.

Both the museum and the home were wonderful and not to be missed. If you did the Picasso tour, then you know that Picasso and Dali were friends, yet their lives so different. Dali loved his wife, Gala, and you really only see this at his home.

The Dali home requires tickets in advance. We did not have them, so we called in the morning and made a reservation and got right in for later that afternoon. After the guided tour is finished, don't shortchange yourself and think that you are finished....go out to the olive orchard and check out the views....they are magnificent!

A day well worth it!!!

After the guided tour is finished, don't shortchange yourself and think that you are finished....go out to the olive orchard and check out the views....they are magnificent!  A day well worth it!!!

quote: Only Dali could create such a strange way to display his art
reviewnospace: If you have the opportunity visit the muesum at night it is visually more spectacular. The fact that Dali was able to build his own muesum makes they whole thing more spectacluar; the building becomes part of his artisic expression. While oddly the collection has few of the famous Dali pieces one is generally familar with it conveys brilliantly the depth of Dali's art and interests. I learnt a great deal about Dali from the muesum that I was previously unfamilar with based on viewing exhibits of his art work in other cities.

quote: A treat in the 'unusual'. A must for Dali fans.
reviewnospace:
The museum contains some interesting works by Dali. In my view the highlight was the jewels which we loved and are unique. There are some very interesting installations. There is a large collection of drawings and less so paintings with a few sculptures. In my view it mainly contains secondary pieces and unfortunately contains very few pieces / references to his melting/wilting clocks which I think are some of his best works.


Despite this was had a very good visit, nice lunch at a local restaurant and it was well worth the 100km trip to get there

quote: Brilliant but beware long travel from Barcelona
reviewnospace: Another must see if you're staying in the region, just be aware of the travel. If going via train and Barcelona, you're looking at €88 for your tickets and entry to the museum. Make sure you leave early too to get the full day in figueres as its a 2 hour journey. As for the musuem itself, great examples of Dali including montages of lesser known sketches. Painfully obvious though that the majority of the great surrealistic works are scattered in galleries all over the world and not here.

reviewnospace: Yes, he was a bit barmy, but what a craftsman and visionary Salvador Dali was. No brain could contain such skills and talents without going a bit gaga. Sculptures, jewellery, installations, even early holograms, they're all here. Time you visit so you can do lunch at Antaviana, up the road 50 metres, for a real double-whammy.

reviewnospace: We visited this museum on our drive from Barcelona to Nice - about one hour out of Barcelona. For an out of the way town, the museum had a large crowd of visitors. It had a large collection of surrealistic art by Dali. I had seen some of his art in other museums and books but did not realize the breadth and inventiveness of his art until this visit. I also appreciated that like the Louvre and unlike the Orsay, visitors are allowed to get close to the art and photograph the pieces. The jewelry museum was a nice addition.

It had a large collection of surrealistic art by Dali. I had seen some of his art in other museums and books but did not realize the breadth and inventiveness of his art until this visit. I also appreciated that like the Louvre and unlike the Orsay, visitors are allowed to get close to the art and photograph the pieces. The jewelry museum was a nice addition.

Cons: long queue, not in a convenient location (need to take a day trip from Barcelona).
titleopinion: Mind-blowing Exhibits. Pros: excellent collection of Surrealist paintings, drawings, jewellery and installation art; value for money.   Cons: long queue, not in a convenient location (need to take a day trip from Barcelona).

reviewnospace: Lots of unexpected pieces of art in a fabulous and unusual building. We spent 3-4 hours exploring all the different floors and rooms. Even my two boys (10 and 12) were captivated by some of the exhibits.
titleopinion: Amazing museum, worth queuing for. Lots of unexpected pieces of art in a fabulous and unusual building. We spent 3-4 hours exploring all the different floors and rooms. Even my two boys (10 and 12) were captivated by some of the exhibits.

reviewnospace: The best Museum worldwide! If you love Salvador Dali. and his Jewels. So much to see and interact with his art
titleopinion: Mindblowing!. The best Museum worldwide! If you love Salvador Dali. and his Jewels. So much to see and interact with his art

reviewnospace: Visited Dali museum in September. Not too long a queue (15 mins). Fascinating place - so many different types of art that Dali undertook. Great insight into the man's mind. Well worth visiting.

reviewnospace:
This is a must see! The most interesting museum ever. My favorite part was the Jewels! The coolest museum and the town of Figueres is darling. Great shopping and food there too!
Try to buy tickets online- if not available you will be able to buy them there.

quote: Excellent morning and afternoon in Figueres
reviewnospace: The Dali Museum was very eclectic. We enjoyed our visit. Moreover, taking a short trip out of Barcelona and to Figueres was very nice. Some tips: 1) if you have time, buy your Renfe tickets for Figueres a day in advance at one of the ticket vestibules (they're purple, and look like an ATM) in the Sants station. 2) Take the earliest train from Barcelona to Figueres (this is about 7:20am). If you take a later train, the line at the museum will already be long by the time you arrive in Figueres). 3) When you arrive at the Figueres Vilifante station, take the local bus (about 2 Euros per person) from the station to a drop off point which is about a 5 min. walk from the Museum. 4) Plan to spend around 1.5-2.5 hours in the museum if you're going at a moderate-fast pace. If you're in a rush and want to get back to Barcelona quickly, you can take a ~1pm train back from Figueres, and be back in Barcelona by 2pm! 5) Make sure to take a taxi from the Dali Museum back to the Vilifante station. the buses back are not super reliable.
titleopinion: Excellent morning and afternoon in Figueres. The Dali Museum was very eclectic. We enjoyed our visit. Moreover, taking a short trip out of Barcelona and to Figueres was very nice. Some tips: 1) if you have time, buy your Renfe tickets for Figueres a day in advance at one of the ticket vestibules (they're purple, and look like an ATM) in the Sants station. 2) Take the earliest train from Barcelona to Figueres (this is about 7:20am). If you take a later train, the line at the museum will already be long by the time you arrive in Figueres). 3) When you arrive at the Figueres Vilifante station, take the local bus (about 2 Euros per person) from the station to a drop off point which is about a 5 min. walk from the Museum. 4) Plan to spend around 1.5-2.5 hours in the museum if you're going at a moderate-fast pace. If you're in a rush and want to get back to Barcelona quickly, you can take a ~1pm train back from Figueres, and be back in Barcelona by 2pm! 5) Make sure to take a taxi from the Dali Museum back to the Vilifante station. the buses back are not super reliable.

reviewnospace: The Dali museum is totally overwhelming and incredible. There is so much amazing Dali creations everywhere that it is impossible to really appreciate everything in a single visit. Definitely worth a day trip if you are staying in Barcelona.
titleopinion: Ultimate Dali. The Dali museum is totally overwhelming and incredible. There is so much amazing Dali creations everywhere that it is impossible to really appreciate everything in a single visit. Definitely worth a day trip if you are staying in Barcelona.

reviewnospace: We had a magical experience here. Quite busy but well worth the trip. There was humour and design excellence! Totally impressed
titleopinion: Wonderful tribute. We had a magical experience here. Quite busy but well worth the trip. There was humour and design excellence! Totally impressed

reviewnospace: Totally worth the trip from Barcelona. We were on a small group tour of only about 14 people, so it wasn't like we were being herded around like cattle. The museum exterior is very unique, but wait until you get inside!! The theater sections is so awesome... like a round atrium surrounded by golden mannequins. The art is amazing!! And the jewelry in the separate vault area (separate admission too) is magnificent!! This was so worth the 11 hour day (we visited Cadaques and his home on this tour too). A definite must see if you are in Barcelona for a few days.

reviewnospace: The best time to visit is early in the day or late in the day as in between these times there is a long queue to get in. From the time you enter to the time you leave you will be amazed by the work of this man. His brain worked in mysterious and talented ways to leave us all with a legacy of art that is unique.
