reviewnospace:
I must admit that we ended visiting the Dali museum only because we had a spare day and had done enough of beach hopping! :) Although we appreciate good art in any form, we hardly knew anything about modern art let alone surrealist, cubist, and what not! But boy, this museum took our breath away as much for the extraordinary variety of Dali's work as for the beautiful structure of the museum and the ambience/impression it manages to create! One well and truly feels in presence of the genius of Dali, and his imagination almost turned us dumbstruck! An absolutely unmissable experience on Costra Brava, perhaps not suitable for kids of any age.

Top tip: Get there as early as you can - we were straight on to the ticket window at 10:30 and there was mile-long queue at noon! This place can get *very* busy and you lose the tranquility a little bit. Also DON'T miss the jewellery museum just round the corner, just as jaw-droppingly beautiful a display of amazingly intricate pieces! Btw, there's a car park for the museum which is not very obvious from the street in front if you went there using a satnav. We managed to park on the street nonetheless.

I booked the trip from Barcelona. Only 89 euro, It worth all money. Small group, 11 people, all over the world. First stop was Figueres. This museum is all you neted to " live". It represent all Dali' s life. An experience for soul. I leaved that place loving life. Do not miss the jewellry museum, right the corner.
Food , drinks and pastries at terasses, excelent!
Next stop, Port Lligat,to take tickets for Dali' s house museum. And enjoy the route to Cap de Creus, close to the franch border. The lava field and the coast are magnificent places, the blue see....Return to Port Lligat for walk, eat and enjoy a beautiful ancient-greek town. Do not miss the church! Exploreaza narrow streets and the hill.
The Dali house museum is the crown of this trip.
I' m sorry, i don' t remember our guide name but she is the best catalunian guide you can meet. She is very good on Dali' s opera and life experience. Good history teller.
A tour I will do again.

reviewnospace: We first visited the Dali Treatre-Museum in Figueres in 1992 and every time we're back to Barcelona we make the time to revisit. Every time is as if it is the first! Not so much because of the actual paintings exhibited - most of his renowned works are outside this museum - but because of the feeling you get of who the artist really was! Definitely a genius - not sure if he was as crazy as he wanted us to believe. I am every time moved by the Christ's Head (no colours, just shades of gray): innocent yet mature, suffering yet enduring - it makes me cry... The expression of the Madonna on his Pieta is also a moving experience. Dali painted fabulously in all sorts of technotropies - he was an artist in every sense of the word and that you realize only after a visit to this specific Museum. This year we were also lucky to see his Jewelry Collection - what a sight! A MUST if you are around this year.

Sometimes we had to squeeze our bodies between others to get by or out. Huge disappointment since we drove out of our way to see the Dali art. It was they were out for the money with no concern as to the maximum number of people who could reasonably appreciate the art. I wondered if there was no fire code maximum occupancy laws.

reviewnospace: Artist in the full meaning of the world ,painter (bad painter (!) in order to live longer by his words) ,photographer,performer,pop art pioneer, sculpturer, father of the surrealistic and hyper realistic art and above all a obsessive and larger than life persona that changed so many aspects of art.Teatro-Museo Dali was build under his supervision and hosts possibly the largest collection of work ,from paintings to sculptures and art installations to holographs,jewellery and hand made xmas cards even his crypt (for a strange reason he is there and not with Gala ) you will be at least puzzled and surely impressed by his contribution. His signature eggs,catalan bread loaf shape ,time,life,death,beauty,religion and Gala's figure is everywhere .Shame that almost none of the exhibits don't even have a small plate to show some info (at least in 2 different languages) what you see.Large queue for tickets and slightly disoriented stuff trying with broken english to help you out with the room sequence .Also you will probably need a car from Barcelona which apparently they should have more ways to get people in Figueres and Cadaques which are nice but without Dali would probably be relatively unknown outside Spain. Approach with open heart and open mind.... A must see even if you are not Dali's work fan.

His signature eggs,catalan bread loaf shape ,time,life,death,beauty,religion and Gala's figure is everywhere .Shame that almost none of the exhibits don't even have a small plate to show some info (at least in 2 different languages) what you see.Large queue for tickets and slightly disoriented stuff trying with broken english to help you out with the room sequence .Also you will probably need a car from Barcelona which apparently they should have more ways to get people in Figueres and Cadaques which are nice but without Dali would probably be relatively unknown outside Spain. Approach with open heart and open mind.... A must see even if you are not Dali's work fan.

reviewnospace: I went at end of July - totally the wrong time, as there was a very long line of people, about 2/3 hours wait, to get in. By paying €20,i was able to jump the queue and get in within 30 minutes. It was worth the visit, even though I am not a fan of Dali. 'Out of this world' would describe it - just mind boggling. Suggest a vivit out of season to beat the crowds, if at all possible.

reviewnospace:
We have been to the Costa Brava twice in the past four years and made it a point to visit the three main Dali attractions while we were there (his home in Cadaques, Gala's home and this museum). This museum was by far the most expansive collection of work and provided the most insight into his vast artistic range and body of work.

For our visit to this museum we left it too late to book tickets and, with two young children (5 and 8), we didn't think we would be able to wait in line for the several hours that all of the reviews said it may take to get into the museum. Fortunately my wife found the private tour offered by guiding.es for a few Euros more per person. The experience we had was worth far more than the few extra Euros we spent per person. Our guide was incredibly friendly, knowledgable and fluent in English. The tour group was private consisting of the six members of our family and the guide, far better than other guided tours that seem to have up to 30 people with headsets to hear the tour guide. Our guide was able to get us into the museum without waiting in line and took us to specific pieces of art and areas of the museum and gave us insight into the importance of the pieces in his life's collection of work.

Importantly for us the guide was also able to keep our boys interested and involved throughout the experience in spite of their young age. Both of them told us they really enjoyed the experience and learned from the tour guide. I highly recommend this museum and the guided tour provided by guiding.es to make the experience even better.

Both of them told us they really enjoyed the experience and learned from the tour guide. I highly recommend this museum and the guided tour provided by guiding.es to make the experience even better.

quote: Be careful of the scary guard lady
reviewnospace:
In the jewel section, Scary drill-sergeant guard lady will yell NO FLASH many times!
Be very careful of her she is very unfriendly -- I think she is almost ready to bite.
The people working here are quite unfriendly and moody in general...
Well worth visiting of course...
titleopinion: Be careful of the scary guard lady. In the jewel section, Scary drill-sergeant guard lady will yell NO FLASH many times!  Be very careful of her she is very unfriendly -- I think she is almost ready to bite. The people working here are quite unfriendly and moody in general... Well worth visiting of course...

reviewnospace:
This is a fantastic museum but is very crowded in the summer months. The hourly guided tours are so large that it is impossible to enter the same room as them, so my advice is not to fellow the advised room sequence, and then to return when they have gone.
The rooms themselves are quite small but crammed with really interesting art so well worth a visit.
titleopinion: Fantastic but crowded. This is a fantastic museum but is very crowded in the summer months. The hourly guided tours are so large that it is impossible to enter the same room as them, so my advice is not to fellow the advised room sequence, and then to return when they have gone.  The rooms themselves are quite small but crammed with really interesting art so well worth a visit.

reviewnospace:
We drove to Figueres one afternoon and arrived to find a queue that stretched some hunred metres long or even more and decided to come back the next day exactly at 9am when it opens it doors. So, we did that the next day. A queue already formed, but we were admitted within 15min.

The museum is huge and has a wide collection of Dali treasures, from paintings to sculptures to mobile art. You should plan for at least 3 hours here. We came here with both our children, aged 8 and 11 and after two hours, it proved a little too much for our boy. But our elder daughter could enjoy the exhibits and went into the 'Dali fever', so much so that she also insisted on seeing the castle Dali bought for Gala in Port Lligat (yes, we went there too).

Bring enough time with you there. It will be an unforgettable experience. We find the Lincoln (Gala looking out of the window) painting, the Dali jewels (separate museum, ticket price included in the main ticket), and the Mae West lips art fascinating.

On top of Dali, some other artists' works are also featured here.

Museum shops are scattered at the exit area too.

I only have one complaint there: the rude staff. The museum was very crowded and I can imagine the stress this has on the personnel. We had two VERY unpleasant occasions with their staff (loud talking down, scolding, harshness) and they did ruin our otherwise very enjoyable trip to the museum.

Parking is extremely difficult there. There is a parking mall beside the museum, but it is full and the parking alongside roads are also all full. parking is a big problem in Figueres. However if you drive a little to the outer area, free parking on a wide space is available at no cost.

Be sure to visit the church beside the museum too. Dali was baptised there as a baby and his funeral service was also held there.

quote: Going to a theater theme park
reviewnospace: I could spend days in this museum. It was really thrilling to see Dali live! Every piece of art in this museum was wonderful!
titleopinion: Going to a theater theme park. I could spend days in this museum. It was really thrilling to see Dali live! Every piece of art in this museum was wonderful!

quote: Dali at night is just amazing!
reviewnospace:
We just did a last minute visit to the Dali theater and we booked the Dali at night tickets at 23:00 on Thursday. It was open till 01:00 but we had plenty of time because it was not so very crowded. Lot of people taking pictures and that takes a lot of time because the hallways are not so big. But the atmosphere at night is just breathtaking! In the garden they were serving glasses of cava to the guests, and a black and white movie of Dali was projecting on the wall. Really nice atmosphere with everyone just relaxing and drinking.

So if you wanna experience a museum visit differently I recommend the night visit! Also Figueres is beautiful at night to walk :)

Even my boyfriend liked it and yes he doesn't like museums at all ;)

Also you can book easily your tickets on internet, it will save time at the line!
titleopinion: Dali at night is just amazing!. We just did a last minute visit to the Dali theater and we booked the Dali at night tickets at 23:00 on Thursday. It was open till 01:00 but we had plenty of time because it was not so very crowded. Lot of people taking pictures and that takes a lot of time because the hallways are not so big. But the atmosphere at night is just breathtaking! In the garden they were serving glasses of cava to the guests, and a black and white movie of Dali was projecting on the wall. Really nice atmosphere with everyone just relaxing and drinking.  So if you wanna experience a museum visit differently I recommend the night visit! Also Figueres is beautiful at night to walk :)  Even my boyfriend liked it and yes he doesn't like museums at all ;)  Also you can book easily your tickets on internet, it will save time at the line!

reviewnospace: Loved the whole place, we booked a bit late so could only get in at 5 pm so only had 3 hours to get round as it closes at 8 pm. This wasn't long enough, I could have spent several more hours there. This meant we didn't actually finish getting right round and missed seeing the last 2 or 3 rooms.
titleopinion: Wonderful museum. Loved the whole place, we booked a bit late so could only get in at 5 pm so only had 3 hours to get round as it closes at 8 pm. This wasn't long enough, I could have spent several more hours there. This meant we didn't actually finish getting right round and missed seeing the last 2 or 3 rooms.

quote: Go for a night-time Dali Museum booking!
reviewnospace: Go for a night-time Dali Museum booking! It's less crowded and really atmospheric. Well worth a visit...lots to see from this genius artist. All the family loved it including the young teens.
titleopinion: Go for a night-time Dali Museum booking!. Go for a night-time Dali Museum booking! It's less crowded and really atmospheric. Well worth a visit...lots to see from this genius artist. All the family loved it including the young teens.

reviewnospace:
I first visited the Dali museum on the late 70s and at the time thought it was one of my favorite art museums in the entire world Not a lot has changed with the museum except that it is extremely crowded now. It is sometimes hard to navigate through the galleries and there will be a line in the Mae West room. One thing that the museum could do to cut down on this problem is to prohibit the taking of photos in any of the galleries. While people are focusing their cameras others can't pass and the lines can't move. Are most people going to be able to take a better photo of a piece of art than what can be found on a postcard or in a book? What friend is going to be interested in seeing a photo of an artwork you saw on a trip?

This is still a great and fun museum but be prepared to endure crowds of people throughout.

quote: Allow plenty of time - there's so much to see!
reviewnospace: After queuing round the corner (should have booked online!) we eventually got inside the museum. Entry is a very reasonable €12 per person. There are so many pieces on display here, that you need to take your time to take it all in. The fact that this is Dalí's final resting place makes it all the more special. The gift shop at the end is incredibly expensive, so I'd recommend visiting one of the many souvenir shopsin Figueres instead.

reviewnospace: Eclectic art using numerous media. A tour bus with guide adds to the uniqueness of Dali's contributions. A small town with an attraction worth the time.
titleopinion: extraordinary. Eclectic art using numerous media. A tour bus with guide adds to the uniqueness of Dali's contributions. A small town with an attraction worth the time.

reviewnospace: Easy to book ahead on the internet- saves queueing. Crowds soon disperse once inside. A beautiful, quirky, characterful building, which Dali loved. Contains a wonderful collection of works, mostly Dali but including Valles and Pitxot.
titleopinion: Homage to Dali. Easy to book ahead on the internet- saves queueing. Crowds soon disperse once inside. A beautiful, quirky, characterful building, which Dali loved. Contains a wonderful collection of works, mostly Dali but including Valles and Pitxot.

reviewnospace: The whole building & it's remarkable contents are like Alice in Wonderland on acid! Dali's fingers are in every crevice of the place, & his own works cover such a wide range it takes your breath away. The guest exhibitors, Pitxot & Valles, complement Dali's own pieces admirably, & his private collection hints at his influences down the years. Try to book for a late-night visit if you can, so you can avoid the queues & crush. On-line booking saves money & avoids the long queues, too.

quote: Must see!!! Want to rate it higher than they allow!
reviewnospace: We screwed up the train getting to Figueres (our fault) and it was hot in June...even so it was the best day we had in Spain (and we loved all of Spain). Figueres is a lovely village and the Dali Museum is a wonder of the world. This man was so talented that I'm astonished that all I know are the melting clocks. Those are practically the least of it. This museum shows the full range and genius of Dali, which is almost beyond belief. Go with an open mind and take in as much as you can. Just be prepared to be surprised and delighted at every turn.

But all round still worth traveling just to see it.

reviewnospace: We took a Girona-Figueres-Dali Museum day tour that included tickets to the museum. Our guide told us Dali didn't want audio guides in his museum so that visitors experienced each exhibit individually and through their own sensory perception. Thankfully, our guide from Catalunya Bus Turistic was very knowledgeable and explained to us some of the key exhibits and how to interpret them. A definite must see. If you decide to go on your own, I will recommend you to book tickets online before showing up. The queue can be quite long.

Our guide told us Dali didn't want audio guides in his museum so that visitors experienced each exhibit individually and through their own sensory perception. Thankfully, our guide from Catalunya Bus Turistic was very knowledgeable and explained to us some of the key exhibits and how to interpret them. A definite must see. If you decide to go on your own, I will recommend you to book tickets online before showing up. The queue can be quite long.

reviewnospace: I am great art fan and this museum fulfilled all my expectations. So different to anything you usually see in traditional art galleries and museums.
titleopinion: BRILLIANT. I am great art fan and this museum fulfilled all my expectations. So different to anything you usually see in traditional art galleries and museums.

quote: Must visit day trip from Barcelona
reviewnospace:
I won't pretend to know anything about art, especially surrealism, but I'm very glad I took a day to visit the theatre-museum and be part of the audience. You get to see both awe-inspiring and bizarre works, and your mind gets a chance to be stretched a little, which is a good thing. Then you can show the pictures and tell your friends about it and they'll be jealous. It's a unique place that you don't encounter everyday. Dali designed the entire space and lived there the last years of his life.

Since the rooms are a bit small it can get a little crowded in the busy season, so it makes sense to book in advance. I did a day tour from Barcelona (booked 2 days in advance online for under $100 USD) on a very comfortable coach bus (with Viator, who use Julia travel, who use a Catalunya tourism company who give the actual tours) that stopped in Girona in the morning, which was a cool place to see since its rich in history and well-preserved. Our tour guide Alex was tremendous, he explained everything in both English and Spanish and was extremely knowledgeable. You get back at 7-7:30 which still leaves plenty of time still do something else in Barcelona on the same day.

quote: Excellent guide and description of Art works
reviewnospace: Good value combined ticket for fastrack entry to museum and walking tour of the city with head phones with guides commentary. I never would have appreciated the art work without the guide. Parking in city was expensive.

quote: Very Crowded But Still A Must-See
reviewnospace:
The Good

The Dali Museum is very unusual and makes for quite a spectacle. There are many different artworks to be seen and the building itself is part of the experience. It is truly unlike any other art museum you will ever visit.

There is an inexpensive parking garage just across the street and there are several restaurants in the city near the museum. A trip to Figueres can make for a nice diversion from Barcelona or the Costa Brava.

The Bad

Unfortunately, this place was extremely packed with people and this made it difficult to enjoy the works. I could not walk anywhere without finding myself in someone's picture. I would go left to avoid a camera on the right and this would put me into someone else's picture on the left. Then I would back up and find that I had just walked into another picture. There were people everywhere and it was not possible to enjoy any piece without having several people walk past/ into me. Once the tour groups were thrown into the mix, there were times when I physically could not leave a room because there were too many people in the way. This museum is certainly not a space for anyone who is claustrophobic or doesn't like crowds.

There was only one bathroom and it was located near the entrance. If you need to use it, you should do so before continuing towards the exit. I waited until the end of my visit and it was very tough to fight the flow of visitors and get back to the bathroom.

Tips to Help You Enjoy Your Visit

Book your tickets in advance. This will save you from waiting in a long line outside the entrance.

Either arrive right at the opening of the museum or delay your visit until near closing time (but make sure you leave at least two hours). This will help you avoid the massive crowds that can overrun this place.

If you arrive at the start of the day, head straight to room 11. By the time we got there about an hour after opening, we had to wait in a 45 minute line to see Mae West from the top of the camel (it sounds absurd, but you'll understand if you go). By heading straight here, you will save yourself lots of time and will then be able to backtrack to the other rooms.

When you get to the end of your visit, if you want to check out the gift shop, head to the one on the right as you face the exit. Everyone else will filter into the gift shop on the left, which will become very crowded. Because the gift shop on the right is not directly in the flow of people, you will be able to shop without all of the crowds.

Even though it has some problems, this museum is not to be missed. If you make preparations to avoid the crowds, you should leave satisfied with a great overall experience.

quote: Fabulous even for non-Dali fans. Make sure you book in advance!
reviewnospace:
My wife didn't know much about Dali beyond the melting clocks -- she was amazed at his work (as i was the first time I visited).

We didn't book early and the walkup queue was about 200 feet long! It was crowded inside but it was also early August.

We got online and booked a tour through guiding.es for about 18 Euros. I booked the night before and it was easy -- multilingual guides escort you in with no queue, give you a headset and after an hour you're on your own.

Make sure you visit some of the upper floors to see some of the work Dali collected from others.

I booked the night before and it was easy -- multilingual guides escort you in with no queue, give you a headset and after an hour you're on your own.  Make sure you visit some of the upper floors to see some of the work Dali collected from others.

reviewnospace: The Dali museum is very entertaining because of all the outrageous works of art to be seen. But there's little explanation about the artist, so you have to buy a book to know where Dali's got all those crazy inspiration.
titleopinion: Outrageous!. The Dali museum is very entertaining because of all the outrageous works of art to be seen. But there's little explanation about the artist, so you have to buy a book to know where Dali's got all those crazy inspiration.

reviewnospace: The lines were long but well worth it. "I am not on drugs, I am the drug," said Salvador Dali. And after the tour, we would agree.
titleopinion: Don't miss this!. The lines were long but well worth it.  I am not on drugs, I am the drug,  said Salvador Dali. And after the tour, we would agree.

reviewnospace:
I visited as part of of a day trip from Barcelona and thoroughly enjoyed my visit.

As a group we did get priority entrance but the non-group queue wasn't very long, and our tickets included the Dali Jewels exhibition. Our guide suggested 1.5hrs for the Theatre-Museum and 15 mins for the Dali Jewels - I spent just over 3 hours in the Theatre-Museum and 45 mins in the Dali Jewels exhibition (and would have stayed longer but I had to get the coach!).

I wouldn't say it was particularly a good place for children to visit - the ones there on the day we visited didn't seem to be enjoying themselves for sure!

The Theatre-Museum was packed with tourists (obviously!) and there was lots of pushing and shoving to get near some of the works, plus lots of tutting and muttering if woe betide you were actually standing looking at a particular piece for longer than about 30 seconds, but I stood my ground and tutted and muttered back!

Whilst it was Dali's wish that there are no explanations/descriptions for his artwork, it would be useful to read up on Dali and his ideas before visiting otherwise I guarantee you will have no idea what they are all about! The exhibits are numbered to make the flow of visitors around the museum easier (apparently), although I found the numbers useful to make sure I didn't miss anything - there is LOADS to see.

The gift shop was pretty uninspiring. Toilet facilities were good. Rucksacks and large bags have to be left at the cloakroom. Photography is allowed, but flash photography and tripods are not permitted.

reviewnospace: The ticket queues were long -so either book on line -or get there early. The Theatre and Jewellery exhibitions are wonderful. It was amazing to explore the creative genius of this artist and his ability to apply his skills to almost every medium available. Strongly recommended. Enjoy.
titleopinion: Creative Genius. The ticket queues were long -so either book on line -or get there early. The Theatre and Jewellery exhibitions are wonderful. It was amazing to explore the creative genius of this artist and his ability to apply his skills to almost every medium available. Strongly recommended. Enjoy.

reviewnospace: I took a guided day trip here from Barcelona, and I'm extremely glad I did. There is a huge collection of Dali's work here, and if you have any interest in Dali or surrealist art at all, I highly recommend. Don't miss the jewelry collection, which requires a separate entrance fee, and plan to spend at least 30 minutes seeing the jewelry alone. I'd never seen this aspect of Dali's work before, and it's as great as anything he did with a paintbrush, plus it illustrates his relationship with the love of his life, which the museum also does a very good job of showcasing as well. I'm not even care much about jewelry, but at the strong urging of our guide, I saw that portion of the museum, which I otherwise probably would have skipped. The pieces are amazing, unique pieces of art, and I was totally engrossed by them. Allow 3-4 hours for the museum and jewelry exhibit, minimum. Nothing else to really see or do in Figueres. We went to Dali's Port-Ligat Home and Museum nearby and the town of Cadaques, as well as the Cap de Creus National Park on the coast nearby. It was a great daytrip from Barcelona which is about 100 miles away, so it was a lot of driving, but well worth it. Highly recommended.
titleopinion: Amazing Dali Museum in Figueres. I took a guided day trip here from Barcelona, and I'm extremely glad I did. There is a huge collection of Dali's work here, and if you have any interest in Dali or surrealist art at all, I highly recommend. Don't miss the jewelry collection, which requires a separate entrance fee, and plan to spend at least 30 minutes seeing the jewelry alone. I'd never seen this aspect of Dali's work before, and it's as great as anything he did with a paintbrush, plus it illustrates his relationship with the love of his life, which the museum also does a very good job of showcasing as well. I'm not even care much about jewelry, but at the strong urging of our guide, I saw that portion of the museum, which I otherwise probably would have skipped. The pieces are amazing, unique pieces of art, and I was totally engrossed by them. Allow 3-4 hours for the museum and jewelry exhibit, minimum. Nothing else to really see or do in Figueres. We went to Dali's Port-Ligat Home and Museum nearby and the town of Cadaques, as well as the Cap de Creus National Park on the coast nearby. It was a great daytrip from Barcelona which is about 100 miles away, so it was a lot of driving, but well worth it. Highly recommended.

reviewnospace: While we enjoyed touring this museum, the hordes of people taking photos with their iPads were highly annoying and took away from the overall experience. I would highly recommend getting there right when it opens. Apparently, the information office close to the museum rents out audio guides. We found this out however after waiting an hour in line in the blazing sun. By the time we were inside we were not willing to go back out to seek out an audio guide. I think it would have been helpful though. The Dali jewels were amazing to see. Don't miss this part of the museum.
titleopinion: Intriguing Museum. While we enjoyed touring this museum, the hordes of people taking photos with their iPads were highly annoying and took away from the overall experience. I would highly recommend getting there right when it opens. Apparently, the information office close to the museum rents out audio guides. We found this out however after waiting an hour in line in the blazing sun. By the time we were inside we were not willing to go back out to seek out an audio guide. I think it would have been helpful though. The Dali jewels were amazing to see. Don't miss this part of the museum.

reviewnospace: Very busy in the summer months. It was packed to the rafters the day we went. A huge amount to see. You can take pictures but must not use a flash. Why don't people just look around and savour the place? All we saw was people madly taking pictures and not looking at anything -weird. There are toilets in the Museum. Take your time there is a lot to see. Do follow your guise sheet around, it is very easy to miss something. And do be respectful in the Treasure room, where Dali is buried. There is an admission price which was 12 euros, but you also get an admission to Dali's Jewels in that price. Well worth it. There is a Car Park around the corner. But we parked in the car park next to the Museum on the side road.
titleopinion: The Wow Factor. Very busy in the summer months. It was packed to the rafters the day we went. A huge amount to see. You can take pictures but must not use a flash. There is an admission price which was 12 euros, but you also get an admission to Dali's Jewels in that price. Well worth it. There is a Car Park around the corner. But we parked in the car park next to the Museum on the side road.

quote: A great collection in a must-see building
reviewnospace:
I am not a Dali admirer, but this collection changed my opinion because it revealed a great deal of craft and a mastery of many different styles and media. The museum can easily be found after a 10-minute walk if you got off the train at the right station. (Some research before the trip is recommended). Then, there are some oddities: the ticket office at the front was open, but the woman sitting in there told us that she is not selling tickets. We thought it was either poor management or perhaps a preperation for experiencing surrealism.... In any case, we had to go around the building to find a long line of visitors waiting to get their tickets.

As much as limiting the number of people in a museum can be a nuisance, visiting the Dali musem made me understand why it is a good idea say, in the Gaudi sites in Barcelona. The Dali museum does not follow that practice; consequently, the place got really crowded to the point of interfering with our enjoyment. Some of the narrow hallways or staircases were very hard to negotiate with huge groups entering from every possible direction. I did not soecifically investigate this, but access for wheechairs may not be easy.

Another thing is that the captions should be more systematically written in at least 3 languages or more to make sure the visitors can read them. It would also have been nice to read an overview in every room that would place the works and styles displayed in some kind of context and time frame. The third floor was particularly confusing for lack of written descriptions, and on this floor there is an El Greco St Paul, which is just amazing, but it was also a surprise.

All in all, this collection is worth the trip. Figueres is a charming town, with friendly people. On the main street (Rambla), there is a small shop with a wonderful selection of hand made ceramic ware from various regions of Spain. Great shopping!

The Dali exhibition ticket also included a 50% discount for the Toy Museum, which was another surprise. It is not as hands-on or interactive as musems for kids in the U.S. are, but the collection of old toys on display was unique.

We also spotted a promising museum of technology with interesting clocks and other old items, but had run out of time. We did not see the Dali-house either. So I agree, It is a good idea to start the say in Figueres early, and unless you are prepared to visit 4 museums, a shop and a Romanesque church (free), maybe plan 2 days for Figueres.

quote: A must See and go early!
reviewnospace:
I'm a big fan of Dali anything. My hubby and I went to spain and I could not miss this. We stayed in Barcelona and took the 50 min train ride. So easy to get to. We walked from the train station to the museum. There arent very many taxis in this small city. It was already hot at 8:30 in the morning. We arrived early. I'm sure we were the first ones there. We were able to take pictures of the surrounding area with no one around. We were the first ones in line. School kids and large groups started to arrive as it got closer to opening time. We went in first and were able to take some photos with no one in them. That was nice because 15 minutes later all those groups came in and they swarmed around everything. It seemed we were always a bit ahead of all the groups so we had a chance to see everything by ourselves. this is one of the best museums I've seen and I'm not saying that just because I love Dali stuff. The museum has a couple of floors and quite a bit to see. I totally thought it was worth the train ride.
There's not much to do in this little town but they probably make a lot of money from all the tourists.
TIP: Go early and get in line before the place opens.

reviewnospace: We weren't previously big fans of Dali, but this museum certainly changed our minds. Besides the surrealistic paintings he's so well known for, he employed many other diverse styles - including Impressionism - during his lifetime. The museum itself is a work of art not to be missed.
titleopinion: Better than expected. We weren't previously big fans of Dali, but this museum certainly changed our minds. Besides the surrealistic paintings he's so well known for, he employed many other diverse styles - including Impressionism - during his lifetime. The museum itself is a work of art not to be missed.

reviewnospace:
"Figueres" is a quaint little town and Dali's Museum (Teatre Museu Dali) stands in stark contrast to anything in the vicinity, or maybe all of Spain! Brightly painted a deep umber/red color, the entire surface is dotted with little tan round bread-like sculpture rosettes and, lining the entire roof perimeter are huge, beige colored egg scluptures. We lost count of the number.

"Eggs" play a major part in his art and it is attributed to his mother who passed away from uterine cancer when he was 16. The "egg" is also a tribute to his home in Catalunya. It is a commonly repeated theme, or element, in his art.

Come early, the theater/museum fills up quickly and it is a long drive to get here from Barcelona. The museum opens at 10:30 from October to June and, in July, it opens at 9 a.m. All backpacks and large items must be checked and the flash function on cameras must be turned off. Just so you know.

This abandoned theater was restored under Dali's direction and it is a work of art itself; it is more than a mere "installation" of his donated art. This is the most visited art museum in Spain. It is a happy place where his imagination ran wild and the museum invites the visitor to do the same with his own imagination.

A diver perched on top of the entry, invites the visitor to "dive in and expore one's own unconsciousness."

Gala was Dali's wife. She is a Russian woman 10 years his senior. He met her when he was 25. He married her twice, the last time in 1964 in a Catholic church. In his later days, he went from being anti-clerical to extremely pro-Catholic.

Gala continued to be his inspiration (she is frequently featured in much of his work), his artistic muse, his marketing director, banker, and she is the person who is credited with creating his "brand".

Dali's family did not accept Gala, or Dali's friends, or much of the way Dali lived his life.

The floorplan of the museum is divided into a few sections: courtyard and stage, ground floor and below stage, first floor (parts one and two), Second floor, third floor, and the exit is on the first floor. It will take more than 2 hours to do it justice and some art pieces have a waiting line (Mae West Room in particular but going through the piece is part of the adventure).

There is a jewelry exhibit of Dali's creatiions, it is adjacent to the museum. It really is spectacular and time should be planned for this brief tour. The room is very dark and the jewelry pieces, in glass cases, are highlighted with bright lights. Such imagination!

Dali is entombed in this museum; his final resting place is below the stage on the "ground floor and below stage" section of the museum.

Our guide map has a warning when talking about the organization of the museum: "It does not have, nor does it wish to have, any systematic function nor chronological sense." Doesn't that sum up Dali, himself and his art, in a nutshell? Say good bye to order.

As this is Dali's own collection, many of his favorite artists are on display as well.

We found ourselves marveling at his creative genius, asking ourselves how he could have conceived of such unique concepts. For instance, the Abraham Lincoln pixilated image (up close there is a back-view nude of his Gala who appears to be looking out a window. However, a different view shows she is in the center of a face; Lincoln only becomes visible when viewed through a camera view finder. It's title is "Naked Gala Watching the Sea" (Lincoln).

Mae West is a carefully arranged entire room: a red lips sofa, 2 framed pictures, a console table, and a theater curtain of blond-looking hair curtains are the props. Climb the small stairway (like absolutely everyone else) to gaze down upon the lined-up pieces to see a very imaginative representation of the head of Mae West.

The large room which looks to be designed on the scale of a fine Cistene Chapel or French Versailles palace room, highlights the bottom-up view (feet first) of a man and woman, whose heads are just about lost in their arms-first ascent through the hole in the ceiling to the heavens above. Normally, heavenly figures are seen reaching down from the heavens or floating up to the heavens. Seeing the oversized, chunky, dirty, feet turns conventionality on its head.

Much the way Gaud's Sagrada Familia took a completely divergent look at tradition (rethinking the way churches can inspire), so Dali does this for art. He asks the viewer to escape the bounds of conventionality. This is a must-see for anyone visitng Barcelona.

Our day trip was with a local Barcelona guide company, "Explore Catalunya" and it was nice not to have to drive there by ourselves.

Website: www.salvador-dali.org
There is an entry fee, try to buy tickets ahead of time, if possilbe.

reviewnospace: This museum was unlike any other. I have been to the big ones, the met, natural history, louvre, etc..but all those are museums , and this was simply dali's world. I have never seen paintings so big, and such vibrant surreal images. Even my husband, who usually sleeps through museums, was transfixed and blown away. Off the beaten barcelona path- but sooo worth it

reviewnospace:
Disclosure: In preparing to be a docent at the Dali Museum in St Petersburg, FL, it was important to me to go to Dali Theatre-Museum in Figueres while in Spain. So I have a different level of interest and motivation than most visitors.

There were so many visuals that added to and enhanced my knowledge of Dali the person and his art. From the exterior to every detail in the museum, I loved this pilgrimage to Dali Museum.
titleopinion: Educational and Thrilling. So I have a different level of interest and motivation than most visitors.   There were so many visuals that added to and enhanced my knowledge of Dali the person and his art. From the exterior to every detail in the museum, I loved this pilgrimage to Dali Museum.

reviewnospace: If reality is what we can see, then yes. However everyone's reality is different according to the Knowledge attached to the person. Dali is not only an artist but a seer and philosopher. Although you will not find Dali's most renowned works in the building but famous doesn't necessarily mean anything valuable. However the feeling of Truth, the picture of the incredible human mind with its destroying and creating capabilities are all there. It is incredible, happy, bitter and sad; as Life is. Absolutely amazing!
titleopinion: Was Dali really a surrealist?. If reality is what we can see, then yes. However everyone's reality is different according to the Knowledge attached to the person. Dali is not only an artist but a seer and philosopher. Although you will not find Dali's most renowned works in the building but famous doesn't necessarily mean anything valuable. However the feeling of Truth, the picture of the incredible human mind with its destroying and creating capabilities are all there. It is incredible, happy, bitter and sad; as Life is. Absolutely amazing!

reviewnospace: Only visit this if you really love arts or love Dali...otherwise this is pretty boring and your time will be better waisted with a "vino blanco" on the placas around the museum!
titleopinion: Just for art-lovers. Only visit this if you really love arts or love Dali...otherwise this is pretty boring and your time will be better waisted with a  vino blanco  on the placas around the museum!

reviewnospace: If you're a Dali fan, this museum is worth visiting. Unfortunately, this museum doesn't contain his classic paintings, but it does have a myriad of his other works in mediums other than paint which shows how talented and creative Dali was. After your backpack is checked-in, which is required, the museum moves your checked-in belongings to the exit. Oops! I left my wallet in my backpack. Now I can't use my coins to pay for some coin-operated exhibits. The museum is close to the train station and there is a farmer's market as well as other places to eat nearby. The entrance fee is 12 euros.
titleopinion: Dali Fans Unite. If you're a Dali fan, this museum is worth visiting. Unfortunately, this museum doesn't contain his classic paintings, but it does have a myriad of his other works in mediums other than paint which shows how talented and creative Dali was. After your backpack is checked-in, which is required, the museum moves your checked-in belongings to the exit. Oops! I left my wallet in my backpack. Now I can't use my coins to pay for some coin-operated exhibits. The museum is close to the train station and there is a farmer's market as well as other places to eat nearby. The entrance fee is 12 euros.

reviewnospace:
Day trip from Barcelona by train. 06.46 train from Barcelona Sants Station to Figueres.
But which counter to buy tickets from? Go to the left. "Tickets for Today". Pay in cash. Or credit/debit with original ID (no photocopies).
This is the Medium Distance (MD) train, which is a bit more expensive than the Regional (Reg), and is faster. Take the MD: more likely to get a seat, faster train. For three people: 96€ return ('round trip' in US English; 'anada i tornada' in Catalan).
Don't worry if you have bought Regional train tickets when you need MD tickets. The ticket inspector on the train will inform you if you have made a mistake. (4€ extra per person each way). Carry cash with you.
You can also get this train from Barcelona Passeig de Gracia Rodalies or Barcelona Clot Rodalies. Plenty of seats.

The museum itself is great - even if you have some idea of what to expect. Tour groups of bored German teenagers are mixed in with expert locals. Some reports online of this place bringing out the worst of humanity are probably a little exaggerated, but it does get crowded. If you take this 06.46 train from Barcelona, you get to Figueres about 08.30. Walk out of the station cross the small park and bear right. 10 mins to the museum. There was a queue of about 15 people in front of us, so when we went in it was more or less empty. Filled up with tour groups by ten a.m.
You will probably need anywhere between 2 hours and 2 years to see the contents of the museum properly. Take 1€, 20¢, and 50¢ coins to operate some of the moving exhibits. The Cadillac is especially great.
Backpacks must be left at the bag check place. Free. Pick up on leaving the museum at the end near the gift shop.
Museumed out? Your 12€ gets you into the adjacent Dalí jewellery museum. This is also spectacular, though much smaller.

Make a day of it and visit Girona on the way home. Turn left out of Girona Station and head toward the Jewish Quarter. Nice town. Very Catalan. If you want to do this buy single rail tickets Barcelona to Figueres; Figueres to Girona; Girona to Barcelona.
TAKE THE MD TRAIN from Figueres to Barcelona NOT THE REGIONAL. A bit more expensive, but you will get a seat (even in July) and it's quicker.

Longish day, but great memories.

reviewnospace: Amazing building architecture and design, completely outside the box "sculptures", beautiful paintings, exquisite jewels... all by Dali. Loved this place. It's the most interesting museum I've ever seen.
titleopinion: Weird, quirky & beautiful. Amazing building architecture and design, completely outside the box  sculptures , beautiful paintings, exquisite jewels... all by Dali. Loved this place. It's the most interesting museum I've ever seen.

quote: Even if you are not art lover this is recommended !
reviewnospace:
Not that I am not art lover but in most cases don't understand it unless it is scientifically based.
So the only reason I managed to get to Figueres was because I was within 50kliometers and thought to give it a try! I was so happy that I did ! We travelled to Figurese in the car and found the parking by a chance conveniently but a bit pricey more than London say !
Found the Museum easily but the queue was a genuine half a mile or a kilometre "visible " as most of members of families in the queue stay out of blazing Sun as ours did and fetched some ice cream to enable me to endure the waiting game!

reviewnospace:
Definitely worth a visit. We took our teenage kids to the museum and even they were fascinated. Entrance to the museum, as well as the jewel museum, was 12 Euro per adult and 9 Euro per child. Children under 8 may enter free of charge- although I cannot see any child of that age enjoying the outing. Go early as the crowds get hectic later in the day.
We chose the combination tickets and bought them online. This allowed us to simply walk past the long line of people still waiting to gain entry and enter through the door marked “Groups”, in the square, at the main entrance. Just go around the corner first to collect your tickets (with your print-out) at a ticket office dedicated to online purchases only. This is on the side of the building where the road is open to vehicle traffic. There is also a parking garage on another side of the building, which prevents you having to run back to pay parking every hour or so.
While I am no artist and in fact know very little about art, it was incredible to see how very talented Dali was and how diverse his talent was. His passion for art, both realistic and surreal, his use of technology in art, his love for his wife Dala and his dedication to his craft leaves one with food for thought for days afterwards. Do get a brochure, as the building has several hallways and one tends to get lost or entering the same space a second time if you don't follow the numbers to the designated areas in numerical order.
If you are not a fan of jewelry design then don’t bother with the jewelry museum. But if you are, then do purchase the combined ticket. The designs are over the top, bold, intricate and each one leads one to wonder about the type of person who would have been daring/enlightened/playful enough at the time to wear his creations

reviewnospace: Really just don't get this. No attraction to this. If I were to deface a local attraction to where I were born in this manner, I would be placed in prison!!; utter nonsense..

reviewnospace: A must see for Dali fans and art lovers alike. The museum itself is art. As soon as you walk in you are surrounded by Dali's unique taste and its fascinating. It can get very crowded.

reviewnospace:
I am not a fan of Dali's work but when my sister and niece were visiting they asked to go there on route to Barcelona.
Figueres is just over the border from France on the Mediterranean side of the Pyrenees and easily accessible from the autopista.There is a big multistory car park next door.
I had made up my mind I didn't like Dali's work and was pleasantly surprised to see some really good paintings although a lot of the weird stuff as well, a tree growing out of a car for instance.
If nearby its worth a visit even to a person, like me, who doesn't like that type of art, for the affectionado a must if you are down that way.

quote: Very crowded and no audio guide
reviewnospace: This museum is fun, but battling the crowds is not fun. I much prefer the Dali museum in Florida. Also, there are no audio guides, and some of the works are baffling, even to Dali fans. We eventually bought a book, small enough to carry around in their gift shop and that did help a bit. I don't think it's accessible. I wouldn't skip the museum, but if you do go, make a stop in the nearby town of Girona. Walk through the old quarter there--don't miss it!

reviewnospace: A must see for Dali fans. Thoroughly enjoyable day out. We booked this as an excursion through Thomson & were treated well by the excursion company.
titleopinion: Dali heaven. A must see for Dali fans. Thoroughly enjoyable day out. We booked this as an excursion through Thomson & were treated well by the excursion company.

reviewnospace:
This was my first stop on the Dali trail. The museum itself is super and interactive (thus, the "theater" in its name).

However, there are no audio guides and so it's easy to miss hidden things. I was very lucky to be standing near a group that had hired an outstanding English guide.

I eavesdropped now and then and the museum, Dali, and his wife Gala came alive for me. It also helped make sense at the Dali house in Cadaques the next day. I wish I had hired Nik Duserm, the guide, myself.

The very bad part is that photography is allowed and people block things as they photograph. Hey, folks...take a look at the art. You're there. It's alive!

Aside from having to fight to see the art, it's a wonderful place.

And take 1 euro and 20 cent coins for the interactive exhibits.

It's alive!  Aside from having to fight to see the art, it's a wonderful place.   And take 1 euro and 20 cent coins for the interactive exhibits.

quote: A required visit if in Alt Empordá
reviewnospace:
If you are visiting the region, make sure to find time to visit this surprising museum.

Dalí is not everybody's cup of tea, but this museum will probably make you get a more balanced opinión on his art.

It covers the different phases of his artistic evolution, and also offers curious installations and mixed art forms, which adds to the legend of the artist's genius.

There is a parking house right behind the museum, which is the most convenient place to park, if you are coming by car.

Dalí is not everybody's cup of tea, but this museum will probably make you get a more balanced opinión on his art.  It covers the different phases of his artistic evolution, and also offers curious installations and mixed art forms, which adds to the legend of the artist's genius.  There is a parking house right behind the museum, which is the most convenient place to park, if you are coming by car.

reviewnospace:
We took a side trip from Barcelona to Figueres just to see this museum. Dali Museum is the number #1 reason tourists flock to Figueres. I kid you not, "flock" is the right word. It gets extremely crowded. A lot of organized tours are bussed in, and being a relatively small building, it is very difficult to make your way through the crowds. Perhaps afternoon visit is a better option. We intended to spend about 3 hours there, and ended up spending twice as much due to the crowds. Don't forget to visit the Dali Jewels exhibit which has a separate entrance.
Personally I prefer The Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Florida. It has a much more representative Dali collection.

quote: Makes you think, but a must see just to appreciate
reviewnospace: The setting is an old theater, and the museum planners use the space efficiently. Dali's work is amazing, from portraits that look like photographs to stereography to jewelry to sculpture. All the famous melted clocks are here, and the various phases of his work are clearly illustrated with large numbers of his work. In order to understand all the symbology (which is everywhere in his art), I recommend a good book beforehand to explain why he uses drawers in figures, the origin and meaning of the clocks, and others. Visitors will not be disappointed - this is an amazing museum holding the works of a true genius, though at times I admit I was puzzled by his work. It is two exhibits - the theater with his art, and a separate exhibit hall for his jewelry. If you are anywhere within range of Figueres, Dali's birthplace, it is worth the time to visit.

reviewnospace: Had a wonderful visit in this lovely museum, the atrium with its own sculptures and planting, the theater, and the galleries on (I think ) three floors were all wonderful. An additional treat is the "Masterpiece Room" housing pieces from Dali's collection including some dutch masters and a Bouegereau. We had two hours (including visiting the jewelry museum next door - worth a separate review) and it was "just" enough.

reviewnospace: I was in a vacantion with my wife at Lloret de Mar (Costa Brava, Spain) and we visited this theatre museum in Figueres (buses from hour to hour from and to, 20 euros/pers). This is a place you do not have to miss if you are at Costa Brava. It was amaizing , interesting and, why not, educational. Salvador Dali was one of the greatest artists of the world. Before visiting the museum, read something about the life and the work of Salvador Dali!

reviewnospace: This is a wonderful museum. The art, the history, the architecture of the building, everything is amazing. We went here for one day only, we drove from France, and we did not get a good impression of the town of Figueres, a day visit is good enough.

reviewnospace:
This museum gallery was a highlight of a 9 week trip. It is full of the most unusual and brilliant art, paintings, sculptures and jewellery I have ever seen. Get there at opening time to avoid queues.
A very worthwhile visit about an hour away from Barcelona and a lovely friendly small village to visit as well.
titleopinion: Fantastic!!. This museum gallery was a highlight of a 9 week trip. It is full of the most unusual and brilliant art, paintings, sculptures and jewellery I have ever seen. Get there at opening time to avoid queues. A very worthwhile visit about an hour away from Barcelona and a lovely friendly small village to visit as well.

quote: Maybe the Best Single-Artist Museum in the World
reviewnospace:
Holy smokes.
To state my biases straight out, I'm not a huge museum guy -- call me what you will, but if it's not the Met in NY, the British Museum, or the Louvre, and it's not raining cats & dogs, I'd much rather do something (anything) else, particularly if it's a museum devoted to a single artist, which is usually a much larger display of ego than of art.
But WOW!
The Dali Museum is simply overwhelming, and you must go, even if you hate museums or surrealism or both.
There are many famous works, including the monumental "Rainy Cadillac" (Dali's '41 Caddy convertible with a fat lady on the hood, dummy passengers getting rained on inside, and a boat on a flagpole high overhead); the Palace of the Wind room with its magnificent ceiling fresco; and the ever popular Mae West room; but in a sense the Museum as a whole is itself a work of art -- maybe even Dali's masterpiece -- because it, and everything in it, was conceived and designed by the artist himself as a collective sensory experience -- a Cliff's Notes of surrealism, if you will. Dali literally gave this project his "all" -- he's buried here, and his grave lies among the exhibits!
Don't forget the jewelry collection (included in admission price) -- not really jewelry so much as sculpture using gold & precious stones as the media of expression -- magnificent stuff.
There is little other reason to visit Figueres, IMO, but this museum is more than enough reason all by itself.
Stay at the El Moli bed-and-breakfast nearby (see my review), and drink it all in. It's an experience simply not to be missed.

But WOW!  The Dali Museum is simply overwhelming, and you must go, even if you hate museums or surrealism or both.  There are many famous works, including the monumental  Rainy Cadillac  (Dali's '41 Caddy convertible with a fat lady on the hood, dummy passengers getting rained on inside, and a boat on a flagpole high overhead); the Palace of the Wind room with its magnificent ceiling fresco; and the ever popular Mae West room; but in a sense the Museum as a whole is itself a work of art -- maybe even Dali's masterpiece -- because it, and everything in it, was conceived and designed by the artist himself as a collective sensory experience -- a Cliff's Notes of surrealism, if you will. Dali literally gave this project his  all  -- he's buried here, and his grave lies among the exhibits!  Don't forget the jewelry collection (included in admission price) -- not really jewelry so much as sculpture using gold & precious stones as the media of expression -- magnificent stuff.  There is little other reason to visit Figueres, IMO, but this museum is more than enough reason all by itself. Stay at the El Moli bed-and-breakfast nearby (see my review), and drink it all in. It's an experience simply not to be missed.

quote: An art museum like no other
reviewnospace:
For anyone considering taking the train from Barcelona to Figueres, I strongly recommend doing so, if you're looking to save the money you would otherwise invest in an organized tour.

Getting there is easy and only involves getting a ticket worth 16 Euros for a one way trip. Trains leave frequently, from early morning, until late into the night, so you have plenty of options to choose from as you plan your travel.

Arriving to the museum from the train station isn't nearly as difficult as I had imagined. I wasn't able to download a detailed map connecting the train station to the Museum beforehand, but there are free (hard copy) maps you can get from the information center, right before exiting the station, together with any other directions you might need. The staff working there and selling tickets also speaks English, so you needn't worry about any communication barriers at all.

The train ride takes under two hours one way and is pretty simple to figure out IF the display screens announcing the next station inside the train compartment actually work! They didn't on our way back, so I suggest you sit close to other locals and ask for your stop, just to be on the safe side. If you're getting off at Barcelona, make sure you remember the name of your exact stop, as there are several "Barcelona" stations, that aren't close to each other.

As other reviewers have mentioned, the museum itself doesn't have a clear route to follow once inside. But, seeing as this was Dali's own wish and is just another sign of his eccentricity, you should allow yourself to get lost in the madness of the museum, and enjoy it to the fullest.

What did bother me, though, was the fact that the brochure they give you at the entrance contains Dali's art works that have since been moved from the museum! This was not mentioned anywhere and caused a lot of confusion, since we were left under the impression that we had omitted seeing them in the rooms pointed out on our map. To make matters worse, when I asked one of the museum guards where we could find the pieces shown in the brochure we had received on arrival (i.e. in which room they were displayed), she just nonchalantly shrugged and told us that she didn't know.

It was only when I found a different guard who was kind enough to try to explain to me - in Spanish (none of them spoke English) - that some works had been given to other museums around the world, that we realized that they had thus made all the brochures that were being given out useless.

All in all, the Dali Theater Museum is definitely something worth experiencing, if not to get a better understanding of Dali, then at least to enjoy the opportunity to witness the creative eccentricity of an artist like no other.
Go there and stand in awe of his undying love for Gala, watch his art works, admire his installations, take in his paintings, his sketches, his statues, his unique jewelry (some of which is moving!) and remember to always look at everything both within close range, as well as after taking a few steps back, as Dali was a mastermind of illusion and he loved playing tricks on the eye. (I only noticed what some of the objects hanging off of the museum walls created as a whole, after looking over the pictures I took, when I got home, for example!)

Make sure not to miss the jewelry museum after you step out of the main "theatre-museum". After you've finished seeing them both, enjoy a stroll around the building for some great shots with the famous eggs resting on the outer walls, and watch all the other little quirky things adorning both the building itself and the square surrounding it - the figures holding loaves of bread, the scuba suit, the car tire column, etc.

Definitely not your run of the mill, dusty, quiet museum!

reviewnospace: A superb museum which is fascinating at every turn. Follow the numbers which will mean you do not miss anything. It is truly magnificent and will capture your heart. Would definitely return.

quote: A place to visit even if you know nothing about art
reviewnospace:
I am not a big fan of art museums, but this one took me by surprise. It is refreshingly fun.

Crazy is the word I would use to summarise my opinion of the work of Señor Salvador Dali. But, his work cannot be classified as just "crazy". It is awe inspiring, intelligent, quirky, fun, philosophical, intriguing, poetic, beautiful, transcending generations and never seizes to amaze.

It is definitely worth a visit and could just change the way you look at art.
titleopinion: A place to visit even if you know nothing about art. I am not a big fan of art museums, but this one took me by surprise. It is refreshingly fun.   Crazy is the word I would use to summarise my opinion of the work of Señor Salvador Dali. But, his work cannot be classified as just  crazy . It is awe inspiring, intelligent, quirky, fun, philosophical, intriguing, poetic, beautiful, transcending generations and never seizes to amaze.   It is definitely worth a visit and could just change the way you look at art.

reviewnospace:
The signs via road are not that good so rely on a sat nav . There is plenty of parking nearby , the one you are directed to outside the museum from the direction we came from would have been an impossible manoeuvre so we opted for the underground one not far away at around 4 euros plus the car stays cool .

The building is spectacular from the outside and the time spent in the queue which wasn't too bad at around 20 mins in a relatively shaded square. Adults are 12 euros each and once in you are in a building filled with the strange . From the central courtyard containing the famous american style car complete with curvaceous bronze female statue and dripping globules .... you have to see it to get it . Around the curved galleries are load of rooms off with various works of art from the man himself to carefully chosen pieces all a bit odd . One of those things really you either love or just don't get it ! The museum has good loo`s and there is an outside area with water fountain to cool off . There is a good souvenir shop with well priced items . leave enough time if you can to walk around the town , we had a lovely lunch 100 yards from the museum , would leave a review can remember the name of the restaurant . In short well worth a visit I would advise to book tickets ahead if you can , go early or late on a hot day , I understood they did late night visits and leave enough time to explore the town ....

reviewnospace: A very well set up museum in a Dali manner, the comment in the guidebook saying that the numbers are there to help you through the museum but it's Salvador Dali, you sure don't have to. Although I strongly recommend it otherwise you might miss something. It's as grand as it's creator and there's a lot of finesse in the way the art is showcased. Look closely otherwise you'll miss something. I would recommend getting in early as when we were there just after lunch it was pretty packed. Don't miss the jewel-museum when your there it's a really cool glittery exhibition.

reviewnospace: crazy, beautiful, mesmerising, thought provoking, weird and wonderful. Our kids - 9 and 7 loved it. Prebook tickets for museum, but buy your train tickets once you get into Spain - we saved about $100 that way. Also, if you're finished and want to return to Barcelona early, the train station people were very helpful.

reviewnospace:
While staying in Barcelona we took a guided tour to this museum .It can be reached also by train or bus .The museum is really a must for art lovers .The collection is very big and it is recommended to take a break and then to continue the visit.The building itself is an introduction to a special world of fantasy and to the works of this special painter.
It is even worth staying for the night in order to have enough time for a long visit to the museum. We have been to the Dali museum in Florida,US and my impression is that this museum has a better collection.

We have been to the Dali museum in Florida,US and my impression is that this museum has a better collection.

quote: A mind altering lesson into Dali's brain and the meaning of art.
reviewnospace: Ok, how pretentious can a guy get with my title above. But I swear it's true. This museum has the best of Dali. It was designed by him. I have been moved to tears before in front of various works in a number of museums around the world. But in this place it is one after the other. Hundreds of first rate pieces, each with multiple ideas pouring out of them. Just go. I can't say enough or anything adequately. Go when it opens to be intimate with the work. Worth a trip of hundreds of miles to get there. Stay overnight in Figueres (Hotel Duran was excellent). You will not regret it.

reviewnospace: We were alerted to the Dali Museum by our host in a small town in France. Coming back from Barcelona we decided to take a detour. We were not disappointed. The museum was spectacular. Crowded - as can be expected, but contains works not often seen. Criticism of some reviewers that works are not the best know does not matter. There is an array of works that spans his life and different periods - many not so well known. A great experience with an added bonus of the amazing jewelry collection that must not be missed.
titleopinion: View into a fanatical mind. We were alerted to the Dali Museum by our host in a small town in France. Coming back from Barcelona we decided to take a detour. We were not disappointed. The museum was spectacular. Crowded - as can be expected, but contains works not often seen. Criticism of some reviewers that works are not the best know does not matter. There is an array of works that spans his life and different periods - many not so well known. A great experience with an added bonus of the amazing jewelry collection that must not be missed.

reviewnospace: We picked up a rental car from Barcelona airport and drove straight to Figueres , a small town in northen Spain where the Dali Theatre Museum is. We didn't really visit the town but planned our trip mainly to visit the museum. We arrived early evening and just went straight to the hotel for dinner and an early sleep to wake up early the next morning to beat the queue and it was the strategy to save hours in the line. We woke up early and walked to the museum, decided to have local breakfast at a near by coffee shop and had a quick photo shoot in front of the theater when the road is quite empty for a good take of the museum external view. Then we headed straight to the museum entrance. We arrived about 8:30am, 30 minutes prior to opening hour with about 20 people in the line in front of us already. The place is quirky, impressive and it's quite Dali to convert his childhood town theater into his museum/ home/ crypt. We went with our 2 boys 11 and 13 then and they lasted almost 4 hours with growing urge to leave the party after the first 3 hours which is quite good for our expectation. However, Dali is quite kids friendly in a way that his art is full of surprise, quirkiness, curiosity, interactive and "naughtiness". Of course there's a lot of adult theme in his arts but we are responsible parents so we did give parental guidance :-). Make sure you go early to the Mae West Room and climb up the viewing platform as it's one of the most popular installation in the museum. And spend good amount of time investigating the central courtyard where the Rainy Cadillac montage parks. We all also enjoyed the Palace of the Wind's bedroom and the jewelry museum, it's a wonderful collection that showcase different sides of his creativity. The building itself is a wonderful piece of art and and indeed if not for the kids growing need to leave, I can easily spend the whole day there. We left the museum around 1ish and walked out to see the enormous line feeling thankful that we arrived early. Had good lunch at a nearby restaurant and walked around the town center for over an hour before leaving to our next destination. Highly recommend to family with kids young or teen.

quote: Worth the 3 hour train ride from Barcelona
reviewnospace:
Enjoyed every inch of this museum: it is unusual, catchy, kitschy, and amusing. Perfect day trip from Barcelona. Make sure to really look at his drawings in the half circle room on the bottom floor - you will find quite a few interesting sexual references.

Great place to visit for everyone, not just Dali fans.
titleopinion: Worth the 3 hour train ride from Barcelona. Enjoyed every inch of this museum: it is unusual, catchy, kitschy, and amusing. Perfect day trip from Barcelona. Make sure to really look at his drawings in the half circle room on the bottom floor - you will find quite a few interesting sexual references.   Great place to visit for everyone, not just Dali fans.

reviewnospace:
We have been to many Dali museums and I thought this one was one of the best. It was not only the art work, but the way they have the building laid out and segregated to get into the art for that area. We were first in line so when we got in, we had the best pictures of the main car artwork without anyone else in the shot. Not so 10 minutes later. We took the train from Barcelona and arrived at 8:30. Plenty of time to walk the 15 minutes from the station. Just go straight on road and take a diagonal left through park and straight across the street. Stand in line for ticket at white theatre building in back. First in gets best pictures ( especially since a buses of kids and tourist come in at 10).

You also get a ticket for jewelry building next door. The red brick building with eggs on top. That was not so interesting but we did a quick walk through.

Well worth the 1 hour train ride.

quote: Definitely Worth the Trip to See This Museum
reviewnospace:
The Dali Theatre-Museum is simply outstanding. This was Dali's home at one time. The art displayed is magnificent in terms of quality and quantity. We spent three hours or so in the museum, and never tired. And then as we thought we were departing the museum, we see that there is an exhibit of jewelry designed and made by Salvatore Dali. I never knew he made jewelry, and what we saw exhibited there was beautiful in concept, design and workmanship. Two full stories of Dali jewelry, breathtaking.

When we did depart, we then spent considerable time viewing the theatre with its ornate spires. Again, engaging and wonderful to look at.

We were driving from near Carcassonne, France to Barcelona, and thought we would make a brief stop at this museum. Each of the four of us was mesmerized by the art, the jewelry, and the architecture. We stayed much longer than expected, and had a wonderful visit. I highly recommend visiting this museum.

We stayed much longer than expected, and had a wonderful visit. I highly recommend visiting this museum.

reviewnospace: Went here knot mowing what to expect, it was really good with plenty to see and it was not to bad a price to get in with carparking next door it is some thing to tick of your todo list and would visit again if in the area.

reviewnospace: We drove to Figueres as part of a road trip and our way to Carcassonne, France, but this museum is worth at least a day trip. We stayed two nights because we got to Figueres in the early evening and we wanted to take our time at the museum next day. This also allowed us to eat at one of the best restaurants of Spain whose chef used to cook for Dali.The food and the museum were outstanding and in a way complemented each other. Whatever you do, take your time to enjoy the art of Dali. .

The cost is low, there is little or no "guidance" but man it was awesome. We arrived into Barcelona and immediately rented and car and drove to Figueres. Beautiful!

quote: Worth a visit if you are in the area
reviewnospace: We visited the Dali museum as we were staying in a resort relatively close by. We found the museum very interesting, being an art fan anyway I especially enjoy surrealism art and so this visit was thoroughly enjoyed. It was relatively cheap entry fee and some fantastic pieces of art all over the museum... Look closely so as not to miss anything! Worth a visit of you are close by!

reviewnospace:
I admit this is a late review, I went probably the best part of 13 years ago but I have been twice so I enjoyed it the first time!
It may have changed in the time I have been away but this really was worth every euro of the entry fee and then some. I admit I'm a Dali fan and to see some of his work 'in the flesh' was an experience, I also remember thinking that as a gallery it was completely bonkers as the outside was covered in bread. There are also other surrealist artists work there so it's an opportunity to expand your repertoire if your only experience of the art form is Dali.

quote: The popularity is the only downfall
reviewnospace: I have waited years to visit and I wasn't disappointed. It is unfortunate that Dali left instructions that the museum would have no explanations in the museum, to enjoy it you need to do a bit of reading first. The only downside is that route is somewhat random and doubles back so if you visit when it is full it could be very frustrating. We went on a Saturday in late May and our guide assured us it was not busy at all.

quote: No melting clocks or elephant long legs here!
reviewnospace:
Euro 12 pp entry to museum as well as to the jewels. There is also a night entry for euro 13 – I guess you pay the extra dollar to avoid the crowds as everyone seems to go in the morning.

We went to the Castello in the afternoon and upon walking back to the museum, we found it was rather empty.

We were disappointed not to have seen any of Dali’s famous melting time pieces and elephants here – was told it is in MOMA in New York which we did see but would have liked to have seen it (again) in his home town.

reviewnospace: Although no experts on surrealist art we thoroughly enjoyed this quirky museum, clearly designed by an eccentric artist. We took the advice of others and arrived before it opened as it quickly filled up with groups and school parties. However we did manage to find spaces to stand and admire the genius of Dali. Don't miss the exhibition of jewels... we thought these were quite beautiful.

We took the advice of others and arrived before it opened as it quickly filled up with groups and school parties. However we did manage to find spaces to stand and admire the genius of Dali. Don't miss the exhibition of jewels... we thought these were quite beautiful.

reviewnospace:
Our experience of theTeatro-Museu Dali was fantastic even though I could not access most of the exhibits! The museum is not wheelchair-friendly but we were both admitted free and I was able to see the courtyard, most of the ground floor and the jewels so, being philosophical, it was a worthwhile visit.
My husband toured the whole place and I had to be content with photos and videos he took but, even so, I would not have missed it. I was particularly impressed with the attitude of the staff who were more than helpful and, especially, the female attendant who ensured that we saw the jewellery and the attendant inside the jewel house who showed us the lift which we would never have found in the dark! I got the impression they really wanted visitors to see and marvel at these exhibits.
Dali is obviously not everyone's cup of tea and maybe we were lucky the place was not overrun with visitors but from what I did see I loved the Dali craziness of it all and recommend it as part of one's education in art even if you are going to carp about it afterwards.
