quote: The extraordinary legacy of the moustachioed gent aired to perfection.
reviewnospace:
The pretty capital of Alt Emporda is famous for the fact that it bred two extraordinary characters in a short period of time. One was the eccentric Dali,the other, the famous maritime legend of Figueres, which figures why the town is honours his feats. Perhaps its the evocative atmosphere of the Avenue where his monument is located,lined with plane trees and lovely 19th century houses,for its the place as well,for the evening stroll.

But its the Dali brand that has made this town pop,with the Dali museum,the most frequented after the Prada in Madrid,a personal legacy of the moustachioed gent,fielding works from all periods of his life. Dali's hand guided by his exuberant imagination,can be sensed everywhere. His quirky pieces bring joy and puzzlement ,once you realise the torment and turpitude his experiences in life led him to create with such depth and whimsy.

In fact,in order to sum up the enormous breadth of his creativity,you have to slow your amble to pause and savour each painting and sculpture. I particularly was taken with the grotesque ceiling painting in the hall of the Palace of the Wind.

Once outside,there are in the town some Dali-free zones. The church of St. Pere,a toy museum and the lovely Museu de l'Emporda. A few km to the south of town,Pubel showcases Dali's medieval castle.

reviewnospace: Incredible place. Very interesting. Lots of opportunities to take unusual photos and see quirky and eclectic things. Nowhere like it ;-)
titleopinion: Unforgettable. Incredible place. Very interesting. Lots of opportunities to take unusual photos and see quirky and eclectic things. Nowhere like it ;-)

quote: Must see if you are near Barcelona
reviewnospace:
We visit this place after we visited Girona, it was an excursion we booked via Viator, worth it
Even if you are not a Dali fan you must go there if you are in the area, I don't have enough words to describe it , it's great,it's awesome, it's amazing, totally agree with TrB876-don't miss the jewels
But book everything in advance, make sure the museum is open if you want to come on Monday
titleopinion: Must see if you are near Barcelona. We visit this place after we visited Girona, it was an excursion we booked via Viator, worth it Even if you are not a Dali fan you must go there if you are in the area, I don't have enough words to describe it , it's great,it's awesome, it's amazing, totally agree with TrB876-don't miss the jewels But book everything in advance, make sure the museum is open if you want to come on Monday

reviewnospace: What a treat to see the museum/theater that Dali himself designed! It was also helpful to have a guide point out some of the things we might shave otherwise missed. We took a tour bus (Julia Tours) to both Girona and Figueres and the juxtaposition of the antiquity of Girona and the modernity of Dali was quite enchanting. Definitely worth a day!
titleopinion: Dali museum a must see. What a treat to see the museum/theater that Dali himself designed! It was also helpful to have a guide point out some of the things we might shave otherwise missed. We took a tour bus (Julia Tours) to both Girona and Figueres and the juxtaposition of the antiquity of Girona and the modernity of Dali was quite enchanting. Definitely worth a day!

reviewnospace:
We bought the joint ticket for the museum and the jewels (there is a good reduction for concessions if you have ID). We thoroughly enjoyed the experience, not having been much into Dali in the past. There was a lot of variety in the museum and to do it justice you should take your time. Not all of what is on display is Dali's work; e.g. it includes a large display of work by his close friend Antoni Pitxot, and this all adds to the interest. The museum was opened in Dali's lifetime and so he had a hand in the design. Several well known works are on display and the Mae West room is most unusual and was created expressly for the museum.
The jewels (in a separate part of the building) are spectacular - the lighting is very low and the display of the jewels is stunning. Be sure to take a camera that you can turn the flash off of, then you can take pictures in the museum and jewel displays.

quote: Worth the trip but can be busy!
reviewnospace:
Spent a Sunday catching the fast train to Figueres to see this wonderful museum. Few key tips;

I booked my ticket online the day before on loco2.com. It's a fantastic booking website, so easy to use unlike many other train booking sights. I also used them when I was planning my trip in Melbourne for train trips in France, again so easy. (Many other sights are so annoying to navigate).

I visited the museum on a Sunday ( to AVOID school groups) no such luck, made no difference there were heaps of students there, which at times was annoying if you wanted to view pieces for an extended period of time. However I found it was better if I stayed ahead of the group. But as others have said, expect lots of people!

The works are fascinating and a broad range of Dali's work, I have been lucky to see his work elsewhere, but was very happy to spend the time here.

Few more tips. Again I booked my ticket online, was necessarily of any benefit as I had to queue to get my ticket, but wait to get in was nothing (I went at 10.45)

Because I hadn't been to Figueres before I caught a taxi to museum from the station (€11). However going back I caught the bus (€1.70!) was very easy just a short walk down the hill from the museum.

Finally, as often is the case, try and walk a bit further away from museum for lunch, I found a great tapas place just near the taxi rank in the centre of town, full of locals and yummy food and sangria.

Hope this has been of help, as a solo traveller I use this sight so often, good to remember to pay it forward!


I

reviewnospace:
Best value, engaging, interactive museum.
Wow - I am just very overwhelmed by this shrine to Dali that he himself built, conceived, curated, designed by the mad genius himself. and when I say genius I'm not kidding. A glimpse into this space will give you insight into his chaotic but beautifully creative mind. I can't even be coherent such is my excitement. This is not the type of experience you can put to paper.
In short - go!!! Go now!!! If you are within 250 Mike radius of this place you owe it to yourself to go!
titleopinion: I love the Dali Museum!. Best value, engaging, interactive museum.  Wow - I am just very overwhelmed by this shrine to Dali that he himself built, conceived, curated, designed by the mad genius himself. and when I say genius I'm not kidding. A glimpse into this space will give you insight into his chaotic but beautifully creative mind. I can't even be coherent such is my excitement. This is not the type of experience you can put to paper.  In short - go!!! Go now!!! If you are within 250 Mike radius of this place you owe it to yourself to go!

reviewnospace: We visited this museum during our week-long vacation in Barcelona. It's an excellent day trip - especially combined with our stop in Girona on the way back to Barcelona. I wouldn't say that we're huge Dali fans, but this museum has some of his most interesting works and it was very well presented. The Mae West room is probably worth the price of admission, but there's so much more. The only downside to our visit is that they let way too many people in - it's basically wall-to-wall people. It would have been better if we they had reserved visiting times with less of a crowd. However, the art was worth seeing and it's a very pleasant train ride from Barcelona.
titleopinion: Worth the trip from Barcelona. We visited this museum during our week-long vacation in Barcelona. It's an excellent day trip - especially combined with our stop in Girona on the way back to Barcelona. I wouldn't say that we're huge Dali fans, but this museum has some of his most interesting works and it was very well presented. The Mae West room is probably worth the price of admission, but there's so much more. The only downside to our visit is that they let way too many people in - it's basically wall-to-wall people. It would have been better if we they had reserved visiting times with less of a crowd. However, the art was worth seeing and it's a very pleasant train ride from Barcelona.

reviewnospace: This was my daughter's reaction after spending a morning experiencing Dali's creativity with all the senses. It's fun, educational, aesthetic, multi-dimensional, inside and outside. What more can you ask for? Well, next time, I will take the night visit, which should be interesting. If I return by day, I make sure to enter before the busloads of French school kids on art field trips.

If I return by day, I make sure to enter before the busloads of French school kids on art field trips.

reviewnospace: Wanted to come for 25 years finally have. I am a huge Dali fan and enjoyed the museum. It has a very good collection, if you want good photo's take a good camara that works well without a flash as flash is not allowed, also be one of the first through the door. I would also recommend weekends to avoid the school coach trips.

reviewnospace:
I studied art in highschool and have always been a big fan of Dali so when my partner and I went to Spain it was a must do. We spent a night in Figueres just for this museum and it was worth it. It's a bizarre and fantastical place - different to basically all art museums - it really is an experience, not just a place to look at art. My partner isn't into art as much as I am but he enjoyed it nonetheless, it is however very strange, and if you are not into the surrealistic nature of the art you probably won't enjoy too much.

We went in an off season so it wasn't too busy but there was several school groups. The ticket you buy at the museum also covers the dali jewels exhibit which is also worth the time.

quote: Fun for everyone, not just Dali Devotee
reviewnospace: The art was fun, had great color and seemed to fascinate everyone in the museum. It was much more upbeat than what I remember studying in Art History 101.

reviewnospace:
Sometimes words are not enough to describe museums like this one! Definitely one of the best attractions of Barcelona area and I suggest you MUST visit it when you visit Barcelona, although it is a 90 mins trip from the city. Everything is simply amazing, the building, the artwork inside, the paintings... Dali is a genius, everybody knows that, but you will love this place even if you are not a Dali fan. Paintings like Lincoln or artworks like the Mae West apartment are masterpieces that you can't easily find. The only drawback is that this place is EXTREMELY popular and it attracts all kind of tourists. For example, when I visited, it was crowded of groups of French young students (probably an educational trip) that seemed to have little or no knowledge of Dali and his work and were only interested in taking self pictures with their smartphones and making noise. Pitty!
So be there VERY early if you want to avoid massive queues for admission.
TIP: The trip to Figueres is an easy train ride from Barcelona (a little less than 2 hours each way). Even if you haven't been there before, it is very easy to get there on your own instead of going with a travel agent. The cheapest price they asked was 67 Euros. If you choose to go on your own, the train costs from 22-35 Euros (depending on the speed) return and the admission fee is 12 Euros, so you' ll save some money. If you take the local train, you get off in the town center. From there, it's an easy 10 minutes walk to the museum.

Paintings like Lincoln or artworks like the Mae West apartment are masterpieces that you can't easily find. The only drawback is that this place is EXTREMELY popular and it attracts all kind of tourists. For example, when I visited, it was crowded of groups of French young students (probably an educational trip) that seemed to have little or no knowledge of Dali and his work and were only interested in taking self pictures with their smartphones and making noise. Pitty! So be there VERY early if you want to avoid massive queues for admission. TIP: The trip to Figueres is an easy train ride from Barcelona (a little less than 2 hours each way). If you take the local train, you get off in the town center. From there, it's an easy 10 minutes walk to the museum.

reviewnospace:
I first visited this exhibition many years ago, the visit on Tuesday 22 April 2014 was with my wife, she had not been there before.
Our holiday was based in Santa Sussana about 90 minutes away by train. The information desk at the railway station in Figueras is excellent, they supplied a detailed map and directed us to the museum.
I could not possibly recommend anyone to go there after our experience.
The queue was about 20 metres, but it took over an hour to gain entry. The queue is neither managed nor stewarded, I saw many family groups head straight for the front and push in, the woman at the single entry desk was not interested in any protests at this behaviour. The museum obviously has a policy of accepting far too many dis-organised school trips as there were countless groups of mostly French school children ushered into an adjoining group entrance.
This utterly destroyed any hope of appreciating the exhibition. They ran amok, spending the whole time photographing themselves and each other and the exhibits. Squealing, shouting and running around is fine in a theme park, but not at a museum. Their teachers, probably glad to be free for a few hours were conspicuous by their absence. The few museum stewards I saw, sat listlessly in the corners of the exhibition rooms endlessly shouting “No Flash” and being totally ignored. It was like a zoo, with the chimps on the loose. Salvador Dali is the epitome of surrealism, and a master of optical illusion. It was simply impossible to appreciate any of this.
I apologised to my wife that this visit had been utterly ruined. It is clearly a policy of the museum to over whelm the exhibition with too many groups presumably to maximise their income to the detriment to others.
Visitors would be far better advised to use the entrance money on a beer and a snack and then browse the many Dali themed souvenir shops.

quote: Can you buy tickets in advance at the museum?
reviewnospace: I am salivating like Dali at the thought of going to this museum, but am having no luck purchasing tickets on line at the museum's website for June 23rd. We are coming from Girona on our last day in the area before we head back to Barcelona. Any tips would be helpful! Thanks!

quote: Art as humour - who would have guessed?
reviewnospace: Dali had an amazing imagination and a great sense of humour. This was the first time we had been in a museum that made us smile, sometimes laugh and always wonder at the incredible imagination that could conjure these outrageous creations. It was also very cool to be in a museum created by the artist. The very building and the rooms were all part of the exhibit. Things aren't explained. It isn't about "understanding" Dali. It is about sharing his sense of humour. Our young adult kids loved it and so did we.
titleopinion: Art as humour - who would have guessed?. Dali had an amazing imagination and a great sense of humour. reviewnospace:
We came with very high expectations and ended very disappointed.
The building and the overall visual effect of the main halls is overwhelming.
However the museum is a total shame.
You get a one page brochure with very little information.
There is no option for an audio-guide.
Most of the works are not even named.
Some are named but don't have any further information about them.
Without a guide you are just wandering around and getting pushed by the crowds.
The museum is overcrowded and there is no control on the amount of visitors.
The place could be a gem with a just little attention, but it is not!!

However the museum is a total shame. You get a one page brochure with very little information. There is no option for an audio-guide. Most of the works are not even named. Some are named but don't have any further information about them. Without a guide you are just wandering around and getting pushed by the crowds. The museum is overcrowded and there is no control on the amount of visitors. The place could be a gem with a just little attention, but it is not!!

quote: One of the most impressive museums ever visited
reviewnospace:
I had wanted to visit this site for decades and I was not disappointed. Well worth the trip. Easy to use local train from Sants or Passeig de Garcia. Return fare 32 Euros each with great views from the train.
The museum blows your mind with the variety & excentricity. In the main high room, cuploa or stage, of the building view the massive artwork on the left wall from many angles & distances. Then view it through your camera. The image comes our as 3 different scenes - a woman, Lincoln & Elton John. This was before I had a drink!
The variety in the rest of the museum beggars belief.
Good lunches in the central square as a break before the next sight. A world away from Barcelona & best done as a small group. Organise your self & beat the crowds.

quote: Must See Even for Non Art Lovers
reviewnospace: What a great way to spend a morning with non-art loving teenage boys! Waited in line for around 15 minutes at 1030 but by lunchtime queues were too long for comfort. Will definitely go back as there was too much (and too crowded) to see all I wanted to see and definitely a challenge for those with limited mobility who would miss the Mae West instillation worth queing for. Not cheap for those of us who benefit from museums and art galleries being free but I certainly do feel it was worth paying for. I definitely benefited from overhearing a well informed English speaking guide hosting an educational tour for young people, who informed me that they don't provide guides for families/indiviudals which I think would be helpful for those like me who would like to experience it from a more informed position. ......

quote: If you're in this part of the world it's worth the trip.
reviewnospace: This gallery is different from most art galleries in that the artist himself was integral in its design and construction. Love him or hate him Dali is a character it is worth learning more about. This gallery showcases the full range of his work in no particular chronological order (which was the wish of the artist). You may not like everything you see but you are left with a strong appreciation of the artist talent of a very unique man. I have lived in Figueres for 6 months and it seems that weekends seem to be busiest for this gallery. Chances are you'll probably come here as part of a day trip. Two further tips: 1.) Avoid the food in the vicinity of the restaurant. It's crap and overpriced. 2.) Go for a walk around the castle for great views.

reviewnospace: I've been many times before and its a great place to go so i thought i would take my family on this trip but this time the museum has little or no control over how many people are entering the doors and so the place was over full, money money money i guess. This situation i could have put up with but for every person just clicking a device at a picture or art work, there is no chance to just stare at the work and take in the altered worlds of perception while you have hundreds of flashes around your vision. Maybe we just got a very bad day but the cost of entry outweighed the experience I'm sorry to say. One possibility for the poor experience was that the day that we went was a rainy day and maybe it is best to visit on a sunny day when less people are going

reviewnospace:
I learned a lot about this amazing artist in the museum, so much that my mouth and eyes were literally open half of the time while listening to the tour guide. [Spoiler Alert] I was particularly interested in the picture of the half eaten bread in the middle of the Treasure Room. Although it might mean something important, I think the artist just placed excessive importance on it as a way to fool us, because you know, he is known for being "crazy".
I highly recommend going to this museum with a personal guide, as it can be difficult to understand the depth of Dali's work.

reviewnospace:
A lot of people around the world have assembled Dali works, but I think this is the most representative (except for a temporary exhibit I saw in Rome a couple of years ago, which did a great job of recounting Dali's life and artistic legacy).

Aside from what I expected, this museum (which is not so easy to get to, being in a relatively small city 2 hours from Barcelona) offers a truly splendid, knock-your-socks-off collection of jewelry designed by Dali. Not your usual Tiffany pins and necklaces, each piece was a tour-de-force combining common crystals with precious and semi-precious stones, in whimsical, totally-original settings, such as a spindly elephant, and a set of wings that physically flap. It's worth coming just for the jewels.

In the main museum is a good collection of paintings and a few "real-object sculptures" by Dali. I especially appreciated the Homenage a Lincoln, which starts as a female nude as you see it up close, then dissolves into a recognizable image of Lincoln's head as you move farther away.
titleopinion: THE Dali Museum. A lot of people around the world have assembled Dali works, but I think this is the most representative (except for a temporary exhibit I saw in Rome a couple of years ago, which did a great job of recounting Dali's life and artistic legacy).  Aside from what I expected, this museum (which is not so easy to get to, being in a relatively small city 2 hours from Barcelona) offers a truly splendid, knock-your-socks-off collection of jewelry designed by Dali. Not your usual Tiffany pins and necklaces, each piece was a tour-de-force combining common crystals with precious and semi-precious stones, in whimsical, totally-original settings, such as a spindly elephant, and a set of wings that physically flap. It's worth coming just for the jewels.  In the main museum is a good collection of paintings and a few  real-object sculptures  by Dali. I especially appreciated the Homenage a Lincoln, which starts as a female nude as you see it up close, then dissolves into a recognizable image of Lincoln's head as you move farther away.

reviewnospace:
This museum was like nothing I've seen before. What interested me was that Dali conceived and designed everything in it allowing the visitor to have a glimpse into his world. I also recall reading on the maps that the museum does not and does not wish to have any logical flow, almost as if its keeping you from leaving. However the map will have a recommended route you may take, so that you do not miss anything out. I visited in January 2014 and there was no queue at ticketing, nor hardly any crowd. There were some French student groups though.

I'm not too familiar with Dali's work but this museum and the art in it blew my mind. Particularly the architecture of the place starting with the courtyard with the bizzare installation and the grand hall, we also saw some of his famous pieces in the museum too. The Palace of the Winds room and Mae West room was very interesting as with the entire layout of the museum. His quirkiness could also be seen in the museum's facade, from the statues with baguettes on their heads, to the giant eggs balanced at the top of the facade to its walls being studded with bread rolls. Dali's crypt is also found in this building in the basement.

Its definitely worth the 2 hour train ride from Barcelona and another 2 hours back. The train ride was very comfortable with toilets onboard although it was pretty pricey, at Eur64 per person for a round trip. The museum is about a 15min walk from the Figueres train station and we used Google maps to guide us there.

The only confusing part for us was changing the trains at Sants station (I boarded at Universitat station), particularly when we are non-Catalan/Spanish speaking. Even the signboards with the train timings didn't make sense to me. Here's what you should do. Once you alight at Sants, take the escalator up and exit the gantry. Right beside it is another gated gantry area which you must enter, this leads you to another train platform for the train to Figueres. We had to ask the information booth staff at both areas in order to finally understand where we should be headed. The Figueres train runs hourly.

I also recall reading on the maps that the museum does not and does not wish to have any logical flow, almost as if its keeping you from leaving. Even the signboards with the train timings didn't make sense to me. Here's what you should do. Once you alight at Sants, take the escalator up and exit the gantry. Right beside it is another gated gantry area which you must enter, this leads you to another train platform for the train to Figueres. We had to ask the information booth staff at both areas in order to finally understand where we should be headed. The Figueres train runs hourly.

quote: On A Short Train Ride From Barcelona
reviewnospace: If you are an admirer of Salvador Dali, this is the place to go. The museum is just a short walk from the train station. And keep your ticket stubs after touring the main museum, because a short walk down a side street is where the Dali Jewels are displayed.
titleopinion: On A Short Train Ride From Barcelona. If you are an admirer of Salvador Dali, this is the place to go. The museum is just a short walk from the train station. And keep your ticket stubs after touring the main museum, because a short walk down a side street is where the Dali Jewels are displayed.

reviewnospace:
Got the train from Passeig de Gracia in Barcelona rather than Sants specifically to go to this amazing place. It helps to be a Dali fan, but is not necessary. The architecture of the place is intriguing and I particularly liked the geodesic dome.
The range of his abilities and skill was astounding, from painting and sketches to sculptures and jewellery. Plenty to see, overwhelming really. Some complaints from others about the chaotic layout didn't bother us at all. Just wander and experience and soak it up.

Getting there, some suggestions by others to get a cab from the train station left us in a limbo. I would recommend checking things out a little and if you are reasonably healthy I would walk up. We were there on a Sunday in February, it was quite warm but the town was asleep. No queues to get into the museum. We're pretty sure we were taken on a newbies tour of the town when it was probably a very short trip. We were mislead by another cab driver who took us to the wrong train station (the Rapid station which is on the outskirts of town). We ended up having to walk for about 30 minutes back into town to get to the correct station. A disadvantage of not speaking Spanish and being a stupid tourist. So watch out.
Other than that we had a nice time walking up the hill from the Dali museum to the Castell de Sant Ferran (about 600 or 700 metres) for an amazing view of the surrounding countryside. We didn't go through the fort, although you can for a fee, because we were running out of time.
titleopinion: Wonderful Dali. Got the train from Passeig de Gracia in Barcelona rather than Sants specifically to go to this amazing place. It helps to be a Dali fan, but is not necessary. The architecture of the place is intriguing and I particularly liked the geodesic dome.  The range of his abilities and skill was astounding, from painting and sketches to sculptures and jewellery. Plenty to see, overwhelming really. Some complaints from others about the chaotic layout didn't bother us at all. Just wander and experience and soak it up.  Getting there, some suggestions by others to get a cab from the train station left us in a limbo. I would recommend checking things out a little and if you are reasonably healthy I would walk up. We were there on a Sunday in February, it was quite warm but the town was asleep. No queues to get into the museum. We're pretty sure we were taken on a newbies tour of the town when it was probably a very short trip. We were mislead by another cab driver who took us to the wrong train station (the Rapid station which is on the outskirts of town). We ended up having to walk for about 30 minutes back into town to get to the correct station. A disadvantage of not speaking Spanish and being a stupid tourist. So watch out. Other than that we had a nice time walking up the hill from the Dali museum to the Castell de Sant Ferran (about 600 or 700 metres) for an amazing view of the surrounding countryside. We didn't go through the fort, although you can for a fee, because we were running out of time.

reviewnospace:
We especially made a stopover in Figueres to visit the Dali museum. As an absolute Dali fan it was awe inspiring to travel half way around the world to visit his magnificent museum. Overwhelmed from the first glance at the exterior, the building itself a delight, the largest surrealistic object in the world and a spectacular piece of art in its own right.

The interior houses the vast, diverse collection of Dali's works, spanning throughout his career. This eclectic collection is scattered throughout 22 rooms, not following any particular pattern or chronology, wonderfully surprised and delighted with every twist and turn. You get the opportunity to see a variety of works not displayed anywhere else.

Dali himself said " It will be a totally theatrical museum. The people who come to see it will leave with the sensation of having had a theatrical dream". He more than delivered. We loved every moment of sharing his dream.

Do arrive early in the day if you have not made an online booking. When we visited online bookings were only available for groups or weekend visits so we couldn’t use this option. Queues move quite quickly so not too much of a wait. We enjoyed arriving in Figueres the previous evening so we could have a stroll around and get up early to get to the museum and also enjoy the afternoon and evening in this lovely town.

It’s only just under an hour train ride to Barcelona so if you are a Dali fan, definitely worth stopping over for the night to experience another wonderful Spanish town and get up early to make the most of the museum.

reviewnospace:
We were disappointed. Firstly, the works displayed are not Dali's best; secondly the organisation of the works is rather haphazard, and thirdly there is little information available on on what is displayed. No audio guides are available, the museum booklets contain a plan of the museum but little else, and the contextual information in the galleries is virtually nonexistent.

Try to join a guided tour or do your homework on the museum before going.
titleopinion: Need a guide!. We were disappointed. Firstly, the works displayed are not Dali's best; secondly the organisation of the works is rather haphazard, and thirdly there is little information available on on what is displayed. No audio guides are available, the museum booklets contain a plan of the museum but little else, and the contextual information in the galleries is virtually nonexistent.   Try to join a guided tour or do your homework on the museum before going.

reviewnospace: Whereas not everyone will enjoy Dali I still think its worth a visit for everyone. If not the art you'll be awed by the place especially because Dali has choreographed the whole experience for us. A great day out from Barcelona using the fast trains or a great stop on a drive in the region. The place is a 15 minute walk from the station.
titleopinion: Be prepared to be awed. Whereas not everyone will enjoy Dali I still think its worth a visit for everyone. If not the art you'll be awed by the place especially because Dali has choreographed the whole experience for us. A great day out from Barcelona using the fast trains or a great stop on a drive in the region. The place is a 15 minute walk from the station.

reviewnospace: Well worth a vist - his early works show the man could actually paint and draw rather well! A rather incredible setting, in a theatre that was burned out.
titleopinion: Interesting - especially the early works. Well worth a vist - his early works show the man could actually paint and draw rather well! A rather incredible setting, in a theatre that was burned out.

reviewnospace: This is a great display of Dali. You can take your time and saunter, think and admire Dali. Don't rush you will miss so many Dali mind tricks and treats. My only dislike are the visitors not even looking at the art but putting their tablet cameras in front of the art, taking a picture and walking on ..... What's the point?!
titleopinion: Dali Delight. This is a great display of Dali. You can take your time and saunter, think and admire Dali. Don't rush you will miss so many Dali mind tricks and treats. My only dislike are the visitors not even looking at the art but putting their tablet cameras in front of the art, taking a picture and walking on ..... What's the point?!

reviewnospace: Have never been a disciple of the great man but visited when we hired a car in Lloret de Mar. Around an hours drive and well worth it. Parked on the outskirts of the old town and walked through to the Teatro. The whole town is worth a visit and then the museum takes it to another level. The imagination, humour and artistic skills of the great man are really brought to life. Make sure that you take in all of the floors (and ceilings) to appreciate all the facets of SD including some works which take you on a less humourous journey.

reviewnospace: Great building, fantastic collection, lovely town. All you need for a good day out. If you have any interest at all in art it's a must. Good fun as well and a lot of kids would love it. He had a sense of humour. Really friendly people in Figueres. We had a lovely lunch for 20 Euros for two including drinks.
titleopinion: Wow!. Great building, fantastic collection, lovely town. All you need for a good day out. If you have any interest at all in art it's a must. Good fun as well and a lot of kids would love it. He had a sense of humour. Really friendly people in Figueres. We had a lovely lunch for 20 Euros for two including drinks.

reviewnospace: Driving from France to Barcelona we had to stop in and visit this museum. So well done, the art is right there for all to see and there is so much of it. Modest admission fees. Museum organized nicely so there is a steady stream of viewers and no one place was overcrowded. Plenty of parking nearby. Even if you arr not a Dali fan you will, I think, appreciate this wide spectrum of his work.

Even if you arr not a Dali fan you will, I think, appreciate this wide spectrum of his work.

quote: Not only is it a Museum for Dali's artwork but the museum is art!
reviewnospace:
This place was a theater where Dali had his first exhibit, and the city wanted to put some of his art in a museum, so Dali decided he would rework the whole place and turn it into art!

The buildings is a piece of art and all of the arrangements inside are amazing. All of his creations here make you think and see outside of your comfort zone. It is eye opening and helps you become appreciative of unique and different.

This place is worth your time for a visit.
titleopinion: Not only is it a Museum for Dali's artwork but the museum is art!. This place was a theater where Dali had his first exhibit, and the city wanted to put some of his art in a museum, so Dali decided he would rework the whole place and turn it into art!  The buildings is a piece of art and all of the arrangements inside are amazing. All of his creations here make you think and see outside of your comfort zone. It is eye opening and helps you become appreciative of unique and different.  This place is worth your time for a visit.

reviewnospace: Definitely worth the visit - enjoyed seeing Lincoln!!! There are many groups in December so try to get your tickets very early in the morning.
titleopinion: Delightful. Definitely worth the visit - enjoyed seeing Lincoln!!! There are many groups in December so try to get your tickets very early in the morning.

reviewnospace:
after being in so many basilicas and museums in Italy the Dali museum was a refreshing change and completely worth every dollar and minute/train ride. Dali converted his last residence into a museum. Therefore he set up and staged all the displays, which is completely evident once you start looking around. You can stand in one spot and see art from a distance that looks totally different from a different spot. Also, you find all sorts of abstract art in the oddest place (make sure you look up every now and then).

The final exhibit it the jewelry he made and designed, which is very extravagant and intricate. Totally worth seeing!

Plus you are allowed to take pictures, as many as you want!!

I did this trip in a day from Barcelona, in the summer of 2009, trip advisory wouldn't let me pick 2009 as date visited.
titleopinion: Absolutely Phenomenal. after being in so many basilicas and museums in Italy the Dali museum was a refreshing change and completely worth every dollar and minute/train ride. reviewnospace:
I have visited the museum three years ago!
it was an amazing experience. quite an oppertunity to see Dali's creations beyond the ones femiliar to everybody.
I visited with a group so I was limited to three hours. I was so amazed that the group had to wait for me.
in my opinion you better come independantly and spend there calm time, without stress, taking a rest once in a while and strolling in your own pace!
very recommended!

reviewnospace: It takes over an hour to get a ticket. But we were impressed because of things we saw. I hope to go there one more time.
titleopinion: I was there. It takes over an hour to get a ticket. But we were impressed because of things we saw. I hope to go there one more time.

reviewnospace: This museum is an experience like no other. The ratings on tripadvisor are not exaggerated, this is unique museum which in my opinion has no challengers throughout the world. I'm talking about one artist who is capable of filling a who theater, building wth apparatus, painting, ceiling paintings, jewels, contemporary installations, optical illusions. This man is so excentric and cocky, its really cool. He also doenst care about standard museum conventions, and can you image that this born in 1904 can deliver such a fresh experience. I was stunned for 2 hours, bravo! If you like Dali than hop on the train and GO!(btw dont forget to stop in Girona in the afternoon). About the lines: we went on monday 30 dec 2013 and there was a very small line at 10.30 and no line at all around noon. GO!

reviewnospace: The biggest Dali museum that the man made himself (if I understand everything correctly) is of course great! It's too much and childish and obscene and adoralbe and genius like you would expect from this punk rocker of art :-) Something for everyone who is young and wild at heart!
titleopinion: Fantastic of course!. The biggest Dali museum that the man made himself (if I understand everything correctly) is of course great! It's too much and childish and obscene and adoralbe and genius like you would expect from this punk rocker of art :-) Something for everyone who is young and wild at heart!

quote: Everything the Dali fan would want, and some things you wouldn't
reviewnospace: Dali was an eclectic artist who created a vast amount of work during his lifetime. I have to say that unlike a lot of artists out there most of his work was controversial and a large majority of it has wound up in this museum. There are literally thousands of pieces of his work and if you are a true Dali fan then you need to make the pilgrimage to Figueres and see the museum but this museum is very, very compact and to see everything you have to trove up and down stairs. It's not wheelchair accessible and you enter on one level and have to exit on another, consider it a one way museum from that perspective. The artwork is great, the furniture and other eclectic things only tell visitors what all the other Dali enthusiasts already know, the many was going about 1000 different directions constantly. While you're there see the Jewelry collection which is in another annex on the property and has it's own admission price. The designs of the Jewelry are great especially the classic "Eye of Time."
titleopinion: Everything the Dali fan would want, and some things you wouldn't. Dali was an eclectic artist who created a vast amount of work during his lifetime. reviewnospace: The Dali Theatre-Museum & Dali-Jewels pay the visit to this nice town, easily reached by train from Barcelona (Sants station). The restaurant of Duran Hotel is intersting, Dali himself used to go there with his wife and muse.
titleopinion: Dali in his hometown. The Dali Theatre-Museum & Dali-Jewels pay the visit to this nice town, easily reached by train from Barcelona (Sants station). The restaurant of Duran Hotel is intersting, Dali himself used to go there with his wife and muse.

reviewnospace: Well worth the time and journey out from Barcelona to see so much of Dali's art the way he intended it to be seen. The museum is a "feast for the senses" with so much to see, touch and take in. A great alternative for kids from a traditional museum as so much of the art is interactive. Don't miss the jewel exhibit, some of the most spectacular pieces of art. I highly recommend the museum.
titleopinion: Sensory overload!. Well worth the time and journey out from Barcelona to see so much of Dali's art the way he intended it to be seen. The museum is a  feast for the senses  with so much to see, touch and take in. A great alternative for kids from a traditional museum as so much of the art is interactive. Don't miss the jewel exhibit, some of the most spectacular pieces of art. I highly recommend the museum.

reviewnospace: Such an artistic genius. The museum itself is laid out nicely. It give you a really nice insight and display of his work without being overwhelming. You can easily enjoy it in a couple of hours.
titleopinion: IT should be an 11!. Such an artistic genius. The museum itself is laid out nicely. It give you a really nice insight and display of his work without being overwhelming. You can easily enjoy it in a couple of hours.

quote: The place you have to visit before you die!!
reviewnospace: For people who do not know who Salvador Dali is it will be interesting and exciting experience. But for SD fans its like a visit to heaven. The most unusual and one of the best museums I ever visit. You can understand and appriciate Dali even more after you visit museum. I suggest to stay in Figueros for 2-3 days and visit it twice!

reviewnospace: Brilliant - go early to avoid people taking selfies @ fat maiden. Jewellery expo in 2nd building awesome.
titleopinion: Dali .... Brilliant - go early to avoid people taking selfies @ fat maiden. Jewellery expo in 2nd building awesome.

reviewnospace: Although many on TripAdvisor advised that we'd better not go, we decided to see for ourselves anyway. I'm so glad we did! We went on a Wednesday afternoon medio december, and we had all the time and space to really take every work in. True, it's chaotic, and there is very little information available, but still I left inspired. A lot of Dali's art doesn't lend itself for too much explanation in my humble opinion... There were just a few visitors in the entire building, so we could enjoy fully. For me, it was worth every penny!
titleopinion: Bijzondere ervaring!. Although many on TripAdvisor advised that we'd better not go, we decided to see for ourselves anyway. I'm so glad we did! quote: Worth the wait - be sure to hit the upper levels
reviewnospace: Really neat museum. You'll likely have to wait a bit to get in but totally worth it. Make sure you make it up to the upper floors to check out some of Dali's lesser known styles (eg the rock figures).
titleopinion: Worth the wait - be sure to hit the upper levels. Really neat museum. You'll likely have to wait a bit to get in but totally worth it. Make sure you make it up to the upper floors to check out some of Dali's lesser known styles (eg the rock figures).

quote: Can't imagine someone not enjoying it
reviewnospace: I am not a huge 'art museum' fan. But this is no ordinary art museum. The collection and variety contained in these walls is amazing. It's probably one of the top 10 museums I've ever been in. He was a genius - his work was so creative, interesting, and covered so many different mediums. It's not like looking at the same thing over and over again. Not only that, but many things had so much going on in them, you could spend hours and not see everything. There are pictures within pictures. Dali designed this museum and he is buried there. Oh, and Don't miss the jewelry exhibit, the designs, the details and the materials are incredible. Just go.
titleopinion: Can't imagine someone not enjoying it. I am not a huge 'art museum' fan. But this is no ordinary art museum. The collection and variety contained in these walls is amazing. It's probably one of the top 10 museums I've ever been in. He was a genius - his work was so creative, interesting, and covered so many different mediums. It's not like looking at the same thing over and over again. Not only that, but many things had so much going on in them, you could spend hours and not see everything. There are pictures within pictures. Dali designed this museum and he is buried there. Oh, and Don't miss the jewelry exhibit, the designs, the details and the materials are incredible. Just go.

reviewnospace: The Dalí Theatre-Museum is a lovely museum, be sure to have plenty of time in order to stroll around the museum and have time to experience everything as things may not be what you think it is at your first glance.
titleopinion: A lovely museum. The Dalí Theatre-Museum is a lovely museum, be sure to have plenty of time in order to stroll around the museum and have time to experience everything as things may not be what you think it is at your first glance.

reviewnospace: One of the most unusual and interesting museums one can visit. From the moment you enter you taken aback by how this museum is different from just about another. The museum is located in Figueras, Dali's home town, which about two hours away from Barcelona by train. Dali was instrumental in building the teatro-museum and the placement of all the artwork. Each floor captured something different, from the bedroom exhibit to the Aliyah exhibit, dedicated to the holocaust an Israel to his statute of Moses. If you are a Dali fan this is a must if you have time when you are in Barcelona.
titleopinion: Dali theater. One of the most unusual and interesting museums one can visit. From the moment you enter you taken aback by how this museum is different from just about another. The museum is located in Figueras, Dali's home town, which about two hours away from Barcelona by train. Dali was instrumental in building the teatro-museum and the placement of all the artwork. Each floor captured something different, from the bedroom exhibit to the Aliyah exhibit, dedicated to the holocaust an Israel to his statute of Moses. If you are a Dali fan this is a must if you have time when you are in Barcelona.

reviewnospace: I have been a huge Salvador Dali fan for as long as I can remember, and this place has been on the top of my "Must-See" list for a very long time. I wanted to go last year when I came, but three days was not long enough to squeeze in a visit to Figueres. This year, my friend and I boarded the AVE train from Barcelona-Sants to Figueres Vilafant. We took a taxi (about 10€) and were delivered to the museum. It did not disappoint from the moment we turned the corner until we finally got directions to get a return taxi to Vilafant. The museum is a bit of a complicated maze -- I'm not convinced that we saw everything that was there to see -- but every piece of art along the way was magnificent. A tour through the Jewel museum attached to the actual museum was also worth it. At 12€, it was definitely a steal for any art fan, and especially those fans of the works of Salvador Dali.

reviewnospace: I was there for 2,5 hours, taking the time to take it all in. There was so much to see! The building it self is strange but wonderfull, coming thru the entrance...wow! The paintings, pictures, murals, painted ceilings, there is so much to see. The bedroom is over the top but amazing. I hope one day to back and see it al again.

reviewnospace: If you are into Dali-this is the place for you. A converted museum this is a wonderful tribute to the extravagance of Dali. There are many installations and mind-blowing artwork. A portrait of Dali's wife which, from a certain distance, transforms into the outline of Abraham Lincoln. Don't miss the adjacent Dali Jewels museum-fantastic, inventive jewelery designed by him.
titleopinion: Surreal wonder. If you are into Dali-this is the place for you. A converted museum this is a wonderful tribute to the extravagance of Dali. There are many installations and mind-blowing artwork. A portrait of Dali's wife which, from a certain distance, transforms into the outline of Abraham Lincoln. reviewnospace:
This museum is first class! It shows so many interesting pieces from Dalí and other artists as well. The first floor exhibits some very thought provoking drawings by Dalí where you can follow his imagination witch later became paintings. One room shows the progression and development of Dalí as an artist and how Picasso influenced him. There is much more on the two other floors, for example some very interesting works by Antoni Pitxot.
You will need a few hours to see everything and have time for reflection. The museum is quite narrow and gets crowded by noon, so a good idea is to spend the night before your visit in Figueres.

reviewnospace: This was such an amazing experience and would have made the trip to Figeures worth while even if we did nothing else here. It really does have something that appeals to everyone, even if you are not particularly an art lover. Definitely a highlight of our trip to Spain.

It really does have something that appeals to everyone, even if you are not particularly an art lover. Definitely a highlight of our trip to Spain.

reviewnospace: This museum is the gift of Dali for his homeland town. Museum contains exclusive original paintings and instalations of Master. Of course need to hire a good guide, because the art of Dali is secrets and simbols. Try to visit not in the summer (museum is very crowded).

reviewnospace:
I drove out of my way to go here - and was certainly not dissapointed. There is so much to see from interesting to thought provoking through to imaginative and just confusing! The whole place is a bit of a maze as well so you can really feel like you're discovering new things at every turn - exactly as Dali intended.

There were tours available, though we didn't get one and I don't think we missed anything. The museum can get quite busy so be prepared to wait to see some exhibits - your patience will be rewarded!

I would reccommend this to anyone - art lover or not! It's got a real imposing feeling to it and you get a really good understanding of Dali and the massive diversity of his art.

Though just as a side note if you have small children they don't allow buggies in.

reviewnospace: "Dali, the Flamboyant Surrealist" describes this museum very well. A read of Salvador Dali in Wikipedia would be well advised before entry. All of the pieces are interesting some impossible to make head or tail of.

reviewnospace:
This is an amazing museum created to Dali's specification, so you know you're in for a treat.

He might have been a shameless self-promoter, but he was also an astonishing genius and this museum gives a greater insight into his phenomenal skill as an artist and his ability to surprise and intrigue with his work.

I got a terrible fright when I belatedly went to the museum's website and it said that it was sold out - but it turned out that was just for guided tours... So we didn't have a guide, which may have been interesting, but certainly is not essential.

I recommend also heading to his house for a tour, it's not too far (37km, but the road is very windy) and it felt like it completed the picture of the amazing man.

quote: An interesting visit for Dali lovers!
reviewnospace:
We took to the Dali Theatre Museum as part of a guided excursion from the Thomson Dream
It took one hour to get there from Palamos and it was well worth it!
My wife loves the work of Dali and to see the building itself was great!
But inside, original works of art and an exhibition that took 2 hours to see if we kept on moving!
Make sure you see this if you are in the area!

reviewnospace:
Whether or not you are a Dali fan, or not even an art appreciator you should visit this intriguing place. We were astonished at Dali's wide variety of art styles. Best known for his melting clock faces, we were amazed to see that he was also a fantastic conventional artist. We also thoroughly enjoyed his whackier pictures and creations which are well represented in this ex-theatre which he turned into a museum. We spent over 3 hours there and it seemed like just minutes, and would have spent longer if we had not been on a coach trip.
It is great that you take photos of everything (without flash) so we have hundreds of photos to enable us to enjoy the artwork again at home at our leisure.
Arrive as early as you can to avoid the crowds.
It's a unique experience - do try it.

quote: A must-see not only for Dali fans
reviewnospace:
This Museum is much more than a museum, it truly is a phantasmagorical theater experience. Everything is there for a reason and the whole visit felt like solving some kind of a giant riddle. We planned to spend about 2 hours in this museum but spent over 4, and felt like we could spend a whole day there. If you can, try to do some homework on Dali before visiting this museum in terms of his biography and art, his symbolism and concepts, it would help you make sense of what you see inside.

TIPS:
1) the many coin-operated machines in the museum are not a prank, they really work. Come with 1-euro coins and deposit them in the slots, you will be rewarded with very interesting tricks designed by Dali.
2) Some of the simple woven chairs in the museum are placed strategically and, if you seat on them, will offer some very interesting view angles.
3) If you can, go to Dali house-museum in Port Lligat first, many things in the museum make more sense after you have seen Dali's house.
4) Spend time in the entry courtyard, it is full of interesting concepts and details there for a reason, and afterwards be sure to walk around the building and see the squares designed by Dali. Even the museum gift shop outside was also designed by Dali.
5) The most important one: Do not rush! You will miss the whole experience if you do.

reviewnospace: I definitely recommend taking a trip here especially if you are visiting Barcelona. We took a regional train from Passeig de Gracia station to the Figueres station which took less than 2 hours. It was 30 € for the round trip. From there, it took us about 15 minutes to walk to the museum. We arrived 3 hours before closing and there was still a 25 minute line to enter. The entry fee for the general public was 12 €, while admission for students was 9 €. Admission includes entry into the jewels exhibition. Although it was packed when we first entered, there were alot less people during the last hour and a half before closing which made it easier to appreciate the art from up close. I highly recommend spending a few hours here! :)

reviewnospace: This museum is definitely one of the most unique you will ever visit! An amazing collection of Dali's works as well as some other artists. I visited knowing a little bit about Dali, but left with a couple of books about him because the museum left you wanting to know more and to know what he was thinking when he created some of these surreal pieces. It was also cool to know that Dali helped design and create the museum himself. We visited on a Thursday morning and the only negative I have to say is that the museum was so crowded with tour groups it was difficult for us as a couple to get around them and get an up close view of some of the pieces. I don't know if there would be a day with less tour groups but if there is, visit then!

quote: Best part of our Barcelona trip

titleopinion: Best part of our Barcelona trip. Don't miss this. Both kids and adults will love this museum. Take the train from Barcelona. It is amazing!!!!

reviewnospace:
As a huge Dali fan, this was a dream trip come true. For my partner, who want a fan, it was still a great day at the museum. Great history and examples of Dali abs other artists work on show and the building itself is awe inspiring.

One tip ... Don't use the directions feature on the Android trip advisor app to take you there from the train station. The address on the listing is correct but the marker on the map is wrong and it will take you over 1km in the opposite direction to where the museum is! Follow the signs from the station and they will take you there, or use the address to guide you, just don't use the app directions!

reviewnospace: Most of my museum visits do not end up with a great review. This museum was different. The artist allows you to be yourself. He has amazing art that lets your imagination free. Like the other artist who try to show you what they want you to see through their eyes, Dali does an amazing job at allowing us to see for ourselves. The museum had some great pieces of art and I really enjoyed my time there. Only reason I did not give it full 5 stars is because I found it a bit too crowded. Dont really enjoying someone jumping in front of my face to take a picture of the art even before they had a chance to look at it . A must visit in Figueres. p.s. there is much more to do in the city and enjoy besides just the Dali museum.

reviewnospace:
We went to Figueres as a return train trip from Barcelona. It's less than an hour from Barcelona Sants on a train that reaches over 250kph. (Don't know the cost - we used a day of our Rail Pass.)

The Dali Theatre-Museum is great - a wonderful setting to let Dali's playfulness come out with his seriousness already known from his 1930-1950s art in particular.

Dali has used a large space to present large objects and large-scale arrangements. He also uses a labyrinth of rooms for smaller pieces and a spectacular grand room with adjoining rooms for some of the most interesting works there.

For those who are hoping to see Dali's most totemic works en masse, you will not find that anywhere unless you see a specially arranged major retrospective. Certainly there is some excellent work here, but Dali's best works are widely spread and only a small number are here. But if you want to learn about Dali's work - his diversity of ideas and media - this is a very good place to do it. Some of the rooms are small and it can get crowded. There are also several flights of stairs - not sure how it goes for people who need an elevator - there are no ramps.

You can walk (about 1.5km) or taxi from the station to the Dali Theatre-Museum. Walking both ways was fine but there was little in the town to engage us. We found a pleasant and affordable spot for food near the entrance to the museum.

For those who are hoping to see Dali's most totemic works en masse, you will not find that anywhere unless you see a specially arranged major retrospective. reviewnospace: Figueres makes for a terrific day-trip out of Barcelona, and if you go, don't miss the Dali Museum. It's the largest collection of art by a single artist that I've ever seen housed in a single building, but it's all fun and quirky art -- unusual enough to entertain even a novice art enthusiast.

reviewnospace: We visited this museum to see the breath of work by Dali- some strange but interesting. No audioguide was available, so do get a map as you go in or you will be confused. All rooms are numbered. The highlight for us was the smaller Jewellery museum which is included in the entry ticket. We caught the train from Barcelona Passeig de gracia staiton- this is not connected to the underground at present so go to street level and look for the temporary ticket office that is located on a street corner a block in from Passeig de gracia and over the steps that take you down to the station. There are two different trains, one takes 1 hr 45 min, the other 2 hr 11 min, so check your times. Figueres is a lovely town to walk in and if you cross the small park in front of the station building you will signs to the museum.

reviewnospace: Its probably 2 hours trip by bus or train from Barcelona each way. Please be aware that the trains go from the North subway L1, parada Arc de Triomf, station and not for Barcelona Sants. They are middle distance (MD) trains most of them, not as fast as the AVE, but most times this last is totally booked and only leave early and in the morning and late in the afternoon. Instead the MD run every hour in each direction (you can find out the specific time if you go to the renfe website). Be aware that if you take the bus, is cheaper of you take a Girona bus and then pay the local 20 minutes drive in the same bus, from Girona to Figueras. You need a minimum of 3 hours in this museum, so it takes you the whole day this adventure. There is also the horse of Dali than is not fay (around 13km), but you should add another 3 hours to your experience. Totally worth it to see this genius!

quote: Brilliant, fun and eccentric - just like the artist himself
reviewnospace:
The Salvador Dali Museum is an excellent insight into the man. I knew little about him before I went but accompanied my wife on something she wanted 'to do' while in Europe. In that time, I learnt a lot about the man, his wife and his life. If you're an Savlidor Dali fan, you'll love it. If you dont know much about Salvidor Dali (like me) then you'll have a good time and learn something about a very eccentric yet influential artist.

It takes at least a couple of hours to see the museum so leave yourself plenty of time, especially if you're a fan. The excrement shapes on the outside of the museum don't reflect whats inside !!

reviewnospace:
This is a magic house where nearly every detail is made or used in a bizarre, surrealistic way. There you'll find bags and chairs on the ceiling, raining car, entrance in the form of a mouth and, of course, the famous "interior face". Some pieces of Dali's art start moving with a euro or 20-cent coin, so it is really like a theatre.
A must-visit place for everyone who is interested in art.

There you'll find bags and chairs on the ceiling, raining car, entrance in the form of a mouth and, of course, the famous  interior face . Some pieces of Dali's art start moving with a euro or 20-cent coin, so it is really like a theatre. A must-visit place for everyone who is interested in art.

reviewnospace:
Long train ride from Barcelona to Figueres but the trains are clean, no graffitti, air conditioned and on time unlike in Italy. Once there it is a good 15 minute walk thru the town which was extremely well signed. You can not miss this outrageous piece of architecture and the entrance alone gets you excited about what lies behind the door.
Art work from most of Dali's fazes are there in all there glory the building that houses it also becomes part of the art. Take your time to meander from room to room study the works and they will take on a different appearance with minutes. What a art livers heaven. Definitely a must see.

location: Palos Verdes Estates, California, United States
reviewnospace: I've been to Dali's museum five times and it never ceases to amaze me. I love watching my students as they try to absorb the artistic and architectural creativity that surrounds them there. It's a very unique experience and you should allow yourself a day away from Barcelona to take it in. Their guides are quite good if you can arrange a group tour ahead of time.

I love watching my students as they try to absorb the artistic and architectural creativity that surrounds them there. It's a very unique experience and you should allow yourself a day away from Barcelona to take it in. Their guides are quite good if you can arrange a group tour ahead of time.

reviewnospace: We went with high expectations and were not disappointed. In September we were able to walk straight in but I have heard from friends that queues in high season can be long, so arrive early!
titleopinion: Fantastic. We went with high expectations and were not disappointed. In September we were able to walk straight in but I have heard from friends that queues in high season can be long, so arrive early!

reviewnospace: if you are visiting barcelona make sure you save a day to visit dalis museum..its really worth it.the museum it self is not huge but it hold lots of his unknown art. Have in mind that the q is huge one,so be patient!

reviewnospace: Felt like being whisked into someone else's dreamworld! Stunning variety of paintings, installations, miniatures and massive sets inspired by icons such as Mae West. Beautifully laid out and designed, no bossy signs insisting on set routes, and Figueres is a smart, pedestrian friendly town with some great shopping. Much easier to handle than Barcelona!
titleopinion: Out of this world. Felt like being whisked into someone else's dreamworld! Stunning variety of paintings, installations, miniatures and massive sets inspired by icons such as Mae West. Beautifully laid out and designed, no bossy signs insisting on set routes, and Figueres is a smart, pedestrian friendly town with some great shopping. Much easier to handle than Barcelona!

reviewnospace: This museum is bonkers, beautiful, and brilliant. It's great from the outside, with eggs and odd statues. Inside, the atrium is simply spectacular and the works of art range from other-worldy, to humorous, to just plain beautiful. Dali built this museum from the ruins of a theatre, and he did a damned fine job. Do NOT miss the jewellery collection in the museum outside the exit (entry included in the main ticket) - it's absolutely fantastic. Sorry. I have run out of adjectives for AMAZING. Just go. Now.

quote: Don't miss if you love Dali!
reviewnospace: We took the train, about 2 hours each way. Very easy and delightful way to see some countryside. Figueres is a very cute town and the museum is walking distance from the train station, about 20 minutes. Don't miss the Dali jewels..
titleopinion: Don't miss if you love Dali!. We took the train, about 2 hours each way. Very easy and delightful way to see some countryside. Figueres is a very cute town and the museum is walking distance from the train station, about 20 minutes. Don't miss the Dali jewels..

quote: Loved the place but too many tourists!
reviewnospace: The museum is stunning and a tribute to Dali throughout his life. Well set out across many rooms, although sometimes a little difficult to climb the staircases and meander through the tight corridors. Worth the effort to see this amazing work on display. The downside is its popularity and the fact there are so many tourists visiting. My advice would be to go very early or do an evening tour with the eerie lighting. Miss the crowds as much as possible, or otherwise you will not get the space to appreciate all the beautiful work.

Miss the crowds as much as possible, or otherwise you will not get the space to appreciate all the beautiful work.

quote: Go later, no lines and a better experience
reviewnospace: Ok so here is my trick and I have done it at the Vatican and elsewhere. Go later. Find out how long it takes and time it. I walked right into the museum at 4:30 - no line at all. It closed at 7:00pm. Again there was no line at all. Not only that I could very freely move through the museum with no traffic jams at stairs and smaller rooms. The various rooms are all numbered so there is some rhyme or reason to this place. Dali was a bizarre man who saw the world in a very strange way so enjoy it. Don't forget to look up and in all directions because there is stuff everywhere. I can understand it is not for everyone but I think considering his relevance to the art world it is a must. I agree with the previous review that noted there was no interpretive materials. I had a hard time trying to figure out the year of some of his work I was less familiar with. That said the book stores and the Internet can answer all your questions. No interpretive panels likely means that the flow of people is faster. The museum, as they said, took me one and half hours. I was not fast or particularly slow. Do go, Dali was an icon. Just go at the end of the day when the tours are finished you will enjoy the experience.

reviewnospace: Great town, fun museum. Go early-at 0900 when they open or 1700-you'll have plenty of time before they close. At 1700, the tour busses are gone. You also get to see jewels he designed as well. You may shake your head at some of the stuff, but like I said-it's fun. Another neat thing to do in this town is to take the audio guided tour of the fortress. We walked to the fortress in the cool of the morning and saw the Dali in the late afternoon.

Another neat thing to do in this town is to take the audio guided tour of the fortress. We walked to the fortress in the cool of the morning and saw the Dali in the late afternoon.

reviewnospace: I recenty spent 7 fantastic days in Barcelona. Anyone who has been there will attest to the endless cultural activities, architectural and historical sites and outstanding restaurants that Barca has to offer. That being said, I could not have been more disappointed with the Salvador Dali Theater Museum, which is noted as the 2nd most visited museum in all of Spain! (How this could be true, is completely baffling to me.) Thankfully, another reviewer had warned our group of the long lines and we made the effort to get to the museum when it opened. An hour later, the narrow halls of this maze of a building were crowded to the point of critical mass. Had we arrived at 11, the wait to get in would have easily been 2 hours, maybe more. My disappointment stems from the complete lack of seriousness, scholarship or historical relevance paid to the legacy of this master in this institution. There are no educational materials provided to the visitor whatsoever. There is no rhyme or reason to the installation and the collection, while it does have a handful of interesting early works, most of it resembles a circus fun house. It is in my opinion that the basic tenants of Surrealism, as was stated on the one map of the building, allows for this intended confusion is completely false. I was so sorry I wasted the better part of a day visiting this place. In addition, the town of Figures is nothing to go out of one's way for. With so much incredible art and architecture in Barcelona, I would warn anyone interested in culture to spend your time doing other things there rather then spending anytime visiting the Dali Theater Museum in Figures.

(How this could be true, is completely baffling to me.) Thankfully, another reviewer had warned our group of the long lines and we made the effort to get to the museum when it opened. An hour later, the narrow halls of this maze of a building were crowded to the point of critical mass. Had we arrived at 11, the wait to get in would have easily been 2 hours, maybe more. My disappointment stems from the complete lack of seriousness, scholarship or historical relevance paid to the legacy of this master in this institution. There are no educational materials provided to the visitor whatsoever. There is no rhyme or reason to the installation and the collection, while it does have a handful of interesting early works, most of it resembles a circus fun house. It is in my opinion that the basic tenants of Surrealism, as was stated on the one map of the building, allows for this intended confusion is completely false. I was so sorry I wasted the better part of a day visiting this place. In addition, the town of Figures is nothing to go out of one's way for. With so much incredible art and architecture in Barcelona, I would warn anyone interested in culture to spend your time doing other things there rather then spending anytime visiting the Dali Theater Museum in Figures.

reviewnospace: Totally entertaining! Amazed by the wonderful world of the surreal ......well worth a visit for any age! Do prepare to stand in line for a ticket. But definitely worth the wait. Don't forget to also see the jewelry Dali created. Not your run of the mill stuff for sure.

quote: Dali Museum is Not for Everybody
reviewnospace:
I love art and just assumed I would love the Dali Museum. There were people oohing and aahing and carrying on, so there were people who loved it. First of all, it is very crowded. Secondly, the building is really just an old run-down theather building. If you don't love Dali's art, there is just nothing great about it. I really did enjoy the new building with his jewelry though. The jewelry was creative and exquisite. We were on a tour that took hours to view the building. The day was very cold and rainy. I was in and out in probably less than an hour. I took refuge in a local tapas place and enjoyed the tapas, quite tasty.
All I can say if you are not a Dali fan, you may not find this museum to your liking. I definitely was disappointed in the experience.

All I can say if you are not a Dali fan, you may not find this museum to your liking. I definitely was disappointed in the experience.

quote: Loved the Jewels exhibition, hated the museum
reviewnospace:
I'm only giving this 2 stars because of the Jewels exhibition - something you could easily miss but is absolutely superb and very unusual.

The theatre-museum itself was a huge disappointment. I'm really interested in Dali and have been to exhibitions dedicated to him in Paris, London and Singapore. I had high expectations coming to his hometown and resting place and the glowing reviews only added to that. What I hated about the place:
- tiny corridors crammed with people
- not a single line of commentary, explanation or insight on any of the works, rooms or installations. No guides or audio guides. Nothing about Dali himself
- no thought given to display or arrangement of the works. Most of them you can't see all that well due to lighting and positioning.
- very few "iconic" works - it's mostly sketches and small-ish drawings which, although interesting, are not as "finished" or "accomplished". The fact that there are entire grim corridors of them lined up takes away their individuality too.
- odd exhibtions by other artists at random places. Here too no explanation is given (you actually need to search pretty carefully to even find the name of the artist) and you don't really know what you've stumbled upon
- dumb layout means you wander to the end of a (tiny, cramped) corridor and have to turn back amidst the crowd

I could go on, but you get the idea. It's also not very well connected to Barcelona and tickets sell out online over a week before the date in summer. There is only one cashier at the ticket office so queues are long (and not shaded). Regarding trains: we took the high-speed from Barcelona Sants to Figueres Alifant and then had to pay 10 EUR of taxi to get to the museum.

It's an expensive, frustrating day out and not worth the trouble.

A must see for everyone but especially art enthusiasts!

quote: Go early and you will have a great time. You can always have a siesta later!
reviewnospace:
Showed up at 8:45. Already 15 people in line but basically before the museum fills up it moves fast. The walk from the high speed station is easy. Neighbourhood seems a bit dodgy but during the day not a problem. Free shuttle but not clearly marked. We couldn't see it.

The line at 10:15 looked about 20 minutes long. By 11:00 maybe an hour and a half. By 12:00 onwards just forget about it. I've never seen a line so long before and they let people in a lot slower once the museum is full.

Wake up early. Have the museum to yourself and have the rest of the day free.

The small attractions you needed 20c, 50c and we saw one for 1euro. Or just wait for others to use them.

They only sell advanced tickets for groups during the day. Individuals they do night ones after 5pm.

The jewellery museum is absolutely stunning, it's included in the price don't miss it.

Apparently Dali didn't want people to use guides. Just go in and interpret what you can. Enjoy. Just note not all his most famous works are located here. And things aren't set out in chronological order like the worldwide exhibition that toured a few years ago.

quote: Brilliant museum, had our eyes looking around, up & over.

Even though we pre-booked tickets for an afternoon slot, more tickets were being sold at the door, so as many people have said, it does get crowded but we went against traffic & thoroughly enjoyed the museum & what was presented.

location: Brecon Beacons National Park, United Kingdom
quote: Go early on Sunday to escape the queues!
reviewnospace: We were a little concerned after reading the reviews so planned to arrive at 8:30 on Sunday.The museum opens at 9:00.We were first in line to our surprise! It wasn't long before the place filled up and large queues were outside.We stayed until after 13:00 and there were still queues. There is parking to the rear of the museum, cost €0.042 per minute, so this was €17. The museum was superb entertainment even for usually non converted surrealists. A must visit.

Add to that 45mins - 1 hr to queue in the heat and I all in all a disappointing experience.
A guided tour would be better but it does get busy and could be hard to hear the guide.

quote: monty python meets disney meets pink floyd
reviewnospace: This has to the wackiest most fun museum you can ever visit anywhere on earth, the universe, the galaxy and the cosmos. The best way to see it is probably go with a group tour so you do not wait in what looks like an interminable queue. Once inside you are for a treat. Whether you are an art lover or not whether you like Dali or Surrealism this is a weird wacky and totally hilarious place to visit. It will take about two hours to get around unless you have extremely sharp elbows. You will have to wait in line at some of the rooms and exhibits but it is well worth waiting.
