Once you exit for the main art building you have to go around the corner and into another door. It is was worth finding it ( and it wasn't too hard to find, just ask the security at the exit of the art museum).  I tool the train in from Barcelona. The travel time was 2 hours each way and cost 30€ round trip. From the station it's about a 15 minute walk. It easy to find just follow the signs.

reviewnospace: Dali at his best: full of himself but still excellent! I really enjoyed the visit. It is enormous and rather long, especially if you stop at all details like I did. I really did not like the series of paintings with stones and actually I am not super fond of Dali in general, just like him a bit. However I think the space is wonderful and totally worth a visit. The central area/stage/dome are very impressinve. It was a great visit. There are no explanations for anything. This is what Dali himself instructed. Just look and enjoy!
titleopinion: not doubt: it is 100% Dali. Dali at his best: full of himself but still excellent! I really enjoyed the visit. It is enormous and rather long, especially if you stop at all details like I did. I really did not like the series of paintings with stones and actually I am not super fond of Dali in general, just like him a bit. However I think the space is wonderful and totally worth a visit. The central area/stage/dome are very impressinve. It was a great visit. There are no explanations for anything. This is what Dali himself instructed. Just look and enjoy!

quote: Non stop fun. This man was an inspiring individual.
reviewnospace: Follow the route on you entry brochure. Look closely at each peace from different angles. Don't skip anything. Its all great.
titleopinion: Non stop fun. This man was an inspiring individual.. Follow the route on you entry brochure. Look closely at each peace from different angles. Don't skip anything. Its all great.

quote: Good visiting in an inclement day.
reviewnospace:
Not ordinary and very varied museum.
Don't miss the optic illusions room, and the jewelery museum.
We waited 30 minutes in the queue to enter and the museum was full with visitors, so be prepared.
titleopinion: Good visiting in an inclement day.. Not ordinary and very varied museum. Don't miss the optic illusions room, and the jewelery museum. We waited 30 minutes in the queue to enter and the museum was full with visitors, so be prepared.

reviewnospace:
A visit to the Dali theatre museum is worth the trip from Barcelona. We caught the train which took under 2 hours and then a 15 min walk following the signs takes you to the old theatre which houses the museum. There is an abundance of Dali works with lots of crazy stuff, amazing sketches and portraits. The jewellery is just magnificent and well displayed, you need to enter a separate building once out of the main museum to see.
The town has tiny narrow streets and lots of cages to cater for all the tourists.
titleopinion: Dali. A visit to the Dali theatre museum is worth the trip from Barcelona. We caught the train which took under 2 hours and then a 15 min walk following the signs takes you to the old theatre which houses the museum. There is an abundance of Dali works with lots of crazy stuff, amazing sketches and portraits. The jewellery is just magnificent and well displayed, you need to enter a separate building once out of the main museum to see.  The town has tiny narrow streets and lots of cages to cater for all the tourists.

reviewnospace: My wife and I spent about an hour and a half exploring the art of Dali at this wonderful museum. We arrived at close to opening time but unfortunately so did several large school groups, so our visiting was somewhat marred by rude and ignorant children who were just there to tick boxes on their school project. Aside from the children, this was a great experience. The building itself is amazing, as are the works by Dali.
titleopinion: Thoroughly enjoyable. My wife and I spent about an hour and a half exploring the art of Dali at this wonderful museum. reviewnospace: If you dont like Dali you will find this theatre/ museum weird and probably think its utter madness. If you appreciate Dali's art from when he started as a young boy and carried on through his lifetime doing more and more surreal art and paintings you will get a very good interpretation of his art throughout his life! Its a long way from Barcelona but you can go via a couple of trains and not very expensive. You are greeted by a stack of televisions with broken screens outside the museum/theatre stuffed with dolls and that is for starters. You work your way around the museum which is very well sign posted and it has to be as there is SO MUCH to see you could miss! You go and up and up the staircase and visit all the floors and from the top you can see the bottom floor which looks like an open air patio. The walls are draped with his most magnificent art work modern and classical and in the centre is the masterpiece...a gansters car from the 1950's with lifesize dolls in the car holding brollies as its raining on the car and there is no roof to the car. This is real water cascading down on the car. There are so many weird and wonderful things to look at in the museum its a must if you are a fan of Dali, you will not be disappointed but you need lots of time for the visit a good 2 hours or more!

reviewnospace:
We went with a Catalania Tours trip. (Our excellent guide, Geordie, was not allowed in which is standard practice).
The whole museum (With the exception of one floor that has some work by another, inferior, artist) gives a range of experiences with the work of this weird, but incredibly talented, man.
He worked in a full range of mediums - nowadays we would say a multi-media experience.
Probably the best example of this is the Mae West room.
We added to the experience by visiting the Dali jewellery exibition next door.
I reccomend it to anyone with any interest in art - and an open mind.

quote: Packed with People But Still Worth a Visit
reviewnospace:
I visited the museum recently, and it was packed with people. I have also been to Dalí's house in Port Lligat. I wish people had to make reservations to enter this site in Figueres in the same way they do in Port Lligat. It is so crowded and hard to enjoy the space. I wanted to go back to revisit some paintings from the beginning of my visit, and I had to fight my way through a group tour in the corridor. They were stopped and listening to their guide, completely blocking traffic. Another thing to consider would be to only allow group tours at certain times of the day. I know this is limiting, but I'd rather pay a bit more money and actually enjoy my time there than deal with a mad rush of people. I cannot imagine what this place is like in the summer time.

Despite the crowds, I think the museum is definitely worth a visit and recommend it to all of my guests. I love how the museum is interactive and displays a great variety of Dalí's work. Be sure to check out the basket of bread painting (my favorite) and read more about Dalí's description of it in the guidebook or online. Stop to appreciate the painting "Enigmatic Elements in a Landscape" which is the most expensive painting the foundation has ever acquired. And definitely save 20 or 30 minutes to visit the jewelry collection which you will find through the entrance on the corner of the building facing Salvador Dalí. The beating heart is creepy and a delight at the same time.

I can appreciate the museum on another level because Dalí actually had a say in the design of the place himself. The building was in ruins after bombing during the Spanish Civil War when Dalí and the mayor worked together to reconstruct the place.

I recommend a visit, but just be prepared for the crowds! If you don't want to purchase a guidebook for the museum, I recommend doing a little research online about some of the paintings in the collection before you go.

They were stopped and listening to their guide, completely blocking traffic. Another thing to consider would be to only allow group tours at certain times of the day. Despite the crowds, I think the museum is definitely worth a visit and recommend it to all of my guests. I love how the museum is interactive and displays a great variety of Dalí's work. Be sure to check out the basket of bread painting (my favorite) and read more about Dalí's description of it in the guidebook or online. Stop to appreciate the painting  Enigmatic Elements in a Landscape  which is the most expensive painting the foundation has ever acquired. And definitely save 20 or 30 minutes to visit the jewelry collection which you will find through the entrance on the corner of the building facing Salvador Dalí. The beating heart is creepy and a delight at the same time.   I can appreciate the museum on another level because Dalí actually had a say in the design of the place himself. The building was in ruins after bombing during the Spanish Civil War when Dalí and the mayor worked together to reconstruct the place.  I recommend a visit, but just be prepared for the crowds! If you don't want to purchase a guidebook for the museum, I recommend doing a little research online about some of the paintings in the collection before you go.

reviewnospace: The museum is jam packed with Dali works! It was a really cool experience with lots of opportunities to interact with the art (coin operated machines that made the art move etc). My one big complaint is that it was so super crowded it was almost not enjoyable. I was actually thinking about that if there were to be any sort of emergency the exits are not clearly labeled and the gallery does not seem to follow any sort of max capacity rule. Really scary.....

Beside the museum is the church where Dali was baptized/attended and his funeral was held. Not expensive to tour.

quote: Weird, wild, but ultimately not worth it
reviewnospace: Driving to Barcelona from the north almost demands a visit to Dali's birthplace in Figueres, where he built his own museum for much of his art. I am not a Dali fan but went with an open mind. While there is much to see, and some quite interesting, the weird sculptures, the wild drawings, and the bizzare hommage to Mae West, the museum did not hold my attention. In fact much of his most well known work (recall the "melting watch") is not there. It was more a feeling of enduring the experience than enjoying it. Others may feel differently, such is the subjectivity of art.

reviewnospace:
He was very frustrated person :). This can be seen in every part of his art. He often uses molten forms, animals, eggs, mirror-reflection, and everything is wrapped with a sense of all kind of life frustrations. I have to admit that for most people his art is too abstract and surreal even for the present time.
I have been twice there, I would love to go once more, but alone, just to have more time to think and understand his mind though his work.
Pure sick genius!

reviewnospace:
I absolutely loved the Dali Theatre Museum, it is like nothing I have ever seen before, from the outside it looks like a rose pink fortress topped with giant eggs, a glass dome and what looks like bread rolls on it's exterior !!! Outside it is visually stunning with golden statues on the building and sculptures in the surroundings, one looks like it is made out of tyres, and set into the building is the face of Dali with a tv and large egg behind a glass partition. The main courtyard is shaped like an amphitheatre with more golden statutes, a ship and a sculpture of a lady on a car whose interior features a lady and gentleman and driver covered with ivy and snails !. The top of the amphitheatre is edged with white sinks !!!!, Inside the building is a massive painting by Dali and another amazing work of art is a painting of Abraham Lincoln which is made up of lots of smaller paintings which viewed from a distance becomes a picture of a naked lady !. As well as Dali paintings there are sculptures, sketches and a room with whose furniture depicts the face of Mae West, a red sofa forming the lips and two large paintings forming the eyes. Another room one enters by the mouth in a three dimensional face, the hair being made out of cobs of sweetcorn and the nose is a model of upside down baby. Also there is a beautiful bed, the bottom is made up of two sea serpents for the legs. Salvador Dali is buried in the basement.

The Dali Theatre-Museum is a totally surreal place and it makes any visit a wonderful, fun and informative visitor experience.

Visited October 2011

reviewnospace: This is one of the most extraordinary experiences anyone can have in an art museum. The range of Dali's work that is exhibited is impressive. His work is so detailed and this collection is so large, that if you really want to enjoy this museum you should take a guided tour so that you do not miss out on any little, yet interesting details and you should be willing to spend around four hours or more to wander around by yourself. Many people wait in line for hours, but the best advice I can give for visitors is to buy the guided tour. It is about twenty euros per person and they not only give you a guided tour of the museum, but a tour of the town where Dali grew up! This was the best part! They take you to see where he grew up and if you go you will learn the secret of the grasshopper and get to see it yourself.....

The art on display is awesome including my favourite a 30 foot painting of Abe Lincon, that is made up of hundreds of mini paintings. Well worth a visit.

quote: A great place to discover an artist
reviewnospace: There is more about Dali than megalomania and you get an education if you visit this museum. I went with a guided tour from Barcelona (one-day excursion) and fantastic guide-driver Ana of the agency Explore Barcelona. Highly recommended.
titleopinion: A great place to discover an artist. There is more about Dali than megalomania and you get an education if you visit this museum. I went with a guided tour from Barcelona (one-day excursion) and fantastic guide-driver Ana of the agency Explore Barcelona. Highly recommended.

reviewnospace:
If you are anywhere near Figueres in North-Eastern Spain, just a few miles from the border with France, take a couple of hours off and treat yourself to an amazing experience.

Dali became a recluse after the death of his beloved wife, Gala, and spent his last years holed up in this former theatre, working as much as failg health allowed to put his distinctive mark on it and to leave hsi own unique legacy.

Love him or hate him, you'll have to admit that Dali's painterly craftsmanship was up there with the greatest.

He admired Velazquez, Vermeer and Raphael above all, stating that he could never reach their level, yet in some of his religious works especially, he is very, very close to their level of perfection. However, it is the desert scenes, magical light, the black Cadillac or the melting clocks which will probably be remembered best, for better or worse.

Dali's museum certainly shows us that whilst as an artist his advance of surrealism made his fame, his sheer ability with a paint brush meant that he was destined to leave his mark in just as real a way as that of any of his predecessors.
titleopinion: Salvador, you've left your mark!. If you are anywhere near Figueres in North-Eastern Spain, just a few miles from the border with France, take a couple of hours off and treat yourself to an amazing experience. He admired Velazquez, Vermeer and Raphael above all, stating that he could never reach their level, yet in some of his religious works especially, he is very, very close to their level of perfection. However, it is the desert scenes, magical light, the black Cadillac or the melting clocks which will probably be remembered best, for better or worse.   Dali's museum certainly shows us that whilst as an artist his advance of surrealism made his fame, his sheer ability with a paint brush meant that he was destined to leave his mark in just as real a way as that of any of his predecessors.

reviewnospace: It was so packed with tourists one could not even stop and take in the art. My husband has wanted to do the three pack since he can remember and we were disappointed by how many people were let in at one time. Tour buses full, hundreds all let in at once! Everyone was pushing and shoving and rushing through like they had to get somewhere else and fast. Hardly room to breath. We heard a lot of insults from uninformed people about Dali and his work. Seriously, it's sad but it seems like a money trap to me. We wish we could have really taken in the true masters work. We did make it to the other two houses and it was well worth it! Much more relaxed and enjoyable. If you are a true Dali lover go to Pubol and Port......if you go here prepare for the crowds.

reviewnospace:
Even though this musuem is quite far from central Barcelona at least 1 hour and 30 mins on the train (if you get the regional train 2 hours).

We got the train from passeig Gracia (this station beware you cannot get to via the metro station). The train station entrance is pass casa mila! Return ticket from Barcelona to Figueres is 30 euros, but the admission fee to the musuem in only 12 euros.

The trains run roughly every hour, so be careful not to get caught out. You need the train from Barcelona which goes to Portbou, this train will stop at Figueres.

Once you leave the station follow the signs which say musuem and gradully you will find the musuem, its meant to onlybe a 10 min walk from the station for us it was more of a 15-20min. So might be best to get directions from the tourist info stand inside the train station.

The musuem is great contains lots of quirky stuff, you will need at least half a day in Figueres but definately worth a visit.

reviewnospace:
My wife and I and two friends decided to drive down from France where we were staying for New Year (about 40 min drive). None of us are artists, nor are we particularly keen on art; however we all thoroughly enjoyed this experience (as well as a nice lunch in the sunshine in December at a restaurant near the "Ramblas" about 5 min walk away).
The experience starts as you queue outside (less than 10 minutes) when you notice bizarre art on and around the building. You go inside and then into an outdoor courtyard to be met by a full size car, raining on the inside. Once you have worked out the number system of the various galleries (1 - 22 I think) you can then follow the pathways round, stairs up and down etc This really adds to the experience as each room is done differently. There is so much art that although we took about 2 hours, we felt we could easily have spent a lot longer. There is also the usual shop at the end if you want to buy some Dali on a t-shirt, mug, poster etc. Overall, if I was an artist or really into art, I would absolutely love this place. I am not, yet I still thought it was absolutely fantastic and a highlight of our holiday.

quote: A fantastic way to spend half a day
reviewnospace: Figueras is an easy train ride from Barcelona and even if your a luke warm fan, the Dali Theatre Museum is well worth the trip. It contains many pieces of his art works, art works that he owned and works of the current curator. But it's the way the works are displayed in multi-level gallery - that twists and turns - that adds to the amazing experience.

reviewnospace:
Determined to visit Dali's museum in his birthplace after attending the Singapore exhibition of his works a few months ago, I was absolutely exhilarated by the experience. To be greeted by the whimsical orange building with the huge eggs on top was just stupendous. It was to be teased by the mustache-twirling master of illusion, delusion and "pull the rug under your feet" maestro on every floor and corner as you turn, from the huge Cadillac in the grounds above which the inflated Hindu goddess floated (jeering reminder of materialism as the ultimate god?) to the Mae West chamber where the iconic bloated red lips remind you that Andy Warhol is only his most successful successor, to the portraits of women composed of blocks of stone (we are only matter in the universe in spite of all sensual embellishments), Dali pulls tricks from behind every curtain. Most poignant of all were the sketches of himself and Gaia in sailor suits innocent children on the seashore, pristine and as yet unexposed to the corruption of the world.
Stairs can be intimidating if you don't like climbing, and some parts (esp jewelry section) too dimly-lit for those not so sure of their footing. A lot of corners to turn, which I suppose add to the atmosphere of the uncanny and unexpected.
Figueres itself is a charming town, full of dear little cafes and lively eating places, shops selling clothes, shoes and nice watches, not just the melting-watch kind, perfect for souvenir hunters. Very negotiable as most roads radiate from the central Ramblas. Catch a 2 hr bus to Barcelona from the bus station which has a little shop selling the best kebab I ever tasted outside of Berlin and Turkey at a modest 4 euros! Be warned though that the public toilet there can be used only with a 0.50 euro coin!

reviewnospace: The trip to Figueres is an easy train ride from Barcelona less than 2hours. There are signs to the museum 15-20 minute walk. The museum was fantastic, you didn't know what to expect as you entered each area. Even if his art is not to your liking, it is a fun ,interesting experience. Take your time to enjoy it. Good day trip if you have extra time.

reviewnospace:
I just returned from a European acation and I want to tell you about the Dali Museum in Figueres.

We parked at the train station in Figueres and walked to the attraction in only 20 minutes. Just follow the signs or ask a local for directions.

We took our time and spent about 4 hours taking in all of the sights there re to see. I recommend reading a little about the museum before you go to familiarize t\yourself with what to expect to see, such as the Mae West room at the top of the building which some people missed because they did not know about it or its location. It is also nice to know that you can put small coins into things like the Cadillac car and make it rain! Dali was quite an entertainer and his personality shows right through here at his museum and also his final esting place which you will see! Have fun, that it what the man wanted....

reviewnospace: I visited Barcelona and made a daily trip to Figueres to visit famous Dali museum. It was fantastic. I'm convinced that Dali was a genius. You must certainly visit there!

reviewnospace: Went to the Dali museum in Figueres when travelling in Costa Brava. It definitely is something not to be missed when in the region, esp if you're a fan of Dali. The building itself is amazing from the outside - the eggs and bread rolls gives an indication of the whacky-ness and quirkiness inside. We went there early in the morning, so didn't have to wait too long for tickets but there was already a sizeable crowd. There is a floor plan which gives a brief description of the significant art work (not just Dali's but those of other artists) housed in the building, though it does say that visitors don't have to follow the rooms round by the numbers. I was struck by how versatile Dali's work was and it really was a weird and wonderful world in the museum. It definitely gave a sense of the bizarre world of Dali and the amazing imagination in his work. I didn't find the entrance fee steep considering the amount of work to appreciate and mull over, also having been to Barcelona, we were used to having to pay even more for Gaudi's buildings. We spent about 2 hours there including a visit to the Jewels section. Figueres itself is a pretty town and worth spending some time in. Definitely recommended!!

reviewnospace:
No trip to Figueres would be complete without a visit to this museum. Make sure you pick up a map of the museum on the way in and this will guide you around the 22 rooms (yes 22). You are free to wander around but as there is so much to see you are best advised to follow the numbers on the map.

You are free to take photos in most of the rooms as long as you don' t use flash.

Well worth a visit but be prepared as it's quite tiring and at 12 Euros each we felt it was a little expensive.

reviewnospace:
If you visit Spain and like Dali, this museaum is where he and his wife Gala lived, so a must see!

Dalí was a skilled draftsman, best known for the striking and bizarre images in his surrealist work. His painterly skills are often attributed to the influence of Renaissance masters.[1][2] His best-known work, The Persistence of Memory, was completed in 1931. Dalí's expansive artistic repertoire included film, sculpture, and photography, in collaboration with a range of artists in a variety of media.

Dalí attributed his "love of everything that is gilded and excessive, my passion for luxury and my love of oriental clothes"[3] to a self-styled "Arab lineage", claiming that his ancestors were descended from the Moors.

Dalí was highly imaginative, and also enjoyed indulging in unusual and grandiose behavior. His eccentric manner and attention-grabbing public actions sometimes drew more attention than his artwork, to the dismay of those who held his work in high esteem, and to the irritation of his critics.[4]
titleopinion: Must see. If you visit Spain and like Dali, this museaum is where he and his wife Gala lived, so a must see! Dalí was highly imaginative, and also enjoyed indulging in unusual and grandiose behavior. His eccentric manner and attention-grabbing public actions sometimes drew more attention than his artwork, to the dismay of those who held his work in high esteem, and to the irritation of his critics.[4]

reviewnospace: After trekking almost half-way around the world to visit the Dali Museum in Figueres, we were surprised by the fact that enjoying it was a bit of a challenge. Since the museum does not sell tickets online or take reservations for individual visitors, we had to wait outside in line almost 1/2 hour late in the afternoon to purchase our tickets. Once in, though, we had the run of the large facility for several hours as it stays open well into the evening. Our challenge in this regard, though, was that there was no docent-led tour or audio guide to help with understanding the very unique but often oblique work of Dali's technical and intellectual genius. Nor did we understand the order in which the many, many works were displayed in the numbered rooms which seemed to be in a jumble themselves. Even so, we spent several hours meandering around, soaking up the breathtaking experience of being surrounded by Dali's oeuvre. We would not have missed it for anything but suggest that, if you must make a choice, several hours spent at the Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Florida is a more complete and gratifying experience.
titleopinion: A challenging art adventure. After trekking almost half-way around the world to visit the Dali Museum in Figueres, we were surprised by the fact that enjoying it was a bit of a challenge. Once in, though, we had the run of the large facility for several hours as it stays open well into the evening. Our challenge in this regard, though, was that there was no docent-led tour or audio guide to help with understanding the very unique but often oblique work of Dali's technical and intellectual genius. Nor did we understand the order in which the many, many works were displayed in the numbered rooms which seemed to be in a jumble themselves. Even so, we spent several hours meandering around, soaking up the breathtaking experience of being surrounded by Dali's oeuvre. We would not have missed it for anything but suggest that, if you must make a choice, several hours spent at the Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Florida is a more complete and gratifying experience.

reviewnospace: This museum overseen by Dali himself is an eye-opener on all levels. Go with an open mind and marvel at the genius that was Dali. Even if you don't like his art you must see the perfection and talent in it.

reviewnospace:
This place was wonderful. We visited as part of a large tour group in October 2012, knowing very little about Salvadore Dali before arriving other than that he painted pictures of melting clocks.

From the moment we saw the building's exterior we knew we were in for a treat. The entire place was utterly crazy and contained much more than just melting clocks. We saw a golden loaf of bread, a doorway shaped ilke a mouth, a gold briefcase which opened up to reveal what looked like a human spine, a mummy leaning against disembodied heads, and more. Perhaps the freakiest (and my favourite) exhibit was the statue of an overweight woman in the courtyard. She stood atop a black and white Cadillac, and huge chains ran from her neck to the walls above. Extremely weird, yet somehow artistic at the same time.


Tips:
1. Try to get here as early as possible to avoid the big tour groups like ours. It was insanely full when we arrived in the early afternoon and more people kept arriving while we were there. By the time we left I was feeling very claustrophobic and having trouble getting close enough to actually look at things.

2. Make sure you leave an hour or so to visit the jewelery meseum next door. Again, I didn't know that Dali made jewelry beforehand, but it was amazing. And equally crazy, especially the golden beating human heart.

By the time we left I was feeling very claustrophobic and having trouble getting close enough to actually look at things.   2. Make sure you leave an hour or so to visit the jewelery meseum next door. Again, I didn't know that Dali made jewelry beforehand, but it was amazing. And equally crazy, especially the golden beating human heart.

reviewnospace: Just visited this museum this past weekend and it was fantastic. If you feel the need in your life for a new source of inspiration and the need to connect with your inner artist and creative side then make it to this museum and Dali will remind you of how you can amuse yourself with your imagination with intensity and humor. If you sit long enough and marvel at his art and let his genius reach and touch you then your internal creative side will remember the days you too imagined beauty and rich colors and how you wanted to translate your feeingls into Art but couldn't or wouldn't or never got around to it. Dali will remind you that you too are an artist even if you can't produce art as long as you appreciate it and find space for it in your life. He will make the case that art is part of the magic of life and that there is beautiful art in everything we imagine touch or feel. Go and visit you will not regret this.

reviewnospace: This was the best detour from Barcelona. What more than Dali's hometown. It's a beautiful place and his genius is beyond a doubt. This is also his final resting place. Take your time and enjoy the day with everything Dali.
titleopinion: Ahead of his time. This was the best detour from Barcelona. What more than Dali's hometown. It's a beautiful place and his genius is beyond a doubt. This is also his final resting place. Take your time and enjoy the day with everything Dali.

reviewnospace:
I consider this museum worthwhile visiting even for those who are not fans of surrealism in general or of Dali in particular. It's quite different from any other museum I have visited.
I found both the building itself and its design as well as the items on display astonishing and inspiring. For Dali-fans, this is heaven.
One note: The museum doesn't give you a lot of background information on the person of Dali or his life, it's really more about his art only. However, Figueres forms part of the Emporda triangle (together with Cadaques and Pubol) in which more Dali-related sights can be found.
True, the musuem is pretty crowded. Due to the lack of a special sequence of visiting, it may be hard to figure out in the end whether you really covered everything, leading to you passing several halls twice or even more times. Still, a great experience, don't skip it.
Figueres itself is a small, cozy provincial town and worth a stroll. The train connection to Figueres coming from Barcelona and Girona is fine.
titleopinion: Astonishing and inspiring museum. I consider this museum worthwhile visiting even for those who are not fans of surrealism in general or of Dali in particular. It's quite different from any other museum I have visited. I found both the building itself and its design as well as the items on display astonishing and inspiring. For Dali-fans, this is heaven. One note: The museum doesn't give you a lot of background information on the person of Dali or his life, it's really more about his art only. However, Figueres forms part of the Emporda triangle (together with Cadaques and Pubol) in which more Dali-related sights can be found. True, the musuem is pretty crowded. Due to the lack of a special sequence of visiting, it may be hard to figure out in the end whether you really covered everything, leading to you passing several halls twice or even more times. Still, a great experience, don't skip it. Figueres itself is a small, cozy provincial town and worth a stroll. The train connection to Figueres coming from Barcelona and Girona is fine.

reviewnospace: we knocked together a trip around catalunya to include the dali museum at figueres and we werent disappointed. stunning and full of interest from the second you turn the corner to set eyes on the amazing outside of the dali designed building. we took almost 4 hours to get around the whole museum which has something to stun you inside every room. this is far from just a normal museum. dali designd it to thrill us all and it certainly does that. i was in dali dreamland from first sighting the crazily brilliant outer design, then entering the museum to sight the cadillac and stunning painting backdrop to the fabulous mae west tribute. the place just had us buzzing. i was a bit worried about not being able to take pictures after reading the dali museum website, but as long as you dont use flash it is fine. at only 12 euros each this really is superb value for money. not to be missed. oh and dont miss the jewellery section. not something i was bothered about but well stunning. just go there and see for yourself.

quote: As different a museum as Dali was a painter
reviewnospace:
there is more stuff here than you can imagine or take in in one or two visits. The brochure provides you with a description of the organization of the exhibits but then suggests you visit them in no particular Order. Those exhibits for which there is any description contain only a title and a date. It is the artist telling you that the experience of this stuff should be your own and not that of any curator or the artist himself.

The museum is a must see.

reviewnospace: On a cruise recently, a visit to this museum was an optional trip. I am so glad I visited this place as it was truly spectacular, so much to see and just not enough time in the couple of hours we had. Having seen some of the familiar Dali work in books, magazines and up close in Glasgow, I was astounded at the variety of work he produced - I felt like Alice in Wonderland and each room brought another delicious surprise. We had a guide who was really excellent and he introduced us to the many delights that lie beneath what the eye immediately sees and which may be missed unless they are pointed out to you. I would love to go back.

quote: The last place I expected to enjoy so much!
reviewnospace:
I have never liked surrealistic art. It makes me feel uncomfortable so you can say I'm not a fan. naturally that museum was not a thing I would go to. However, I was on a company trip which I was grateful to join since I had just started working there three weeks before that, so I didn't want to complain and seem ungrateful. Oh man, it was a good thing I shut my mouth! From one exhibit to another, I couldn't make my jaw go back to place. We had a guided tour of course, so we didn't miss anything. Some of the hidden meanings I would have overlooked without it.
The man drew in pixels long before they were called pixels. The May West living room will have you wonder just how many angles were working to get that idea into his mind and even the most "ordinary" pictures will have you stare at them.
It's worth every effort and every minute you are going to put into it.
Strongly recommended.

Oh man, it was a good thing I shut my mouth! From one exhibit to another, I couldn't make my jaw go back to place. We had a guided tour of course, so we didn't miss anything. Some of the hidden meanings I would have overlooked without it.  The man drew in pixels long before they were called pixels. The May West living room will have you wonder just how many angles were working to get that idea into his mind and even the most  ordinary  pictures will have you stare at them.  It's worth every effort and every minute you are going to put into it.  Strongly recommended.

quote: Fantastic representation of the man and his work
reviewnospace:
Well worth the trip we made from Barcelona to Figueres to see this exhibition. Even if you have little interest in Art or prior knowledge of Dali's work, this exhibition gives an amazing insight to the workings of the human mind. His skill, vision, imagination and eccentricity give truth to his self proclaimed genius. Take time to look closely as many of the exhibits reveal much more than a cursory glance might indicate. Don't expect to see many of his better known works as these are exhibited in museums across the world but the museum he designed and planned for his home town of Figueres is an outstanding legacy. Also don't miss the second museum just round the corner (entry is included with your ticket) as the jewels reflect another aspect of his work and are masterpieces of exuberance and extravagance.
There are a number of options for getting to Figueres from Barcelona. We opted for the train from Passeig de Gracia station which was relatively straight forward and gave us more freedom and control than an organised tour would have done - it also cost less than half the price of the tours we saw advertised in Barcelona which included a visit to Girona. However as the train goes through Girona this is something you could easliy do after Figueres if you wish. We preferred to soak up the sunshine in a little restaurant at the square in Figueres and enjoy Tapas and Cava - sheer bliss

reviewnospace: This museum has an incredible collection of Dali art which is well presented. If you are any where in the area and like, or want to learn more about Dali's art, this museum is amust.
titleopinion: Worth a detour. This museum has an incredible collection of Dali art which is well presented. If you are any where in the area and like, or want to learn more about Dali's art, this museum is amust.

reviewnospace:
We visited here, not quite sure what to expect, not being particulary into art galleries etc. I found it fascinating. Whilst I didnt understand what much of it means, by looking at the small detail in his work,I appreciated the skill, and imagination he had. Also unlike many artists, he worked in many different mediums, and styles as well as sculptures, and holograms. Travelling round is confusing in itself, but I think he deliberately designed it that way, and its easy to miss things. I would recommend going
to there, even if you are not into art, as I'm sure you would realise
how many different talents he had,and yes, we actually enjoyed it.

I would recommend going to there, even if you are not into art, as I'm sure you would realise how many different talents he had,and yes, we actually enjoyed it.

quote: Dali's genius and quirkiness all on display
reviewnospace:
A worthwhile hour trek up from Girona to visit this museum. Examples of many of his works are on display, and the price of admission to this surrealistic and quirky museum includes admission to the adjacent Dali-Jewels museum which showed an aspect of Dali I was not aware of. And make sure you you spend the time to wait in line to see the Mae West Room. I won't say more, but you've got to see it!
As much of a fan of Dali as I am, I reluctantly give the experience a 4 instead of a 5, not because of the crowds, which are to be expected, but because of the constant tour groups going through, one after another, and guides speaking very loudly in some of the smaller galleries. I would recommend that the museum consider having groups only go through at certain hours, so those not in groups can stand back and enjoy.

reviewnospace:
It is the best thing in Figueres. Even maybe the only worth visiting.
The museum consists of two parts: Dali art and Dali Jewelery.
It is worth mentioning, that museum has a big success, so it is crowded. Salvador Dali is burried in here and You can visit his thomb in here.
I can't explain the art and impressions in here, because it is incomparable. Just You has to now, that there are lots of Russian tourist groups, and less from the other countries. So if You know Russian, every five minutes You can find a guide with the group and You can use it while listening to an excursion.. It is great thing for those who came here by themself. With the guide You will no and see much more great things in here, than without it . So i strongly reccomend to take a guide, or listen to the guide who goes with the other group.
Guides talking in Englis or other languages, ar rarer in here, but stil there I saw a few.
Also, after seeng first exposition of the art and theathre of dali, don't miss the other part - jewelery. This part You can visit with the other ticket (at the entrance of the museum You are getting two tickets, each for the part).
Dali jewelery is realy great. It made a big impression to my girlfriend. So, guys, don't miss an oportunity to by some of Dali jewelery stuff in the souvenir shop of the museum, Your other part would really like it. And keep in mind, that You wont get this stuff anywhere else except Figuares.

quote: Worth a visit but very crowded.
reviewnospace: Glad we visited the Dali museum. Not sure I liked all his art, but very wide ranging and imaginative and there were examples of extremely good draftsmanship. We went on afternoon of 20th Sept and it was still very busy with everyone using their cameras to take flash photos of picture and installations which did detract from the experience.
titleopinion: Worth a visit but very crowded.. Glad we visited the Dali museum. Not sure I liked all his art, but very wide ranging and imaginative and there were examples of extremely good draftsmanship. We went on afternoon of 20th Sept and it was still very busy with everyone using their cameras to take flash photos of picture and installations which did detract from the experience.

reviewnospace: Train can be taken from Pasaige de Gracia street and takes about 1.5 hours. From the train station, follow the signs for about 15 minutes to get to the museum. If you have a backpack or any other large bag you have to check it in for free. Your ticket includes the jewelry with has a separate entrance. The museum itself is nuts and you know Dali was on something when he painted. Photos without flash are allowed. Takes about 3 hours to see everything. Follow the map or else its easy to miss stuff.

reviewnospace: We've visited a lot of museum all over the world but this museum one of the best. Dali's genius is reflected in every showpiece of this museum. One can spend hours in this museum, amazed, inspired by great mystery of this man, his imagination and work.

quote: Not worth the time and effort
reviewnospace: Frankly, unless you are a total nut for Dali, I wouldn't bother ... extremely crowded, since they don't limit number of people at a time. Lots of art, but very jumbled - not well organized displays. Dali was a very skilled artist, but he was so busy being shocking and weird that a little bit goes a long way. The town itself is totally lacking in charm, and with a 2 hour train ride from Barcelona, my opinion is that it just isn't worth the effort.

The town itself is totally lacking in charm, and with a 2 hour train ride from Barcelona, my opinion is that it just isn't worth the effort.

If you are in the big original museum dont miss the painting of Gala in the nude which turns into Lincoln's face and also the face of Mae West.. but actually we liked all his works

reviewnospace:
What a great museum to visit. It has a Fredo Kahlo or Robert Brady Museum feel. Dali was an amazing creator of everything from beautiful painting to quirky art pieces that make no sense but fun to see. They also have visiting art exhibits that are wonderful. I think the only negative is that they let too many people in at one time. Several student groups visiting without any supervision.
The venue is incredible...a neat little museum with tons to see.

reviewnospace:
This is the place to go for art lovers...a massive cross-section of this prolific genius's work.
Stunning!
titleopinion: Wow. This is the place to go for art lovers...a massive cross-section of this prolific genius's work. Stunning!

reviewnospace:
Let me make it clear, I love Salvador Dali, many don't, but I think he is a genius, hey you have to be to produce some of the rubbish he did.
I was so excited to visit this museum and what a disappointment.
The museum has no control over numbers of visitors. We arrived an 10.15 in the morning and could hardly see anything because of the hundreds of idiots taking photographs of everything in it (buy a postcard, it's better quality). Booked and timed entry, as at the Dali house in Cadaques, would be a much better idea. Keep the numbers under control and everyone will enjoy it more.
As I have said I love Dali but he did, like every artist, produce a lot of dross. There is no editorial control, dross is next to genius.
Maybe because of the crowds but even with a map I managed to miss what I really wanted to see above all else (Mae West).
This could, and should, be a wonderful experience, but it just ain't.

reviewnospace:
I have read the negative reviews on this place, which mainly relate to the number of people visiting the museum. I think its a bit unfair to give bad marks to a place just because it's popular!

Perhaps I got more out of the visit that other people, because I went to art school years ago, and it was breath-taking to see some works in real life, which I have been familiar with (but only in printed form in books etc.) for so many years.

The building itself is a work of art too!

We went a few years ago, so the date I have put on here is incorrect, however, it is still virtually the same now as when I went (I checked the current site online).

Seeing alot of the works together like this makes sense of Dali's life, the surroundings and people around him figuring often.

If you like art, this is not ordinary exhibition...... don't miss it!

I normally comment on disabled access issues (since my mother is disabled) but on this occasion I have to admit that I was so interested in the art, that I neglected to check out the other facilities! - sorry!)

quote: Great museum, but park your car in a safe area
reviewnospace: We went this summer to this great museum which was absolutely astonishing! However I just wanted to mention to absolutely go there by day and park, if possible, on the museum's parking spaces. We went in the evening (the museum is open until 1am in summer) and since the museum's parking was closed (I still cannot believe why) we parked in the lower area and some guys broke into our camping car, broke our door and windows and stole our camera, navigation system etc. We also saw another car with a broken window, the police told us that thieves are targeting mostly foreign cars, so you should be aware of that if you go in the evening.

quote: One of Highlights of our Trip
reviewnospace: We went to the Dali Museum in September 2012 with a tour guide, and it was one of the highlights of our trip. Dali was such an original, unique, fun and charismatic artist. For those who get bored of art museums quickly, trust me, you will really enjoy this museum and it will likely be like no other art museum. The Jewellery museum was our favourite and just breath-taking. Really really had a great time.
titleopinion: One of Highlights of our Trip. We went to the Dali Museum in September 2012 with a tour guide, and it was one of the highlights of our trip. Dali was such an original, unique, fun and charismatic artist. For those who get bored of art museums quickly, trust me, you will really enjoy this museum and it will likely be like no other art museum. The Jewellery museum was our favourite and just breath-taking. Really really had a great time.

reviewnospace:
This is not an art museum - this is a theatre where Dali expressed himself on such a grand scale that you almost feel out of breath.
This is fantastic!! You can pre-book and skip the line which can get rather long. Even standing in line you will however glimpse what awaits you as outside there are also various creations. Especially based on that Catalan way of life where nothing is thrown away but a new purpose is found for it - even old tractor tyres make the pillar for a statue.

An absolute delight was the jewellery collection. WOW!!! With a 'beating heart' and jewels that open and close - FANTASTIC.
titleopinion: Dali on a grand scale. This is not an art museum - this is a theatre where Dali expressed himself on such a grand scale that you almost feel out of breath. This is fantastic!! You can pre-book and skip the line which can get rather long. Even standing in line you will however glimpse what awaits you as outside there are also various creations. Especially based on that Catalan way of life where nothing is thrown away but a new purpose is found for it - even old tractor tyres make the pillar for a statue.  An absolute delight was the jewellery collection. WOW!!! With a 'beating heart' and jewels that open and close - FANTASTIC.

reviewnospace: Simply a must go if you're in the north of Spain. Find out what a great multitalented artist Dali has been. First do the museum (in some 2 hours), then visit the jewelry museum next door too (for an hour or so). Make sure you are at the entrance around 09:00AM before opening time; this way you can truly see the pieces of art without being annoyed there's too many people walking around.
titleopinion: Must go!. Simply a must go if you're in the north of Spain. Find out what a great multitalented artist Dali has been. First do the museum (in some 2 hours), then visit the jewelry museum next door too (for an hour or so). Make sure you are at the entrance around 09:00AM before opening time; this way you can truly see the pieces of art without being annoyed there's too many people walking around.

reviewnospace: Probably the only interesting thing to do in Figueres... The Dali Museum is an extraordinary collection of the best Dali's work. He's my favorite artist and I have been a few times to this splendid museum. My suggestion would be to take your time and go in the morning, less crowded hours. Also there is some non-permanent exhibitions from less known artist but quite good as well. Figueres is only 1 hour drive from Perpignan (France) and 1 hour from Cadaques, Dali's former house and a nice piece of art as well.
titleopinion: For Dali lovers. Probably the only interesting thing to do in Figueres... The Dali Museum is an extraordinary collection of the best Dali's work. He's my favorite artist and I have been a few times to this splendid museum. My suggestion would be to take your time and go in the morning, less crowded hours. Also there is some non-permanent exhibitions from less known artist but quite good as well. Figueres is only 1 hour drive from Perpignan (France) and 1 hour from Cadaques, Dali's former house and a nice piece of art as well.

reviewnospace:
From Barcelona take the train to Figueres. Once in Figueres walk up the hill and behold the museum. Dali fans will not be disappointed as there is a good sampling of many of his works throughout his life. The museum itself is flamboyant, whimsical, interactive and just plain fun. It does get crowded but many of the works are large, so you have good viewing opportunities.

There is a second part to the museum featuring his jewel collection. Do not miss this (it is included in the price of the ticket). You will oooh and aaaah and giggle when you see some of the pieces. I couldn't take my eyes off the gold heart with rubies that beat.
titleopinion: Various Works Featured. From Barcelona take the train to Figueres. Once in Figueres walk up the hill and behold the museum. Dali fans will not be disappointed as there is a good sampling of many of his works throughout his life. The museum itself is flamboyant, whimsical, interactive and just plain fun. It does get crowded but many of the works are large, so you have good viewing opportunities.  There is a second part to the museum featuring his jewel collection. Do not miss this (it is included in the price of the ticket). You will oooh and aaaah and giggle when you see some of the pieces. I couldn't take my eyes off the gold heart with rubies that beat.

reviewnospace: Have always been intrigued by Dali so visit to this museum was on our holiday schedule. Not disappointed. The museum entrance is stunning and leads you into a large glass fronted entrance hall. Although it was very busy it did not feel crowded. We arrived about 9.30am in the morning. If you can get there earlier it may be quieter. You are allowed to take photographs without flash. The visit lasted about 2 and 1/2 hours, but we took our time. Don't have to be interested in Dali to enjoy the experience. Definately worth a visit.
titleopinion: Execellent museum. Have always been intrigued by Dali so visit to this museum was on our holiday schedule. Not disappointed. Don't have to be interested in Dali to enjoy the experience. Definately worth a visit.

reviewnospace: This museum contains a large collection of works by Salvador Dali and is a must for anyone interested in his artistic career. It is extremely well laid out and even if you're not interested in modern art his work is clever and fascinating.
titleopinion: Super collection. This museum contains a large collection of works by Salvador Dali and is a must for anyone interested in his artistic career. It is extremely well laid out and even if you're not interested in modern art his work is clever and fascinating.

reviewnospace: Stopped on route to Cadaques, having pre-booked tickets online which I recommend as it will save you queuing. This museum is fun and so interesting, loved by all family. So glad we stopped and made the effort to visit.
titleopinion: A real joy. Stopped on route to Cadaques, having pre-booked tickets online which I recommend as it will save you queuing. This museum is fun and so interesting, loved by all family. So glad we stopped and made the effort to visit.

reviewnospace: A must see! This place is extraordinary so make the pilgrimage to Figueres! His work is so imaginative......we arrived & it was as hot as hell, the queue was at least 2 hours.....so I saw a sign which said tours from the info office,..... an hour around the city & direct access to the museum. Much better idea & insight into Dali & where he lived....

quote: Great museum worth a day in Figueras
reviewnospace:
Great overview of Dali's work, with nice artworks and installations.

The audioguide in the May West installation gives some nice tips, for 2€. Given the importance of the man & the museum, consider taking a guide.

We booked a ticket through internet and it spares you a long waiting line... we took the visit at 17H; check the museum website for visiting times with internet tickets!
When you book at 17Hcome 10 minutes before 17H. In 10 minutes, the line forms very quickly.
Check also which line you have to take (FYI you can take the left lane which is significantly shorter)
The museum also has some other artists expo's.

You can also get tickets in every Caixa bank; shorter but not always easy since only the first events ticket screen is in English.The bank people are happy to help you further in case you do not known Spanish that well.

Have fun and enjoy Dali!
titleopinion: Great museum worth a day in Figueras. Great overview of Dali's work, with nice artworks and installations.  The audioguide in the May West installation gives some nice tips, for 2€. Given the importance of the man & the museum, consider taking a guide.  We booked a ticket through internet and it spares you a long waiting line... we took the visit at 17H; check the museum website for visiting times with internet tickets!  When you book at 17Hcome 10 minutes before 17H. In 10 minutes, the line forms very quickly. Check also which line you have to take (FYI you can take the left lane which is significantly shorter) The museum also has some other artists expo's.  You can also get tickets in every Caixa bank; shorter but not always easy since only the first events ticket screen is in English.The bank people are happy to help you further in case you do not known Spanish that well.  Have fun and enjoy Dali!

reviewnospace: What a great way to experience this surreal and magical museum. Highly recommend - not too busy and you can really take your time to see all the amazing exhibits.
titleopinion: Night time spectacular. What a great way to experience this surreal and magical museum. Highly recommend - not too busy and you can really take your time to see all the amazing exhibits.

reviewnospace: We went to the Museum late in day, so we avoided the long queues. The place is outstanding : the personality of the artist is completely represented y the originality of the works of art. Two upper floors dedicated to the artist collection of other painters ; the ground floor "spiral" dedicated to the artist work . In the underground floor an outstanding collection of jewels and the Artist Tomb.
titleopinion: OUTSTANDNG place!. We went to the Museum late in day, so we avoided the long queues. The place is outstanding : the personality of the artist is completely represented y the originality of the works of art. Two upper floors dedicated to the artist collection of other painters ; the ground floor  spiral  dedicated to the artist work . In the underground floor an outstanding collection of jewels and the Artist Tomb.

quote: Visit by night for extra atmosphere
reviewnospace:
The night visits start from 10pm and it is well worth waiting until then. The queues are minimal (10 minutes) and you see many things in a way that Dali intended (i.e. at night with the special lighting). We went in August when the daytime queues were two to three hours in the hot sun.

We last visited the museum two years ago (daytime) and the contrast was very notable. Then we paid extra for the guided tour which is the best way to see it by day (and to avoid all those queues!).
titleopinion: Visit by night for extra atmosphere. The night visits start from 10pm and it is well worth waiting until then. The queues are minimal (10 minutes) and you see many things in a way that Dali intended (i.e. at night with the special lighting). We went in August when the daytime queues were two to three hours in the hot sun.  We last visited the museum two years ago (daytime) and the contrast was very notable. Then we paid extra for the guided tour which is the best way to see it by day (and to avoid all those queues!).

reviewnospace: We visited Dali Museum in Mid July and the line can be VERY long at this time of year so its good to be there early (around 9.00). The museum was great and there was a lot to see. Make sure you have enough time here. Also Figueres is a nice city to walk around. The ticket was around 10EURO
titleopinion: Marvellous place. We visited Dali Museum in Mid July and the line can be VERY long at this time of year so its good to be there early (around 9.00). The museum was great and there was a lot to see. Make sure you have enough time here. Also Figueres is a nice city to walk around. The ticket was around 10EURO

reviewnospace:
The Teatre-Museu Dali is amazing. A trip to Barcelona would be MUCH enhanced by a day-trip to Figueres JUST TO SEE this. GO GO GO!
My tips:
-Show up when it opens to skip the line, which can be unbelievably long like a Disneyland line
-Research the ticket options so you're not surprised - the prices aren't bad
-Allow plenty of time to meander and enjoy the museum
-Check out the Joies exhibit which is awesome
-Take a camera for lots of fun pictures inside and outside the building
-Explore the art on the outside of the building and down the little side streets just off the building (there are some really cool, funky statues)
titleopinion: Awesome monument to surrealism. The Teatre-Museu Dali is amazing. A trip to Barcelona would be MUCH enhanced by a day-trip to Figueres JUST TO SEE this. GO GO GO! My tips: -Show up when it opens to skip the line, which can be unbelievably long like a Disneyland line -Research the ticket options so you're not surprised - the prices aren't bad -Allow plenty of time to meander and enjoy the museum -Check out the Joies exhibit which is awesome -Take a camera for lots of fun pictures inside and outside the building -Explore the art on the outside of the building and down the little side streets just off the building (there are some really cool, funky statues)

reviewnospace: Spent a pleasant half day here. Would advise either booking online or join one of the guided tours to avoid queuing which we had to do for over an hour in August heat. Were not disappointed with the museum which was very quirky and typically Daliesque. We really liked being able to get up close to the exhibits and take as many photos as we wished (without flash). Would advise timing your visit carefully as there is no coffee shop or place to eat in the museum. Sensible pricing which we felt was worth it.
titleopinion: Worth a visit. Spent a pleasant half day here. Would advise either booking online or join one of the guided tours to avoid queuing which we had to do for over an hour in August heat. Were not disappointed with the museum which was very quirky and typically Daliesque. We really liked being able to get up close to the exhibits and take as many photos as we wished (without flash). Would advise timing your visit carefully as there is no coffee shop or place to eat in the museum. Sensible pricing which we felt was worth it.

reviewnospace: I found the place fascinating and spent several hours in the various rooms. The admission charge was not too much, Children under 9 are free so 24 euros for a family of four was quite good for such an attraction. We had to queue for approx 35mins but I think you can buy tickets online which enable you to skip the queue. My personal favourites are Dali's self portrait with bacon and the Dali's Gala and Abraham Lincoln portrait, the children liked the Mae West room with its high viewing platform. All in all a very memorable day and I would highly recommend.

quote: Night time is the time to see it! Very Special
reviewnospace: We went to the evening session entering at 11pm and it was truly special. The jewellery Gallery is just amazing and we were lucky to see a film of Dali and get a glass of champagne on the terrace included in the price!
titleopinion: Night time is the time to see it! Very Special. We went to the evening session entering at 11pm and it was truly special. The jewellery Gallery is just amazing and we were lucky to see a film of Dali and get a glass of champagne on the terrace included in the price!

quote: Absolutely Amazing - Get A Guided Tour
reviewnospace: I am writing this after literally just coming back from this museum, it's incredible. Arrive super early if you want to go around on your own, however I would recommend a guided tour as you skip the queue completely, which is often at least an hours wait. I had a wonderful guide who spoke complex perfect English, as well as having a deep knowledge of Dali's life and the history behind the design of the museum. We stopped at around 10 different rooms and pieces and the guide gave some history on the piece as well as a personal interpretation of the pieces meaning, which was absolutely fascinating. The tour lasted around 2 hours and was only 8 euros more than standard entry. After the tour is finished you have the opportunity to look around on your own some more if you wish. With the tour you also get stacks of information and knowledge which is not displayed on any of the walls, it's truly amazing the way it is structured and the way Dali planned each aspect of the museum, if you are staying in Costa Brava or Barcelona make the journey it is completely worth it!
titleopinion: Absolutely Amazing - Get A Guided Tour. I am writing this after literally just coming back from this museum, it's incredible. Arrive super early if you want to go around on your own, however I would recommend a guided tour as you skip the queue completely, which is often at least an hours wait. I had a wonderful guide who spoke complex perfect English, as well as having a deep knowledge of Dali's life and the history behind the design of the museum. We stopped at around 10 different rooms and pieces and the guide gave some history on the piece as well as a personal interpretation of the pieces meaning, which was absolutely fascinating. The tour lasted around 2 hours and was only 8 euros more than standard entry. After the tour is finished you have the opportunity to look around on your own some more if you wish. With the tour you also get stacks of information and knowledge which is not displayed on any of the walls, it's truly amazing the way it is structured and the way Dali planned each aspect of the museum, if you are staying in Costa Brava or Barcelona make the journey it is completely worth it!

reviewnospace: I am a huge Dali fan, and took a guided day trip to Girona and Figueres to see the museum that the man himself built. It was everything that I had hoped for: interesting, strange, and not stuffy at all. There are several floors, and while there are no descriptions or audio guides (surely Dali would want each person to interpret his art in their own way) the museum is easy to navigate due to the signs on the wall saying which way to go next. I felt bad for those waiting in the long queue to purchase tickets, so buy tickets ahead if possible. As someone who can study one of Dali's paintings for several minutes, I was so disappointed at how busy the museum was. The halls are narrow in many places, and the single file line of spectators did not allow for the examination of the paintings in these areas. August is a busy time I am sure, but this museum is the fourth most visited attraction in Spain (!) so be prepared for tight quarters.
titleopinion: Great Museum. I am a huge Dali fan, and took a guided day trip to Girona and Figueres to see the museum that the man himself built. reviewnospace: this beautiful museum, in the centre of Figueres, is all about different aspects of Dali, with a couple of exhibitions of other artists; the Dali paintings are wonderful, but it is very important to look at the tiny detail, not just the subject; we went with a friend who is a Dali expert, who showed us many things we could not have spotted for ourselves; you can enter for reduced price if over 65, but you need your passport for proof; there is a Dali multi-storey car park, 30 seconds from the museum; a stunning place to visit, better in winter when the crowds are lighter

quote: Dissapointing if you are not with a guide!!
reviewnospace:
We were staying in barcelona and rented a car especially to go to this museum. we were dissapointed to find out that: there are no audio guides, no pamphlets or any explanations about the work you are seeing (english is out of the question). You can buy a book for a a nice sum, of money!! and then after entering the museum you are "blessed" with the privilage of spending more money during the exhibit: there are sevaral exhibits that require electric or mechanic movement in order to be displayed in the right manner, in order to "see" these wonders you must insert coins of 1-2 Euro in the machine as if you were in some arcade or amusement park!!
As a consumer I felt taken advantage of. I was so frustrated about these things that the content of the exhibits did not reallly impress me.

quote: Up close and personal to Dali's works
reviewnospace:
This museum was planned by the man himself and even includes his own tomb in the basement.
I have always been a fan of his works, ever since they were available as posters in the 70's. (You could buy them in record shops!) Well - at this museum, you can get right up close to them and study the intricate details of the madman's imagination - there are no roped off limitations or alarm beams to fend you off. Museum staff keep a friendly protective eye on the visitors to make sure everything is OK, and everything else is relaxed.
There are some truly amazing works on display. In the centre of the former cinema, there are huge paintings including an amazing picture which at first glance looks like a woman. When you view the picture through your digital camera, the same image looks like the head of a man instead - believed to be that of George Washington. So how did Dali anticipate that, when digital cameras didn't even exist when he painted the picture? Actually, you get the exact same result if you look through a pin-hole or make your thumb and finger into a small hole, but either way, the effect is astonishing.
When I visited this attraction, I expected to have a leisurely look round and be away in just over an hour. Instead, I had to tear myself away after well over two hours, because the variety, quality and sheer number of exhibits just blew me away.
I will be back in northern Spain in October. I can't wait to go again!
titleopinion: Up close and personal to Dali's works. This museum was planned by the man himself and even includes his own tomb in the basement. I have always been a fan of his works, ever since they were available as posters in the 70's. (You could buy them in record shops!) Well - at this museum, you can get right up close to them and study the intricate details of the madman's imagination - there are no roped off limitations or alarm beams to fend you off. Museum staff keep a friendly protective eye on the visitors to make sure everything is OK, and everything else is relaxed. There are some truly amazing works on display. In the centre of the former cinema, there are huge paintings including an amazing picture which at first glance looks like a woman. When you view the picture through your digital camera, the same image looks like the head of a man instead - believed to be that of George Washington. So how did Dali anticipate that, when digital cameras didn't even exist when he painted the picture? Actually, you get the exact same result if you look through a pin-hole or make your thumb and finger into a small hole, but either way, the effect is astonishing. When I visited this attraction, I expected to have a leisurely look round and be away in just over an hour. Instead, I had to tear myself away after well over two hours, because the variety, quality and sheer number of exhibits just blew me away. I will be back in northern Spain in October. I can't wait to go again!

reviewnospace:
Have been here a couple of times and am in absolute awe of the man's genius.
The diversity and quality of his work was exceptional.
A personal highlight for me was the "real thing" of a work that I have in my office. I have an Abraham Lincoln print on my wall and often think what a wide range of work Dali was capable of.
To see this in the prime position in the museum was amazing but every room was an inspiration - from the art to the humour of Mae West was a testiment to both his artistic skills and his frivoulous sense of humour.

Ihad no idea Dali was so diverse! Dali's Theatre Museum is well worth the wait in line. Here is a tip to avoid a wait in line. Arrive around 5:00 PM. The line is almost non existant. Tour groups are gone and standard tourist have gone by 5:00 PM. There are a ton of small streetside cafe's and restuarants inteh same few block radius, so don't sweat the time of day. If you try to show up between noon and 4:00, you can expect to wait in line for at least 1.5 hours.
Be sure to go to both museums. There is an art museum and a jewelry museum (Both are Dali works). He was absoultely brilliant! Expect to be in the museums for 3 hours.

reviewnospace: The lines are long, so the earlier you get there, the better (museum opens at 9:30). The museum's layout is not straightforward, but I didn't mind. The museum does not provide that much information about the different paintings, so you'll have to do your research before or after. The space is beautiful, including the outdoor courtyard (of which you can take some nice pictures as you go to the different floors). The attached jewel museum is small, but worthwhile, especially the heart brooch that actually beats. A really fun museum. Don't miss it!

reviewnospace:
Overall this is worth the trip. I drove south from France and then to his house in Cadaque ad thought the two were nice and easy to do in one day. I read all the negative reviews and was nervous but it is a great museum. I went early-9:20 and there was a line of five people. The museum was not that busy and it's freeing to walk around without a clear direction but there are also numbers so you can follow those if you want. I thought the artwork was interesting and it was nice to see seemingly atypical Dali art. As other reviewers noted, there are no descriptions of the paintings so it can be hard to understand or gain insight into the work. If that is crucial to you then they sell a guidebook you can buy there or on amazon called Dali Figueres that goes over most of the pieces in the museum. Seems a little like a money making scheme to me but probably worth it if you really want to understand Dali--although I'm not sure you are supposed to understand him. The jewelry museum is worth the extra trip next door and is not large so you could run through it in 15 min.
The entire museum took about 1.5 hours for me skimming over most pairings and sculptures. You could spend way more time particularly if you have the book that describes the paintings. All in all, it was a great trip and if I could have only gone to one museum of Dali it would have been this one.

reviewnospace:
An interesting place to see, but need a great capacity to accept we are all different. Some of us, way different!

It is very a strange display and probably some introductory leaflets, given with the tickets, would help the visitors to understand some basic ideas.

Some of the works, to my perception, are indeed great. Some, seemed to me, a terrible kitsch.

When visiting the place, it's probably recommendable to just lay back and observe yet another product of this world. At least for usual tourists, not as familiar with the modern art.

But all in all, in does worth seeing the place. City also worths a short stroll.

reviewnospace: We have an Art major in our family, thus trip was focused on artists (Dali, Picasso, and Gaudi). The museum in Figueres was a good addition to our trip. The lines were not long (we were there on a Monday). The exhibits are spread on three floors of this building (we did the daytime visit). There are four choices when you visit this museum (daytime, night time, a jewelry museum, and his house--which is some distance away). We only had time for the daytime visit. The main entrance lead you to the Cadillac sculpture and garden space. Most of the family broke up and toured the museum the way they wanted. You could take pictures (no flash). It would be a small space if there was a lot more people visiting (like in high season). Most of his main works are not located here, but there are enough to see his style and his relationship to the area he grew up in. His crypt is also located in the building. Our art major loved the visit; our other two college age kids could have spent an hour and left. :)
titleopinion: A day with Dali. We have an Art major in our family, thus trip was focused on artists (Dali, Picasso, and Gaudi). The museum in Figueres was a good addition to our trip. The lines were not long (we were there on a Monday). The exhibits are spread on three floors of this building (we did the daytime visit). There are four choices when you visit this museum (daytime, night time, a jewelry museum, and his house--which is some distance away). We only had time for the daytime visit. The main entrance lead you to the Cadillac sculpture and garden space. Most of the family broke up and toured the museum the way they wanted. You could take pictures (no flash). It would be a small space if there was a lot more people visiting (like in high season). Most of his main works are not located here, but there are enough to see his style and his relationship to the area he grew up in. His crypt is also located in the building. Our art major loved the visit; our other two college age kids could have spent an hour and left. :)

reviewnospace:
If you get tickets to the Dali Museum in Figueres, you are given tickets to the Dali Jewellery Museum next door as well. Between the two museums, we had a spectacular day. At every turn, we found things to make us smile. Definitely worth the trip from Barcelona if that is where you are staying.

We took a taxi from the station because we were pressed for time, and could not be bothered to find the museum, but we heard it is not very difficult to find it from the train station. The taxi driver set the minimum fare at E7.00 approximately and we paid about E10 total for the trip, so if you have the time, and are watching your pennies, it is not far to walk. There was no taxi rank nearby that we could see, so if you will need one to get back to the station, ask the driver who takes you there for his number so you can call him when you are ready to be picked up.

It was not very crowded when we went (early June 2012). Wheelchair access is limited. Lots of cafes nearby.

reviewnospace:
We had the best day out while on our holiday to Castell Montgri last month here. Someone here said its more than a museum and that about wraps it up in a nut shell, you get every thing here for a good price, we got in early thank god because as the day went on the rooms got fuller and there are a lot of rooms to walk into here, put aside 3 - 4 hours.

The town is smallish and easy to get to great roads to and from it, once you get there park there is a huge underground car park very central, if the museum is not for everyone send them off shopping because you will find lots of high end shopping here.

Look as for as the contents, there is no way I could possibly comment, as someone of such genius does not need me to tell you all just how good he is - I will say this however if I was as close to it next week I would go back and gladly pay again - in my humble opinion It Is Amazing !

Here are some photos go and see it you wont regret it.

reviewnospace: Great museum, different, well labeled, light and bright, a pleasure to visit.
